title: ‚ÄòI still want to achieve‚Äô: people living with stage 4 cancer embrace Chris Hoy charity ride
excerpt: Mel Erwin is pragmatic about what it took to get her on a bike. ‚ÄúI have one and a half lungs. I‚Äôm on a treatment drug. I don‚Äôt identify as sporty. I wouldn‚Äôt have done it without a goal.‚Äù
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Mel Erwin is pragmatic about what it took to get her on a bike. ‚ÄúI have one and a half lungs. I‚Äôm on a treatment drug. I don‚Äôt identify as sporty. I wouldn‚Äôt have done it without a goal.‚Äù

This Sunday the 57-year-old will roar up the Campsie Hills north of Glasgow in a ‚Äúcamp as Christmas‚Äù sparkly cape alongside her partner, Sarah, and 3,000 other participants.

It‚Äôs all part of the inaugural Tour de 4, a charity ride conceived by Sir Chris Hoy with the aim of challenging assumptions about those living with stage 4 cancer.

The roaring is literal: during months of training, Erwin has found vocalising ‚Äúreally helps‚Äù on steeper inclines. And the pink and gold sequins encapsulate the spirit of celebrating each day woven through the event, a hallmark of Hoy‚Äôs approach to his own stage 4 prostate cancer.

The six-time Olympic gold medallist stunned the UK late last year when he revealed that his cancer was incurable, with a prognosis of between two and four years to live.

Hoy‚Äôs honesty and grace in sharing his circumstances moved Erwin, who has been living with stage 4 lung cancer for five years. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs rare that people speak out about having stage 4 cancer. The shame, the confusion, it‚Äôs not something we speak about,‚Äù she said.

Hoy describes this unique event, where those living with stage 4 cancer will cycle alongside their loved ones to raise funds for cancer charities across the UK, as ‚Äúan opportunity to push limits‚Äù.

Different routes and levels of participation are tailored to the individual‚Äôs physical capacity ‚Äì from riding a static bike for as little as one minute in the Sir Chris Hoy Velodrome in Glasgow, to three outdoor routes of increasing length and elevation.

‚ÄúThis is not about being the fastest,‚Äù Hoy has reassured participants. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs about preparation, about showing up, riding your way and being part of something bigger than all of us.‚Äù

This notion of it being a movement inspired Erwin, who lives in east London, to get involved. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs about being part of a community. It‚Äôs really isolating having cancer ‚Äì stage 4 cancer in particular,‚Äù she said.

Hoy‚Äôs motivation is ‚Äúto shine a spotlight on what a stage 4 cancer diagnosis can look like and demonstrate that it is possible to live well and lead a happy life alongside this devastating diagnosis‚Äù.

It‚Äôs an attitude that resonated powerfully with Christine Lote, from Bristol, who was diagnosed with stage 4 bone cancer on her eldest daughter‚Äôs third birthday last June. In the ‚Äúwhirlwind of overwhelm and heartbreak‚Äù that followed came Hoy‚Äôs announcement and his memoir All That Matters. Lote, whose daughters Sophie and Chloe are now two and four, appreciated how Hoy had written about ‚Äúnavigating your diagnosis as a family‚Äù.

skip past newsletter promotion

after newsletter promotion

‚ÄúLooking back, I‚Äôd like my girls to see I was part of something that did challenge me, at a time where I could have easily not been so willing,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI want to set that role model for them ‚Äì to be positive and you can still achieve things.‚Äù

A particular achievement for Lote, who trained on the Bristol and Bath railway path, has been re-learning to pedal with a prosthetic after her right leg was amputated below the knee.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been such a focus this year,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúObviously, I can‚Äôt completely forget about the cancer when I‚Äôm out there cycling, but I‚Äôm not thinking too much about the ‚Äòscan-xiety‚Äô and other stuff, I‚Äôm thinking about the cycling.‚Äù

Many people who have experience of cancer describe a brutal loss of trust in their own bodies ‚Äì because cancer can often hide undetected. For Erwin, the training has eased this. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs something about keeping the wheels turning, the fact that my muscles, thighs, heart, lungs, everything is working in synchronicity.‚Äù

title: Britain‚Äôs illegal e-bike boom: desperation, delivery drivers ‚Äì and unthinkable danger
excerpt: A busy Wednesday morning on Bishopsgate in London and Sgt Stuart Ford of the City of London police is pointing out possible offenders. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs not pedalling,‚Äù he says, indicating a man on a bike on the other side of the road. ‚ÄúStill not pedalling, but he is going downhill, he mi‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
A busy Wednesday morning on Bishopsgate in London and Sgt Stuart Ford of the City of London police is pointing out possible offenders. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs not pedalling,‚Äù he says, indicating a man on a bike on the other side of the road. ‚ÄúStill not pedalling, but he is going downhill, he might be all right. I‚Äôd still pull him over and have a look.‚Äù

Not today, though, because the non-pedalling possible offender is heading north, while Ford‚Äôs team ‚Äì two members of the cycle response unit he set up two years ago and leads ‚Äì are facing south on the opposite side of the road. A lot of the unit‚Äôs work centres on illegal e-bikes; they have seized 212 so far this year.

News comes over the radio that PCs Harry Rose and David Parker have stopped someone they suspect is on an illegal e-bike, so we find them with a delivery rider in the familiar green livery of Uber Eats. The man, whose name is Mahede Hasan, says his bike has pedals, and the power of the electric motor is 250 watts, which he thought was allowed.

Ford tilts the bike on its stand and twists the throttle on the right handlebar. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs illegal for a start,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúYou should pedal to make the motor work.‚Äù The bike doesn‚Äôt go anywhere, because the spinning back wheel is off the ground, but the speedometer climbs ‚Äì 20, 30, 40, 50, 52km/h. That‚Äôs about 32mph. ‚ÄúWhat do you think the top speed of this bike should be, with pedal assist?‚Äù he asks Hasan, who doesn‚Äôt know, so Ford tells him. ‚Äú15.5mph [25km/h]. This is basically a motorcycle.‚Äù

E-bikes aren‚Äôt illegal per se, and you will no doubt have noticed their increased popularity in UK cities, including the proliferation of rental ones (you might have views on them blocking pavements, or the fact that the ever-present background noise of urban Britain is the click click click of a kid on a stolen Lime bike, but that is a different issue). To be legal, which the rental bikes are, an e-bike needs to meet certain criteria. These include having pedals that can be used to drive the bike, an electric motor with a maximum power output of 250W, and a maximum assisted speed of 15.5mph. That doesn‚Äôt mean they can‚Äôt go faster, if you pedal hard or go downhill, just that the motor won‚Äôt help above that speed. Essentially, they‚Äôre bicycles with a bit of help, and that‚Äôs how they‚Äôre treated: you don‚Äôt need a licence, registration or insurance to ride one.

The trouble is a lot of e-bikes aren‚Äôt legal to ride on the road, but they are very easy and cheap to get hold of. While the officers complete their paperwork, Hasan, 21, tells me he bought his bike new, on the internet, for ¬£600. ‚ÄúI got it because I do, like, eight or nine hours a day, and if I‚Äôm only pedalling I‚Äôm going to get more tired. An e-bike makes it more comfortable.‚Äù Originally from Bangladesh, he has put a sticker showing a map of the country on the front mudguard.

He assumed the bike was legal because there was nothing on the website he bought it from that said it wasn‚Äôt. ‚ÄúIf it‚Äôs not, how do they sell it to people?‚Äù He says that if he‚Äôd known he was breaking the law, he wouldn‚Äôt have stopped when they pulled him over. The cycle response unit operates on pedal bikes. ‚ÄúI believe they wouldn‚Äôt catch me,‚Äù he says.

The officers tell him they‚Äôre seizing the bike, and he asks if he can keep the detachable battery, which they allow, while he cancels the lunch order he was due to deliver. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs going to affect my account because when you accept a job, that means you‚Äôre committing to delivering to the customer. If you don‚Äôt, that‚Äôs your problem, not the company‚Äôs.‚Äù

title: Why fear the tote bag-wielding, matcha-drinking ‚Äòperformative male‚Äô? At least he makes an effort | Rachel Connolly
excerpt: Picture a man sitting opposite you on public transport. He wields a copy of The Will to Change by bell hooks, and he takes care to parade the front cover or the spine lest any nearby strangers miss the title. He is in his 20s or 30s and conventionally attractive; maybe he has ‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Picture a man sitting opposite you on public transport. He wields a copy of The Will to Change by bell hooks, and he takes care to parade the front cover or the spine lest any nearby strangers miss the title. He is in his 20s or 30s and conventionally attractive; maybe he has a dangly earring or two. There on his knee rests a tote bag. This man would not engage in loutish, careless behaviour like ‚Äúmanspreading‚Äù or placing all his stuff on the seats. And the tote bag probably bears the logo of an ethical brand or a bookshop. The bag is probably adorned with social-justice badges. If he showed you what music he is listening to, it might be, say, Lana Del Rey or Clairo.

Here we have the performative male ‚Äì a new kind of vaguely problematic man to watch out for. And one who is the subject of all manner of viral TikToks and memes, and media coverage everywhere from GQ to the New York Times, which reported on a recent performative male contest in Seattle. For some reason when I picture him he always has curly hair. Big bouncy lustrous curls. You can probably add your own details, but you get the picture. The idea is that the performative male is a guy who goes about looking feminist and woke. The catch is that his aesthetic is curated to appeal to what he thinks women might like rather than being a totally earnest expression of his interests.

Imagine that! A person choosing clothes and accessories to increase their attractiveness in the eyes of the gender they are trying to sleep with. Very insidious and unusual behaviour. I can tell you right now I have never once in my life participated in such a charade. I will admit, too, that some of this coverage has made me feel baffled by what is apparently considered desirable. The performative male is said to wear several Labubus and drink matcha. I don‚Äôt really understand why this would lure women in. It‚Äôs even been suggested a performative male might stow tampons on his person. But if I met a cisgender man who made a point of carrying tampons around with him I‚Äôd probably telephone the police.

My first thought, when I came across this trend, was: God, straight men cannot win. My second was: yes, this aesthetic is very common ‚Äì not just with men but with women too. A parade of images flashed before me of all the young women and men I have seen self-consciously clutching their unbroken copies of Angela Davis and so on in coffee shops and on the bus. ‚ÄúA lot of the time they don‚Äôt know what they‚Äôre talking about,‚Äù one of the hosts of the Seattle performative male contest told the NYT, speaking about the kind of men who adopt this look. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just an aesthetic for them.‚Äù But I would gently submit that a substantial proportion of the women who take care to post highlighted and pencilled-over pages of bell hooks to Instagram do not put much of the ethos of her work into practice in their own lives either.

After all, performative righteousness is not solely the preserve of young men. I have often felt that the parallel vapidness and popularity of online social-justice messaging has created an entire generation (or two) of people obsessed with the idea of telegraphing their own worthiness rather than practising it.

As the performative male trend has gained traction, I have received a few PR emails about it on behalf of ‚Äúexperts‚Äù with funky job titles offering to help counsel young women to spot toxic signs and red flags in the opposite sex. These missives, which I receive every time a new dating trend is coined, are always full of my own personal red flags. One such email on behalf of a ‚Äúrelationship coach‚Äù explained that the performative male is dangerous because he ‚Äúspeaks the language of emotional availability but doesn‚Äôt practise it‚Äù. I am happy to say that, for all its shadowy allusions to grave transgression, I have no idea what this sentence means.

title: Taylor Swift‚Äôs romantic travails were the soundtrack to mine. What does her engagement mean for fans‚Äô love lives? | Hollie Richardson
excerpt: Taylor Swift wrote today‚Äôs headlines when she was only 17 with her country hit Love Story: ‚ÄúBaby, just say yes!‚Äù Now, at 35, she has announced her engagement to Travis Kelce, her American football player partner of two years, who got down on one knee and popped the question. ‚Äú‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Taylor Swift wrote today‚Äôs headlines when she was only 17 with her country hit Love Story: ‚ÄúBaby, just say yes!‚Äù Now, at 35, she has announced her engagement to Travis Kelce, her American football player partner of two years, who got down on one knee and popped the question. ‚ÄúYour English teacher and your gym teacher are getting married,‚Äù she captioned the subsequently staged engagement photos of them in a rose garden. It‚Äôs gaudy, it‚Äôs cringe, it‚Äôs gleefully too much ‚Äì some even say it makes the Bezos wedding look classy. But it‚Äôs perfect and it made me cry.

When the pop star who has soundtracked your entire adult love life gets engaged, it‚Äôs discombobulating. Especially when they are similar in age. Over two decades, Swift has gifted a song for every crush, relationship, situationship, and heartbreak. (I even once plagiarised All Too Well lyrics in a very embarrassing email to an ex-boyfriend; he never did reply to my calling him ‚Äúso casually cruel in the name of being honest‚Äù.)

But marriage is new territory. Similarly to when a mate tells me they‚Äôre getting married, my delight over the news has been chased by bittersweet pangs of change and reflection: what role does Swift‚Äôs music play in our romantic lives now?

This article includes content provided by Instagram. We ask for your permission before anything is loaded, as they may be using cookies and other technologies. To view this content, click 'Allow and continue'.

She was there for those first flutters and disappointments: a teenager singing out loud the kind of heart-on-sleeve confessions that we kept safely hidden in our diaries (including ones way beyond teenhood). On the one hand, you could slot yourself into the lyrics of the story she‚Äôs telling: ‚ÄúPlease don‚Äôt be in love with someone else,‚Äù she hoped in Enchanted. But then, you could go and find out exactly who she is writing about: ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you think I was too young to be messed with?‚Äù she asked in Dear John, presumed by many to be about her musician ex John Mayer, which Swift never confirmed or denied. This triggered a global obsession with her relationships, but it has never stopped her writing about them, thank God. Weirdly, she makes dating famous people juicy and relatable.

When we reached our 20s, ready to bite back at bad boys, the Red album was the ultimate bible of breakup bangers. Who didn‚Äôt fall to the floor screaming ‚ÄúOH!‚Äù when I Knew You Were Trouble came on? But she was at her most vulnerable, too, in All Too Well ‚Äì a power ballad that even now pierces me with the pain of life after short-lived loves. The next album, 1989, was more upbeat but just as scathing: I‚Äôm not ashamed to say that, during the peak of Blank Space, I clinked my drained wine glass at a dinner, stood up and announced: ‚ÄúBoys only want love if it‚Äôs torture‚Äù.

Then Swift fell in love. Her 2017 album Reputation might have been vengeful, but the industry was the target, because her new boyfriend Joe Alwyn was actually nice! A classically handsome actor (‚ÄúWhat can I say? You‚Äôre gorgeous‚Äù) who scratched her English thesp itch and was happy to shelter with her away from the bullshit (‚ÄúHe built a fire just to keep me warm‚Äù). Only someone totally lost in a cloud of sparkly love could then seriously release saccharine odes Me! and London Boy.

They stayed together for six years and during that time she turned to writing more fictional songs, sometimes with Alwyn, on lockdown albums Folklore and Evermore. Look, I was happy for Swift and enjoyed ditties about the heiress Rebekah Harkness, former owner of Swift‚Äôs mansion, having a marvellous time ruining everything ‚Ä¶ but when she and Alwyn called it quits and she quickly started dating the 1975‚Äôs Matty Healy, I was ready for the real-life dramas she essayed between her and Healy in last year‚Äôs The Tortured Poets Department.

title: ‚ÄòI thought, I can‚Äôt keep living with this shame‚Äô: five life models on the power of posing nude
excerpt: Craig, 54 ( @tattooed_nude ) I started life modelling 18 months ago. My mum said: ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre getting all these tattoos and no one gets to see them.‚Äù That triggered something in me. I‚Äôve always loved art and I wanted to see how artists would respond to my tattoos.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
‚ÄòIt has changed my life‚Äô

Craig, 54 (@tattooed_nude)
I started life modelling 18 months ago. My mum said: ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre getting all these tattoos and no one gets to see them.‚Äù That triggered something in me. I‚Äôve always loved art and I wanted to see how artists would respond to my tattoos.

I replied to a local advert looking for life models on Instagram. I was only given two hours‚Äô notice before my first class, because another model had dropped out. There were 30 to 40 people there ‚Äì I‚Äôd never been naked in front of so many people before.

  • ‚ÄòI feel a responsibility to get into interesting and adventurous poses that will inspire the artists.‚Äô Photograph: @garygeezerphotoart

I felt very self-conscious and vulnerable. It was like an out-of-body experience. Now, I usually forget all about my nudity ‚Äì and I‚Äôm always getting great feedback on my poses. I base them on the Austrian painter Egon Schiele‚Äôs work: I make them quite angular and dynamic, and use my hands a lot.

It‚Äôs a very physical job. I feel a responsibility to get into interesting and adventurous poses that will inspire the artists. I never feel bored, but sometimes I wish a pose would end. If you stay in any position long enough, it becomes uncomfortable. I‚Äôve had dead legs that have taken days to recover, as well as back and neck ache.

  • ‚ÄòSome more traditional classes refuse to hire me because of my tattoos.‚Äô Photograph: Courtesy of Craig

I‚Äôve never done yoga or gymnastics, but I do work out using kettlebells. I‚Äôve spent about ¬£35,000 on my tattoos and I don‚Äôt want to lose my shape and distort them. While some more traditional classes refuse to hire me because of my tattoos, other artists want to draw a model who‚Äôs a bit different or will inspire them to be more expressive with colour. I force them out of their comfort zone and that‚Äôs really rewarding for me.

  • ‚ÄòI display the best ones in my flat, though I turn them to face the wall when my mum and sister visit.‚Äô Photograph: Bruce Mulcahy

Becoming a life model has changed my life. I travel around the country now, mixing in artists‚Äô circles and feeling more like an insider in the art world. I used to visit exhibitions ‚Äì now I‚Äôm in them and I meet the artists afterwards. I typically earn ¬£20 to ¬£25 an hour, and some artists give me their work afterwards. I display the best ones in my studio flat, though I turn them to face the wall when my mum and sister visit.

A lot of my classes are for young people, such as sixth formers. Although I‚Äôm 54, I don‚Äôt feel uncomfortable about that ‚Äì drawing from a live model is an important part of their development as artists. They could be the next Jenny Saville.

‚ÄòWhen I uncovered my naked body, I was waiting for the laughter‚Äô

Geoff, 56 (@yorkslifemodel)

  • ‚ÄòFor more than 40 years, I had hated my body‚Äô ‚Ä¶ Geoff. Photograph: Steven Curtis.

I have attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and I am super shy and quiet. But I wanted a hobby, so I took an adult education class to learn how to draw. For two years, I didn‚Äôt really speak to anyone in the class. Then, at our regular weekly life drawing class, the model didn‚Äôt show up. I surprised myself by saying: ‚ÄúI‚Äôll do it.‚Äù

I volunteered because, for more than 40 years, I had hated my body. I started puberty early and was bullied by other children for being circumcised, and then, as an uncontrollable, non-sexual reaction to feeling intensely embarrassed, getting an erection at school. Gangs of boys and girls would chase after me, calling me names and laughing at me to trigger this reaction. It went on for years.

For decades afterwards, I never wanted anyone to see me naked ‚Äì or even to see myself naked ‚Äì because it just brought back the voices and the laughter. I call those memories ‚Äúthe shadows‚Äù, because they feel like darkness coming over me.

title: The one change that worked: I sobered up ‚Äì and started to listen to what my body was telling me
excerpt: Most of my adult life has revolved around music: clubs, bars, festivals, house parties ‚Äì anywhere I could dance to loud music. I loved how energising and cathartic it was to get immersed in it, to lose myself a little and move my body expressively without judgment. I‚Äôd get so ‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Most of my adult life has revolved around music: clubs, bars, festivals, house parties ‚Äì anywhere I could dance to loud music. I loved how energising and cathartic it was to get immersed in it, to lose myself a little and move my body expressively without judgment. I‚Äôd get so absorbed that I would lose track of time; once, at Burning Man, I was awake for 36 hours exploring the festival, meeting new people and partying.

When I became a DJ, these kinds of events increased. Late nights out would last until the morning. Often, they became marathon weekend sessions, which ran from Friday night to Sunday lunchtime. It wasn‚Äôt all dancing and shenanigans ‚Äì there would be moments to sit around and chat with people, too. I‚Äôd be out at least three times a week. Even though I‚Äôd get tired, I would always find some way to push through to the early hours because I was scared to miss out on things. Fomo (fear of missing out) drove many of my decisions.

My work never suffered but my mental health did. I started to feel anxious and dangerously close to burnout. Consumed with self-loathing, I wanted to stop but couldn‚Äôt figure out how ‚Äì until I went on a 10-day silent meditation course.

It was then that I realised the life I was living was unsustainable. But it took a while to unravel my hedonism and habitual indulgence. I went sober because I wanted to rid myself of the brain fog and fatigue I was often bogged down with.

Learning to navigate nights out without a crutch to keep me going sparked an important shift in my approach to parties and festivals. Instead of giving in to Fomo, I have learned to listen to what my body is telling me rather than ignoring the signs. Tired legs usually spark a well-earned sit down or, in some cases, I will call it a night and get myself home to bed. This kind of behaviour was unheard of between the ages of 17 and 37, when I had my last drink. Back then, I would keep going even when I was exhausted.

It hasn‚Äôt been easy, though. Being sober is hard work. Not having an easy escape can be very challenging. I had to learn how to be more confident and expressive without ingesting anything. Dancing while sober is still fun but it‚Äôs tricky dealing with how self-conscious you feel.

Responding to my body‚Äôs needs consciously and waving goodbye to Fomo have given me a real sense of stability. Every time I‚Äôve made the decision to have an early night or given myself time to rest has reinforced my self-respect and self-love. The gradual accumulation of healthy decisions has been life-changing for me. The dancefloor has been my sanctuary for a long time. Now I can happily get my fill and go home when the time is right, without ever feeling as if I‚Äôm missing out. That peace of mind is priceless.

title: The kindness of strangers: a nurse saw me crying and asked if I wanted a hug
excerpt: In 2024, I was unexpectedly diagnosed with leukaemia. I was 34. I had no symptoms (none!) and it came at the worst possible time, although there is never a good time.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
In 2024, I was unexpectedly diagnosed with leukaemia. I was 34. I had no symptoms (none!) and it came at the worst possible time, although there is never a good time.

I am a musician and was one week away from flying to New Zealand to be in a show. I was extremely excited about the show and, to be organised, I thought I‚Äôd get a blood test to check my iron levels before I left the country for five weeks.

Six hours after the blood test, I got a call from my doctor telling me that something was wrong. I was what‚Äôs called neutropenic. In layman‚Äôs terms it meant I had no immune system and I needed to go to hospital immediately.

It made no sense. I had been in Savers, at my nieces‚Äô school fete and the pub the day before. The doctor said to wear two masks and stand outside or I might not survive an infection ‚Äì which sounded like a ridiculous overreaction for what I was sure was a mixed-up test. It wasn‚Äôt. After entering that hospital I wouldn‚Äôt leave it again for six weeks.

About 7pm I was told I had cancer (who knew they have haematologists in emergency?). The diagnosis was utterly overwhelming. Although my family is amazing, they weren‚Äôt close by that night. A friend had come for a few hours to help translate what the doctors were saying while I was in a state of shock. But I was alone in my hospital bed when I woke up around 3am and it all suddenly hit me. All I could think about was that not only was I not going to New Zealand, but I also had cancer, and it was going to kill me. It always seems to kill people in the movies ‚Äì writers, I beg you to stop doing that. Lots of us live.

As I was death-spiralling, a nurse walked past and asked if I was OK. I wasn‚Äôt. I just dissolved and, through tears, explained what was happening. He asked if I wanted a hug. I did, and I have never needed one more in my life. His name was Ben.

That night was probably the scariest part of my whole time with cancer ‚Äì I‚Äôm now in remission. I never saw Ben again but his name stuck with me through the six weeks in hospital and eight months of chemo. His kind act meant the world to me then, and still means the world to me now.

What is the nicest thing a stranger has ever done for you?

title: SUNY New Paltz Presents Composium, a Series of Events Exploring Sustainability in the Arts
excerpt: With a full slate of workshops, talks, and exhibitions focused on sustainable arts practices, SUNY New Paltz is thrilled to present its 2025 Composium from September 18 through 20 at the SUNY New Paltz campus.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
With a full slate of workshops, talks, and exhibitions focused on sustainable arts practices, SUNY New Paltz is thrilled to present its 2025 Composium from September 18 through 20 at the SUNY New Paltz campus.

This year‚Äôs keynote address, ‚ÄúSustainability as a Collaborative Practice,‚Äù will be presented by cross-disciplinary artist sTo Len, who will discuss his holistic, community-minded approach to creating ecologically transformational work.¬†

Also on Friday, artist and author Natalie Stopka discusses her work utilizing botanical color in re-envisioning ecological relations and shares the colorful stories of her historically inspired plant pigments. On Saturday, Natalie hosts a workshop on using foraged ink and pastels.¬†

On Saturday, artist Venetia Dale will present a survey of her pewter and fiber sculptural works that speak to the emotional landscape and interconnection of mothering, interpersonal relationships, and community.¬†¬†

All talks will be held in-person as well as livestreamed online.¬†¬†

The Composium features three events with ceramicist Lisa Orr, including the construction of an ultra-efficient, zero-smoke wood kiln on Thursday, September 18; a firing in the kiln filled with work made from locally foraged clay on Friday, September 19; and an unloading and evaluation of the firing on Saturday, September 20.¬†

SUNY New Paltz metal students will exhibit their collaborations with Radical Jewelry Makeover, a project that works with jewelers of all levels to educate people about mining and material sourcing issues involved in jewelry making.¬†¬†

Other exciting Composium offerings include a foraging walk and ethnobotanical tour of SUNY New Paltz with Matthew Friday; a charcoal retort presented by Michael Asbill and Ripley Butterfield of Processing Collapse; and a public meal of foraged and locally sourced food in SUNY New Paltz‚Äôs EcoArtLab.¬†

Composium is free and open to the public.¬†

To learn more and register, visit newpaltz.edu or contact Matthew Friday at fridaym@newpaltz.edu .

We don‚Äôt think even the best immersion blender should replace your regular blender outright, but they are a convenient addition to a well-stocked kitchen. Sometimes called stick blenders or hand blenders, immersion blenders are lightweight and small enough to tuck into a drawer when you‚Äôre not using them and a breeze to clean (just run the blender in a cup or bowl of hot soapy water, then rinse). They allow you to conveniently puree soups in the pot you‚Äôve cooked them in, or blend dips and sauces in the bowl you‚Äôll serve them in, meaning less mess and fewer dishes. Immersion blenders can emulsify salad dressings or aioli quickly, without requiring you to dig your big blender out of the cabinet for such a small task.

Our top picks:

  • Best overall: All-Clad Corded Immersion Blender
  • Best with attachments: Breville Control Grip Immersion Blender
  • Best budget immersion blender: Amazon Basics Multi-Speed Immersion Blender

Featured in this article

BA editors reach for immersion blenders in our own kitchens most often for hot soups (it‚Äôs a nightmare to have to transfer a hot liquid into a full-sized blender, not to mention dangerous), and for quick blends where you still want some texture, like pestos or chutneys. They‚Äôll never be able to handle tougher tasks that a high-speed, full-sized blender like a Vitamix 5200 can‚Äîno crushing nuts into butter or milk‚Äîand they‚Äôll take longer to achieve the level of creaminess in a pur√©e that you can get in a regular blender. But they absolutely cannot be beat in terms of convenience.

Most models come with chopper and whisk attachments, so in a pinch, they are versatile enough to whip cream and egg whites, and, in many cases, act as mini choppers. They‚Äôre great as the single blender for a dorm room or first kitchen.

Over the last few years, we‚Äôve tested and retested more than a dozen popular models over the course of countless hours, living with them in our home kitchens and using them daily, to find the best and most versatile options. Read our review of the best immersion blenders below.

Best immersion blender overall: All-Clad Corded Immersion Blender

Pros & cons

Pros:

  • Feels sturdy
  • Quality materials
  • Easy to use
  • From a trusted cookware brand

Cons:

  • Attachments sold separately
  • Blade guard lacks protective rim

Specs

Blending depth: 9.25"Power: 600 wattsPower settings: Variable plus turboIncluded attachments: NoneWarranty: Limited lifetime warranty

All-Clad‚Äôs stainless-steel corded immersion blender has been our top pick for years, after testing and retesting against new models‚Äîand it‚Äôs the immersion blender you‚Äôll find in the BA test kitchen.

What we love: All-Clad‚Äôs powerful handheld blender has a 600-watt motor that quickly and easily turns solid ingredients into soups and smoothies, even if you don‚Äôt engage the Turbo button (which turns this thing up to ‚Äú11‚Äù). The top of the motor handle also features a variable speed dial that lets you adjust the power while blending (a feature we liked less than the two speed buttons; more on that below). And even at a lower speed, this blender can handle most smaller blending jobs in less than 60 seconds.

The dishwasher-safe blending shaft on the All-Clad is 9.25" (longer than many of the models we tested), which makes it easy to blend in tall containers or pots. Though the shaft is long, the blending head (the blade guard and blade) is on the shallow side, which meant it sometimes requires a little extra time to get started on bigger chunks of solid ingredients‚Äîbut once something gets sucked into this blender‚Äôs powerful vortex, it will quickly be pulverized or pur√©ed.

This blender is more expensive than most of its competition, and it really is possible to get a well-functioning immersion blender for much less. However, this machine is made of high-quality materials, from a brand we trust to make products that last. It features a limited lifetime warranty. So we think it‚Äôs a great decision to splurge and take good care of your machine, so you won‚Äôt have to replace it later.

For three seasons on FX's The Bear, actor and comedian Joel McHale portrayed an abusive chef so realistically that it was triggering to real-life kitchen workers. But aside from one short stint working at a Seattle deli under a manager with an incredibly short fuse ("This guy was a screamer‚Äîand he was fired," McHale says), the kitchen has been a place of joy for McHale.

‚ÄúIf I'm home, I'm the cook,‚Äù says McHale, who also hosts the Fox cooking competition series Crime Scene Kitchen and is a spokesperson for Seattle's Best Coffee. "I am very good at cooking meat.‚Äù In fact, he tells me he has plans immediately following our interview to roast a couple of chickens for guests he has joining him for dinner.

Last year, in what McHale calls ‚Äúone of his finest cooking moments,‚Äù he got to show off his steak-searing skills as a guest on restauranteur and chef (and friend) David Chang's Netflix show, Dinner Time Live. ‚ÄúI was not expecting you, on live TV, to actually cook a beautiful steak," Chang said on the show. "And I'm wrong."

Below, McHale shares some of the tools and gear he uses to master the grill as well as the pantry items he always keeps stocked.

A monster smoker

McHale takes his meat smoking seriously‚Äîand that means using some pretty serious tools. ‚ÄúI have a Pitts and Spitts, a brand out of Texas, which is as tough as a Sherman tank," he says. ‚ÄúI can smoke a pork tenderloin like nobody's business, and a few months ago I made a chateaubriand.‚Äù

Other favorite recipes in McHale's rotation: "For Thanksgiving, I smoked a bunch of tri-tips. Two nights ago I made this dish where I take a whole chicken breast with the skin and part of the bone, then season them up a little bit, sear the outsides off, and then I put them into a tomato and Iberico ham sauce.‚Äù

Instructions from an all-star

For burgers, McHale says he uses Gordon Ramsay's burger blend method‚Äîa 70/20/10 ratio, with 70% chuck steak, 20% short rib, and 10% fat, as Ramsay explained on Masterchef.

Good, old-fashioned tongs

‚ÄúI had a whole argument with David Chang about tongs," says McHale. ‚ÄúHe thinks tongs are amateur hour.‚Äù But McHale has no shame in using the tool‚Äî"I'll send [Chang] photos of tongs resting on the side of a dish," he says‚Äîespecially in a pinch.

‚ÄúWhen I cooked the steak for Dinner Time Live, [using the tongs] had to be done because I only had, like, 25 minutes,‚Äù McHale says. To get a beautiful, golden crust on the steak, "I salted the hell out of it and put it in oil. Then I put weight on top of the meat to spread it out, and flipped it.‚Äù McHale finished his dish by frying eggs in the beef fat left in the pan for steak and eggs.

Ghee and Wagyu beef tallow

For cooking fat, McHale likes to use Wagyu beef tallow or ghee. ‚ÄúUsing ghee makes you look like a cook,‚Äù he says.

A caffeine fix

‚ÄúI grew up in Seattle, where I worked at a coffee cart for years and drank tons of coffee," says McHale. ‚ÄúI continue to‚ÄîI probably had eight cups so far this morning, which is about average.‚Äù

While Seattle's Best beans take McHale on a trip down memory lane, he's also recently been enjoying one of the brand's new launches. ‚ÄúFor the summer, Seattle's Best released all these limited edition Coffee Roast Mallows‚Äù in collaboration with XO Marshmallow, says McHale. "All the marshmallow flavors are inspired by the different blends of their coffee‚Äù‚Äîwhich, it turns out, is exactly where McHale likes to put them. (Why should hot cocoa get all the fun?)

title: How Servers Really Feel About the "No Tax on Tips" Law
excerpt: On July 4, the One Big Beautiful Bill Act was signed into law, restructuring, among other monumental changes, the way tips would be taxed for service workers. The law is the fulfillment of a campaign promise President Trump made nearly exactly a year prior in a campaign speech‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
On July 4, the One Big Beautiful Bill Act was signed into law, restructuring, among other monumental changes, the way tips would be taxed for service workers. The law is the fulfillment of a campaign promise President Trump made nearly exactly a year prior in a campaign speech in Las Vegas on July 9, 2024. ‚ÄúFor those hotel workers and people that get tips, you‚Äôre gonna be very happy,‚Äù he said at the time. ‚ÄúBecause when I get to office, we are going to not charge taxes on tips.‚Äù

Although it's colloquially referred to as ‚Äúno tax on tips,‚Äù the legislation isn‚Äôt as straightforward as simply eliminating all taxes on gratuities. Section 70201 of the new law states, ‚ÄúThere shall be allowed as a deduction an amount equal to the qualified tips received during the taxable year that are included on statements furnished to the individual.‚Äù

But ‚Äúthere's a limit of how much in tips you can deduct for purposes affecting income tax‚Äîit‚Äôs up to $25,000,‚Äù explains Garrett Watson, director of policy analysis at the Tax Foundation, a nonpartisan tax-policy-focused think tank. There are income restrictions on the deduction too. ‚ÄúIf you have income above $150,000 if you're single, or $300,000 if you‚Äôre filing jointly, the value of this deduction phases out,‚Äù Watson says.

The idea of a tip-based tax deduction received widespread support from both sides of the aisle‚ÄîKamala Harris endorsed the policy on the campaign trail as well‚Äîbut now that it‚Äôs law, how might it impact servers? The tipping system has been in the spotlight in recent years, criticized for its racist foundations, and increasingly unpopular with diners who have begun to feel tip fatigue. This new legislation is positioned as a step forward for a system that‚Äôs long needed improvements. Could it have a significant impact on servers‚Äô and bartenders‚Äô finances, or is it all smoke and mirrors wrapped up in a shiny populist talking point?

Lessening the tax burden on tipped workers looks good on paper, but the research shows that the effect will be relatively limited. Research from the Tax Policy Center shows 40% of households with tipped workers would receive no benefit at all. On average, the same report concluded that tax savings would come out to $1,800 a year, or $35 a week.

For some servers, any savings is a boon. ‚ÄúEvery dollar goes far,‚Äù says Louis Leffler, a server in Denver. ‚ÄúIt helps me give my kid a music class, or a swimming class.‚Äù

How the Restaurant Industry is Responding to ‚ÄúNo Tax on Tips‚Äù

Restaurant industry advocates have other concerns. Saru Jayaraman, president of One Fair Wage, a national nonprofit that advocates for the abolition of the subminimum wage, calls the ‚Äúno tax on tips‚Äù law a red herring. Many tipped workers, she says, don‚Äôt earn enough money to have to pay federal income tax. Data from the Yale Budget Lab, a nonpartisan policy research center, support Jayaraman‚Äôs position. According to a June 2024 report, 37% of tipped workers had incomes low enough that they faced no federal income tax in 2022. The same report estimates that just 2.5% of the workforce is in tipped occupations. Both figures suggest untaxed tips would have limited benefits for tipped workers and certainly for the broader American workforce.

And while the bill holds very limited benefits for tipped workers, it also lays out major cuts to both SNAP and Medicaid benefits, both social services that restaurant workers in particular must lean on, according to a recent report from One Fair Wage. SNAP faces $186 billion in funding cuts, while Medicaid will be cut by nearly $1 trillion.

Data published by the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities shows that 10% of total SNAP participants work in restaurants, the largest single industry among SNAP beneficiaries. More than 1.5 million restaurant and food service workers rely on Medicaid. ‚ÄúIf we want to actually benefit workers,‚Äù says Raeghn Draper, executive director of the CHAAD project, a Chicago-based restaurant worker advocacy group, ‚Äúlet‚Äôs give them something that‚Äôs permanent: Let‚Äôs raise wages, let‚Äôs have universal health care.‚Äù

Welcome to 5 O‚ÄôClock Somewhere, a new series in which our network of culinary all-stars share their favorite drinks‚Äîalong with everything you need to serve them in style.

The Honey Deuce is a marvel of modern marketing. Nineteen years ago, restauranteur and Grey Goose brand ambassador Nick Mautone (his resume includes time as the former managing partner of Gramercy Tavern and hospitality director at the Rainbow Room, among other bona fides) was tasked with dreaming up a signature cocktail for the US Open. For decades mint juleps have been must-haves for viewing the Kentucky Derby and anyone who's anybody sips a Pimm's cup at Wimbledon‚Äîand Grey Goose, it's safe to assume, wanted to cement itself as a permanent part of the US Open experience.

As the story goes, inspiration struck Mautone when he was creating a fruity dessert for a dinner party he was hosting at his home in Hampton Bays (as one does). "I was at the kitchen counter making these honeydew melon balls and I just said to my wife, 'Oh my God, these look like tennis balls,'" Mautone says. He borrowed the flavor profile from his dessert‚Äîberries, citrus, melon, and a hint of rosemary‚Äîadded the required Grey Goose vodka, and, Voil√†! The Honey Deuce.

Is it on the nose to serve a cocktail that literally looks like sporting equipment at a Grand Slam tournament? Absolutely. But lucky for Grey Goose and for tennis fans, the Honey Deuce is also delightful on the palate. What better to sip on a late summer afternoon or evening than, essentially, a spiked raspberry lemonade?

Millions agree, making the Honey Deuce a hit: According to Grey Goose, nearly 3 million have been sold since the drink's debut in 2007, but the Deuce really hit its stride in 2024, with over 550,000 enjoyed during last year‚Äôs tournament alone.

But you don't need to hoof it out to Queens to enjoy the drink. Below, Mautone shares the Honey Deuce's official recipe, some ideas for snazzing it up, and all the gear you need to make and serve it at your US Open watch party.

The Honey Deuce

Ingredients:

  • 1¬º oz Grey Goose vodka
  • 3 oz fresh lemonade
  • ¬Ω oz raspberry liquor
  • 3 honeydew melon balls (frozen) for garnish

Preparation:

  • Fill a highball glass with cubed ice
  • Add vodka, then top with lemonade and raspberry liqueur
  • Garnish with your melon balls on a skewer

The gear you need

Vodka and raspberry liqueur

One of the original stipulations for the cocktail was that it needed to feature Grey Goose's flagship vodka, not any flavored varieties. You of course can sub in your vodka of choice, but why mess with an icon?

Highball glass

According to Mautone, "The simplest, easiest glass to use is a highball glass." You can go chic with classic crystal, or choose kitsch with something more playful. "A couple of years ago I was hosting a US Open party and bought about 30 of the signature Honey Deuce glasses on eBay," he says.

"I also love putting the Honey Deuce in a nice, big balloon wine glass for the very simple reason that it looks elegant," says Mautone. For a ritzy spin on the original recipe worthy of such a classy glass, he recommends adding a splash of off-dry sparkling wine or seltzer. "It's a little bit fizzy, a little bit tart, a little bit sweet. And the sparkling wine also cuts the sweetness," he says.

Melon baller

Uh duh, can't forget this, lest you end up with melon cubes in your drink. (What is this, Picasso's tennis tournament?) Mautone says you don't need to spend a lot of money on your Parisienne scoop‚Äîone of his go-to brands for kitchen tools is Oxo. "The brand's products are just designed well," he says.

title: This is how we do it: ‚ÄòWe were evicted from our home due to noisy sex. We call it our bang to rights moment‚Äô

body:
Chris, 24

We try to be respectful and, obviously, we don‚Äôt want to cause people alarm, but we‚Äôre very noisy creatures

Luke is 20 years older than me. If he‚Äôd had a history of dating younger people, I wouldn‚Äôt have pursued it because I think there‚Äôs an inherent power imbalance that comes with age-gap relationships. It‚Äôs something we discussed from the start, but it doesn‚Äôt come up for us sexually. I‚Äôve been with more sexual partners than Luke has, so I had more experience than him in terms of kink and BDSM.

About 80% of our sex is BDSM, but we‚Äôre both very touchy people, so there‚Äôs a lot of cuddling throughout the day. We were actually evicted from our home due to noisy sex. We were getting complaints from the neighbours downstairs. At one point, the housing association office came to the door when we were having sex ‚Äì we call it our bang to rights moment.

We try to be respectful and, obviously, we don‚Äôt want to cause people alarm, but we‚Äôre very noisy creatures. Now we‚Äôve got the mattresses on the floor, so we‚Äôve learned our lesson.

When we met, I was pre-transition, and I worried that someone who found me attractive then might not fancy me after I‚Äôd taken testosterone. I had my guard up, and while I enjoyed Luke‚Äôs company, I really didn‚Äôt think much would come of it.

But both of us are really happy to be proven wrong, and it is a really beautiful thing to have been on this journey with him, and to have shared this experience.

Luke finds me just as attractive with a bit of facial hair. He‚Äôs been super supportive, and I‚Äôm more self-confident in my own body now. I‚Äôm far more comfortable with who I am, and that is a fantastic feeling. It‚Äôs all had a really positive effect on my life ‚Äì and on our sex life. I‚Äôve now been on testosterone for a year and a half, which comes with increased libido. My desires are stronger than ever and I‚Äôm a feistier in bed now. Every time I go to the gender clinic, we pick up about 60 packets of lube, which we get through in about three days.

Luke, 44

Even just using the correct pronouns while we were having sex and seeing how much extra fire that added was lovely

I‚Äôm not a religious person, but sex to me is almost like something that‚Äôs transcendental. When you‚Äôve got someone else on board with that uninhibited expression of human sexuality, I don‚Äôt think there‚Äôs any greater joy.

Sex with Chris is joyous and fun. We can‚Äôt get enough of each other. We met at a bar three years ago, and when we first started going out I wasn‚Äôt sure if we‚Äôd be long term as there‚Äôs a 20-year age gap. I thought it would lead to problems, or an imbalance in terms of emotion and life experience. But we had such a connection and I found life was so much better with him.

We did get carried away at the beginning. It was probably five times a day after we moved in together. I had just lost my job and we had a lot more free time together, and that‚Äôs when we had a lot of noise complaints from the neighbour. We probably could have handled it a wee bit more diplomatically, but life is short so you might as well just go for it.

I‚Äôve found that dirty talk can really enhance sex, it‚Äôs like a little bit of seasoning you put on the experience. We also use a lot of restraints and things like that, and we‚Äôve ended up having a wide arsenal of things to do.

In the last year, Chris has started taking hormone replacement therapy, and his treatment has allowed him to feel more comfortable in his own skin. To see that has been one of the most rewarding and exciting things in my life. Even just using the correct pronouns while we were having sex and seeing how much extra fire that added was absolutely lovely.

title: Women cope better when their partner dies. I‚Äôll have to go before him, out of spite
excerpt: David Mitchell is probably the only male on the planet who could get away with defending mansplaining, so that is what he has done. ‚ÄúI feel there‚Äôs an unfairness to the term, which is taken to be men explaining things in a boring way to women,‚Äù he told the Sunday Times . ‚ÄúBeca‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
David Mitchell is probably the only male on the planet who could get away with defending mansplaining, so that is what he has done. ‚ÄúI feel there‚Äôs an unfairness to the term, which is taken to be men explaining things in a boring way to women,‚Äù he told the Sunday Times. ‚ÄúBecause they do it to each other, and they take turns, and that‚Äôs what men call a conversation.‚Äù

In the same interview, Mitchell and his comedy partner Robert Webb are asked how each counselled and supported the other through various personal challenges. They are confused and slightly aghast at the idea that they might have discussed such matters. What do men talk to one another about, then? ‚ÄúWell, yes,‚Äù says Mitchell. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a question [my wife] Victoria‚Äôs asked me many times. And I never really know.‚Äù

This insight came in the same week Rylan Clark revealed what he has learned from hosting his podcast How to Be in Love. ‚ÄúI never really understood when people said, ‚Äòmy partner is my best friend,‚Äô‚Äù he admitted. ‚ÄúBecause I thought, well, my partner is not my best friend ‚Äì my best friend is my best friend. I didn‚Äôt get it. But I‚Äôve realised that your partner can be that.‚Äù

Hmmm ‚Ä¶ can they, though? As so perfectly illustrated by David Mitchell, men and women communicate in extremely different ways so, if you are in a heterosexual relationship, the odds seem stacked against you. Of course, there are exceptions to the rule but, if my husband went to the pub with a mate whose entire family had just been abducted by aliens, there‚Äôs a very real chance it might not come up. There have been many instances where something huge is happening in the life of one of his pals and I‚Äôm waiting patiently for the next instalment, but he comes home clueless. ‚ÄúDidn‚Äôt you ask?‚Äù I‚Äôll shriek, brandishing my rolling pin. And he will look bewildered, somehow unaware he was meant to.

Meanwhile, I know my friends inside out, and vice versa. From their deepest dreams, hopes and desires, to how they feel about themselves and everybody they have ever met via what they fancy for lunch. We check in, we keep up, we don‚Äôt have to be reminded to enquire about the plot twists in each other‚Äôs storyline, we are living and breathing them together. How can these opposite ways of relating, of transmitting and receiving, mesh successfully so both parties get what they need?

But perhaps bigger, and more important, than the question of whether it‚Äôs possible to be best friends with your partner is if it‚Äôs a good idea in the first place. Isn‚Äôt that a lot of pressure on one person, and also too great a shift from romance towards roommates? Love aside, I do like my husband, we are friendly, but I‚Äôm not sure he‚Äôs my best friend, nor that I want him to be. It feels co-dependent and insular. A bit Stepford, tradwife, like we might share a toothbrush or, worse, an email address.

Then I asked my husband who his best friend was, and his answer, and my reaction to it, surprised me. He thought for a second, and then gave a male name. He had been best man at our wedding, so the clues were there, but I was oddly hurt. ‚ÄúNot me, then?‚Äù I clarified, in case he had mixed me and this guy up or something.

‚ÄúWell, I‚Äôm not yours, am I?‚Äù he replied, immediately reeling off five people and one cat who would definitely be ahead of him in the queue. All fair enough. Except ‚Ä¶ it turns out that although my husband isn‚Äôt my best friend, and I am fine with that, I want to be his. Want and expect. Oh, and I‚Äôm increasingly outraged not to be, the longer I ponder it. Welcome to marriage.

title: My health is declining and I‚Äôm worried my husband might not take care of me
excerpt: I am 53 and my husband is 60. When our relationship started, he was the forgetful one; I tended to remember everything . I have always been mindful that I might need to look after him in his old age . But I am a caring person, and always thought I would manage.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
I am 53 and my husband is 60. When our relationship started, he was the forgetful one; I tended to remember everything . I have always been mindful that I might need to look after him in his old age . But I am a caring person, and always thought I would manage.

This is not how things have worked out. My husband is pretty healthy, while I am suffering the beginnings of¬†a noticeable cognitive decline ‚Äì forgetfulness , overwhelm and a¬†decrease in mobility ‚Äì which I¬†haven‚Äôt been to the doctor about yet .

My husband is not a very outwardly caring person, and I have no idea if he will care enough to look after me if I¬†become more immobile or start to forget things more. I want to feel loved, but I don‚Äôt. This is sad in itself, and really scary for the future.

I have had some health challenges in the last year and am doing my best to look after myself. My husband gives me a lot of advice about my weight and health , but he doesn‚Äôt walk or talk more slowly if I struggle to keep up .

Today we went to the cinema as a¬†family. I booked it , paid and drove , but¬†my husband and kids walked off to the cinema without me and I couldn‚Äôt catch up. I want to be together, but I‚Äôm left behind. This feels like a metaphor for our life.

What I really want my husband to say is, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt worry, I‚Äôll take care of you, and you take care of me.‚Äù But I¬†just don‚Äôt think he‚Äôs capable of it.

Your letter was one of the saddest I‚Äôve read. Not because it is without hope ‚Äì quite the opposite ‚Äì but because this gap between you and your family could be bridged with communication. But I know that takes courage.

Please go to the doctor. A proper checkup could put your mind at rest, or give you concrete answers to present to your family. So many women your age, who have had a lifetime of looking after others, are exhausted and overwhelmed ‚Äì not because they are failing, but because they are so capable. It‚Äôs time to start looking after you.

UKCP registered psychotherapist Meeri Rebane was ‚Äúmoved by your letter and your courage in asking for help. It seems that being the strong physically capable ‚Äòcarer‚Äô is a role you‚Äôve carried throughout your life. From the start of your relationship with your husband, you took on the responsibility of thinking about what and who needs taking care of in the family.‚Äù Rebane went on to say that there‚Äôs ‚Äúnothing wrong with that, people can get great fulfilment from caring for others, but who took care of you when you were growing up? It seems you were taught to be the ‚Äòcaring person who would always manage‚Äô, but also that to ‚Äònot manage‚Äô was not OK.‚Äù

We wondered if this was why you don‚Äôt feel you can ask for help now? I wondered about your life when you were a child. You may find the podcast I did on the Parentified Child useful.

skip past newsletter promotion

after newsletter promotion

When you‚Äôre the planner and the fixer, you and your needs can become invisible because you just get on with it. I don‚Äôt think your husband and children are uncaring ‚Äì after all, you‚Äôve shown them a lifetime of how to do it ‚Äì but it‚Äôs very likely they have no idea at all how you feel.

‚ÄúYour husband may not be capable of giving you the response you need at first,‚Äù says Rebane. ‚ÄúHis way of expressing care may be different to yours. It doesn‚Äôt mean he doesn‚Äôt want to take care of you. If you don‚Äôt tell him what you need, however, he can‚Äôt even try to support you.‚Äù

title: The moment I knew: stuck in Chile in the early days of Covid, he brought me out of my anxiety loop
excerpt: In May 2018, I was scrolling through prospective dates on Bumble when I saw Charlie‚Äôs profile. I could tell we had a lot of immediate connections. He had worked for human rights organisations, travelled a lot and even had interesting profile pictures. I swiped right.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
In May 2018, I was scrolling through prospective dates on Bumble when I saw Charlie‚Äôs profile. I could tell we had a lot of immediate connections. He had worked for human rights organisations, travelled a lot and even had interesting profile pictures. I swiped right.

Later that day, we met at a small bar close to my work in Melbourne for a drink. Even though it was a good first date, I decided I didn‚Äôt have the energy for more dates straight away and cancelled our second one. I think he thought I was a bit of a time waster.

A month later, I was visiting family in Perth and my mum asked if I was seeing anyone. I expressed frustration that it‚Äôs so hard to sort through all the garbage on dating apps ‚Äì but there was one guy I‚Äôd met who seemed lovely and had a beautiful smile. So when I got back to Melbourne we met again for dumplings, and it was on.

After just six months together we moved into his one-bedroom bachelor pad. That was a massive mistake. We did it way too fast and immediately started squabbling. It was just too soon for two very independent people who had spent a lot of time building up their own lives to be suddenly trying to mesh them together.

By March 2020, our bickering was at an all-time high. We decided to see a couples counsellor before going on a one-month trip to South America ‚Äì we didn‚Äôt want to ruin the trip for ourselves. I remember immediately disliking the counsellor, which I think was more about what she revealed about us. At the end of the first session she just looked at us and said she didn‚Äôt think she could help because we were too far apart as individuals for things to work out. We were like, that‚Äôs really bad!

Before we left Australia we‚Äôd heard murmurings about this new virus emerging but we were feeling smug that we were escaping. After five incredible days hiking across Patagonia, we found ourselves bunkering down in a small hotel room in Punta Arenas as the news of Covid spread across the world.

Flights were cancelled, borders were closing, we had desperate messages from friends and family. We were freaking out. It went from a complete state of relaxation and wonder at the world to OMFG the world is melting down.

Charlie was way more relaxed about it than me. He was like, we‚Äôll be OK. It just wasn‚Äôt in his realm of possibility that we wouldn‚Äôt get home. So while I was contacting embassies, trying to change flights and reaching out to friends and family to figure out our way home, Charlie was happily imagining our new life in Chile. ‚ÄúBabe, imagine how good we‚Äôll get at Spanish,‚Äù he said. A line I‚Äôll always remember.

In the hotel room in Punta Arenas I knew that if the world was ending, as it felt like it was, it was him I wanted to be next to. Charlie was making us go on walks, making up songs and cracking jokes the whole time. He was bringing me out of my anxiety loop. We balanced each other out perfectly in that crisis, on opposite ends of the scale.

Eventually, we got seats on one of the last flights back from Chile before the borders closed. We were waiting on standby at the airport, and we only got seats on the flight because two temporary residents were booted off when the rules changed and only permanent residents could get back into Australia. It really was the most bonkers time.

Charlie proposed in July 2020 and we eloped in December 2020.

I thought our time in Chile was going to be the worst thing we would go through ‚Äì but we have faced many difficulties together since then.

Through it all, I‚Äôm always so grateful to have him by my side. We never went back to that couples counsellor.

title: Eat Pray Love author Elizabeth Gilbert on leaving her marriage for a dying friend: ‚ÄòShe said, Let‚Äôs just live balls to the wall until I die!‚Äô
excerpt: Sometime in the summer of 2017 I wrote in my journal, ‚ÄúJesus fucking Christ, please save me.‚Äù I was trapped in hell, and I could see no way out. Our beautiful, sunny, two-bedroom penthouse apartment in the East Village ‚Äì which I had rented for Rayya to make her happy in the la‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Sometime in the summer of 2017 I wrote in my journal, ‚ÄúJesus fucking Christ, please save me.‚Äù I was trapped in hell, and I could see no way out. Our beautiful, sunny, two-bedroom penthouse apartment in the East Village ‚Äì which I had rented for Rayya to make her happy in the last months of her life ‚Äì had become a dungeon of misery, danger, degradation, drugs. Rayya kept the shades drawn at all hours of the day, not only because the light hurt her eyes but also because she had become intensely paranoid that she was being watched by the police, and that they were coming for her.

And, to be honest, the police might very well have come for her (for both of us, actually), because our apartment now contained thousands and thousands of dollars‚Äô worth of cocaine ‚Äì some of which Rayya was cooking down and shooting into whatever veins she could find upon her beaten-down, disease-ridden body, some of which she was freebasing, some of which she was snorting up her now constantly bloodied nose. But most of the coke, as of this moment, she had chopped up and laid out in thick rails on the coffee table, next to an overflowing ashtray, a bottle of whiskey, several bottles of morphine and trazodone and Xanax, a stack of fentanyl patches and a cluster of empty beer bottles. And these heaping lines of cocaine she counted, weighed and studied all day long.

‚ÄúWhat the fuck are you looking at?‚Äù she demanded, glancing up for a moment from her cherished cocaine heaps and peering at me through a blue haze of cigarette smoke ‚Äì staring me down with hostile eyes that had not, as far as I could remember, blinked in days.

Good question.

What was I looking at?

I was looking at somebody who was supposed to be dead by now ‚Äì who had been given six months to live over 15 months earlier ‚Äì but who simply refused to die. I was looking at somebody who had recently gotten kicked out of hospice (who gets kicked out of hospice, by the way?) for being aggressive and uncooperative to the kind, generous nurses and support staff who had been trying to help my beloved partner prepare her body and mind for a ‚Äúdeath with dignity‚Äù ‚Äì a death that, at this point, Rayya had utterly rejected in favour of plan B, which was to do enough drugs that she could feel immortal, that she could feel nothing.

I was looking at somebody who had once been the only person on Earth who could make me feel completely safe and loved, but who now verbally abused me all day long, telling me that I was ‚Äúa fucking shit show of a failure‚Äù when it came to taking care of her; that everything I was doing to try to help her was wrong; that I was a ‚Äúneedy little fucking crybaby‚Äù who had to ‚Äúgrow the fuck up‚Äù.

I first met Rayya Elias in the spring of 2000. I was 31 years old at the time, and married. I was on a certain path back then. Husband, nice house, good job, about to start a family. Except there was a problem with my hair, which was a frizzy mess. One day a friend told me I resembled a young Art Garfunkel, and said I needed to do something about it. She suggested I go see this person named Rayya, who was cutting hair out of a walk-up apartment on Avenue C.

I was dressed that day like a sales clerk at Banana Republic, which is how I always dressed back then. All khakis and cardigans. I remember my outfit clearly, because I looked and felt so different from Rayya, who was wearing black leather pants, a white tank top and motorcycle boots. I have fallen in love with many people at first sight, but I did not fall in love with Rayya Elias that day. In fact, I didn‚Äôt fall in love with her for another eight or nine years. But I did like her. She was funny and interesting and exotic.

title: See Ten Gorgeous Photographs of Lions and Discover What Makes the Majestic Felines Special
excerpt: Long considered symbols of royalty and strength, lions have fascinated humans for centuries. Although we are their biggest admirers, we are also one of their biggest threats , poaching them for their skins, encroaching on their territories, killing them to protect livestock an‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
A new book of essays and images reveals the history of the big cats and how they‚Äôve become a vulnerable species today, and uncovers little-known facts about them

Long considered symbols of royalty and strength, lions have fascinated humans for centuries. Although we are their biggest admirers, we are also one of their biggest threats, poaching them for their skins, encroaching on their territories, killing them to protect livestock and hunting them as trophies.

‚ÄúWe are now the predators,‚Äù says Don Pinnock, an investigative journalist, photographer and environmental writer. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre squeezing out wildlife; it doesn‚Äôt have a place anymore.‚Äù

To draw attention to the plight of modern lions, Pinnock teamed up with Colin Bell, a writer and co-founder of multiple safaris, to collect essays and photos from various lion experts. The result is The Last Lions, set to be published on September 16, from Smithsonian Books.

The Last Lions

The Last Lions is a powerful rallying cry voiced by scientists and conservationists to save the lions before it‚Äôs too late, with stunning wildlife photography.

Some of the essays explore strategies being implemented across Africa to save these animals. ‚ÄúAs we canvassed all the experts around Africa, the emerging theme was that there‚Äôs always a solution,‚Äù Bell says. The challenges in each locality are different, however, and strategies must be tailored to specific cultural, political and environmental needs.

For example, a lack of oversight and resources threw the Majete Wildlife Reserve in Malawi into disarray. It was established in the 1950s as a protected area for wild animals, such as lions, leopards and hyenas, but the reserve was poorly managed. The land and its animals were left vulnerable to loggers and poachers in the 1980s. But in 2003, a nonprofit conservation organization called African Parks established a public-private partnership to carefully manage the reserve, slowly reintroducing predators and prey to the site over many years. Majete notes that it has since reintroduced more than 3,000 animals from 17 species and currently has an estimated 80 to 100 lions.

African Parks looked beyond the reserve and established strong relationships with the surrounding community early on, Pinnock notes. When he visited Majete in 2023, he spoke with park manager John Adendorff and asked how the reserve had become so successful. ‚ÄúHe told me that you put up a fence and then look after what‚Äôs outside it,‚Äù says Pinnock. ‚ÄúIf the park is of no value to the people around the park, you‚Äôll lose it.‚Äù The organization provides schools, clinics and technology to the neighboring communities, and in return, the people are fiercely protective of Majete and its animals.

The essays in The Last Lions describe many facets of lion history, genetics and behavior. Here are five facts about the animals that give insight into their past, present and future.

  • According to the book The Last Lions, these big cats have experienced a geographic range retraction of around 85 percent since the year 1500.
  • Today, lions face habitat loss, poachers and many other threats.

Lions roamed Europe and Asia many years ago

Although lions are thought of as a distinctly African animal, they also used to roam southern Europe and a large part of Asia thousands of years ago. Now most live in parts of Africa, and a small population still calls India‚Äôs Gir National Park home.

‚ÄúLions didn‚Äôt fit well with the rising civilizations of Europe,‚Äù says Pinnock. ‚ÄúThey were increasingly pushed out and hunted out.‚Äù The book notes that while India was still a British colony the 1800s, British officers and Indian maharajas hunted lions, almost completely wiping out their populations. Today, it‚Äôs estimated that as many as 891 Asiatic lions reside in Gujarat, India.

Lion territory in Africa has dwindled over the years, limited now to small regions in a smattering of countries, and none remain in the northernmost region of the continent. When Pinnock and he were born, there were hundreds of thousands of free-running lions in Africa, says Bell. ‚ÄúToday, there are no more than 23,000 to 25,000 wild lions,‚Äù he says.

We don‚Äôt really know how many lions are left in the wild

title: Did the Dwarf Planet Ceres Once Host Life? Astronomers Suggest Chemical Energy Could Have Fueled Microbes Long Ago
excerpt: Ceres , the only dwarf planet in our inner solar system, is covered in ice and salt deposits. Its daytime temperatures range from a frigid minus 136 degrees to minus 28 degrees Fahrenheit.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Though no direct evidence of life has been found, models suggest Ceres had hot water shooting into its underground oceans billions of years ago, offering potentially hospitable conditions

Ceres, the only dwarf planet in our inner solar system, is covered in ice and salt deposits. Its daytime temperatures range from a frigid minus 136 degrees to minus 28 degrees Fahrenheit.

‚ÄúLooking at this barren, frozen, gray world, we might be [forgiven] for thinking it the last place likely to host life in our solar system,‚Äù Iain Todd writes for BBC Sky at Night Magazine. And¬†yet, researchers now suggest Ceres might have once been habitable.

In a study published in August in the journal Science Advances, astronomers reveal a new piece in the puzzle of Ceres‚Äô history: The dwarf planet might have one had long-lasting chemical energy that could have sustained microbial life. While there is no evidence that life‚Äînot even single-celled organisms‚Äîever existed on the dwarf planet, the new findings suggest that if any organisms were there, they might have had ‚Äúfood‚Äù available.

Thanks to data collected by NASA‚Äôs Dawn mission, which reached Ceres in 2015 and ended in 2018, researchers had already figured out that the dwarf planet had an underground reservoir of salty water as well as organic material in the form of carbon molecules. These are two key ingredients for hosting some microbial life, with chemical energy being the third.

In the recent study, the team created models to simulate the internal temperature and composition of Ceres over time. The models indicated that around 2.5 billion years ago, radioactive decay in the then-young world‚Äôs rocky interior could have caused hot water with dissolved gases to push up through the rocks and into the underground ocean.

This process is similar to how hydrothermal vents work on our own planet. These unique environments¬†are marine regions where hot water shoots out of cracks in the ocean floor along with life-sustaining minerals, supporting entire ecosystems. Organisms known as chemoautotrophs can process chemical energy emitted by these hydrothermal vents.

‚ÄúOn Earth, when hot water from deep underground mixes with the ocean, the result is often a buffet for microbes‚Äîa feast of chemical energy,‚Äù Sam Courville, lead author of the study and a planetary geophysicist at Arizona State University, explains in a NASA statement. ‚ÄúSo, it could have big implications if we could determine whether Ceres‚Äô ocean had an influx of hydrothermal fluid in the past.‚Äù

According to the new models, Ceres is most likely to have been habitable between about 2.5 billion and 4 billion years ago, when its core‚Äôs temperature would have peaked and hot fluids would have reached the underground ocean. Since then, however, the dwarf planet‚Äôs ocean ‚Äúhas likely become a cold, concentrated brine with fewer sources of energy, making it less likely to be habitable at present,‚Äù the researchers write in the study.

In effect, the warmth from radioactive decay has weakened, much of the water has likely frozen and the remaining liquid is probably very salty. What‚Äôs more, Ceres isn‚Äôt heated by the gravitational push and pull caused by orbiting a large planet‚Äîthe process that generates heat deep within Saturn‚Äôs moon Enceladus and Jupiter‚Äôs moon Europa, both possible candidates for hosting life.

The idea of potential past habitability might feel like a far cry from the long-awaited evidence that we‚Äôre not alone in the universe. However, Amanda Hendrix, director of the Planetary Science Institute who was not involved in the study, tells New Scientist‚Äôs Karmela Padavic-Callaghan that scientists need to investigate bodies like Ceres‚Äîworlds that have oceans now or had them in the past‚Äîif they hope to find clues to current or bygone life in our solar system.

Plus, the recent paper is relevant to the study of other water-rich, icy moons and dwarf planets that are about the size of Ceres. It suggests that even if these bodies don‚Äôt have internal heating right now, they might also have been hospitable long ago.

title: Christie's Helped Drive the Art World's NFT Craze. Now, the Auction House Is Shutting Down Its Digital Art Division
excerpt: Christie‚Äôs is shutting down its digital art division‚Äîa significant pivot for the auction house, which helped ignite the art world‚Äôs nonfungible token (NFT) craze four years ago.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Christie‚Äôs Helped Drive the Art World‚Äôs NFT Craze. Now, the Auction House Is Shutting Down Its Digital Art Division

Once a booming sector, the nonfungible token art market has been contracting for years

Christie‚Äôs is shutting down its digital art division‚Äîa significant pivot for the auction house, which helped ignite the art world‚Äôs nonfungible token (NFT) craze four years ago.

‚ÄúChristie‚Äôs has made a strategic decision to reformat digital art sales,‚Äù a spokesperson tells Now Media‚Äôs Matt Medved. ‚ÄúThe company will continue to sell digital art within the larger 20th- and 21st-century art category.‚Äù

Two digital art staffers were let go as part of the shake-up, which comes under the leadership of Christie‚Äôs new CEO, Bonnie Brennan, who was appointed in February. A digital art specialist will stay on staff at Christie‚Äôs, Now Media reports.

The news comes four years after Christie‚Äôs sold its first NFT, a digital certificate that lives on a blockchain, ‚Äúa digital record of transactions distributed across a decentralized network of computers,‚Äù in the words of Marina Isgro, a curator at the Smithsonian‚Äôs Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden, and proves ownership over a work of digital art. As Isgro explained during a 2021 online panel, an NFT is ‚Äúa unique piece of data registered on a blockchain that can serve as a surrogate or certificate of authenticity for various kinds of objects in the digital and real worlds.‚Äù

Fun fact: The most valuable living artists

  • The sale of¬†Everydays: The First 5,000 DaysinMarch 2021marked thethird-highestauction price then achieved by aliving artist, placing Beeple (the name used by artistMike Winkelmann) afterJeff KoonsandDavid Hockney.

In 2021, Christie‚Äôs facilitated the sale of the NFT associated with Everydays: The First 5,000 Days, a digital artwork by the artist known as Beeple. Going under the hammer for $69.3 million, Everydays is still the most expensive NFT ever sold.

The sale helped kick off an NFT fad in the art world that lasted roughly a year. Christie‚Äôs went on to invest in the space further, launching its own NFT auction platform.

But the digital art gold rush was short-lived. Between 2021 and 2022, Christie‚Äôs reported a 96 percent decline in NFT sales, as M.K. Manoylov reported for the Block in 2022. More recently, a 2024 report from NFTevening found that 96 percent of NFTs are effectively ‚Äúdead,‚Äù or not valuable.

The shuttering of Christie‚Äôs digital art division comes two years after Sotheby‚Äôs, another renowned auction house, laid off numerous employees in its NFT division, as ARTnews‚Äô Shanti Escalante-De Mattei and Angelica Villa reported in 2023.

Weighing in on X, the social media platform previously known as Twitter, digital art adviser Fanny Lakoubay says Christie‚Äôs decision is ‚Äúprobably tied to the current art market contraction.‚Äù

‚ÄúAuction houses can‚Äôt justify a whole department when it brings in less revenue than the others (even with some recent successful sales),‚Äù Lakoubay adds.

Earlier this year, the Art Basel and UBS Global Art Market Report found that sales in the international art market overall declined by 12 percent in 2024. ‚ÄúDecline in value was driven by cooling at the top end,‚Äù the report stated, describing 2024 as ‚Äúa year of continuing geopolitical tensions, economic volatility and trade fragmentation.‚Äù

The Christie‚Äôs news is ‚Äúdefinitely not a great public signal,‚Äù Lakoubay writes. ‚ÄúBut we should also remember: Auction houses only focus on secondary sales of already well-known artists and brands. It‚Äôs still too early for that model to really work/scale with digital art.‚Äù

Christie‚Äôs is not pulling away from digital tender entirely. Earlier this year, the auction house debuted a crypto real estate division, which allows buyers to purchase properties with digital currencies.
