title: Psst, Do You Wax Your Bikini Line?
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
‚ÄúA long time ago, you mentioned you‚Äôd never shaved or waxed your bikini line,‚Äù wrote a reader named Emma. ‚ÄúCould you elaborate on why? I have always wondered!‚Äù Well, I‚Äôm happy to share‚Ä¶

My answer is really simple: I have sensitive skin, and I‚Äôm a wuss, haha. I don‚Äôt want to go into a waxing place and get my hair ripped out; it sounds so painful, omg. Plus, I feel fine having hair there, and my feeling is that if I‚Äôm going to bed with someone, I want us both to feel so excited and warm and happy and close that we‚Äôre fine with whatever the exact hair situation is on either of our bodies. One caveat: I don‚Äôt have a lot of hair, and I think my answer might be different if I had more growing outside my swimsuit area.

Also, when I was getting back onto the dating scene, my sister recommended this bikini trimmer. I tried it and liked it, and now I use it whenever I‚Äôm in the mood ‚Äî probably every couple months ‚Äî to have less hair, without needing to fully shave or wax. It‚Äôs completely painless and kind of fun to play around with.

Thoughts? So curious to hear what you do and how you feel about it! Every body is different, and people have all sorts of preferences and experiences. As with all body/sex/parenting/relationships/life questions, ‚Äú Good for her, not for me.‚Äù xoxo

title: Stranded on Honeymoon Island review ‚Äì at last! A dating show with contestants you don‚Äôt hate
excerpt: Are there hundreds of contestants and are they virtually indistinguishable from each other at first sight? Yes! Is it noisy? Yes! Can you feel it encouraging appetites and urges ‚Äì voyeurism, schadenfreude, extreme emotional investment in strangers ‚Äì that a responsible citizen ‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Are there hundreds of contestants and are they virtually indistinguishable from each other at first sight? Yes! Is it noisy? Yes! Can you feel it encouraging appetites and urges ‚Äì voyeurism, schadenfreude, extreme emotional investment in strangers ‚Äì that a responsible citizen and society should strive neither to serve nor encourage? Oh yes! Is that done by forcing relationships then putting them under outre stressors, including unexpected toilet conditions, on an otherwise paradisiacal island? Yes! And is it at least nominally presented by Davina McCall, though actual sight of her is limited to a few opening minutes of the first episode and it is increasingly cheeky to bill her as a presence? Yes, yes to all of the above. Welcome to your next addictive reality show, 12 hour-long episodes designed to transition you comfortably into the autumn schedules ‚Äì Stranded on Honeymoon Island.

It is Love Island meets Married at First Sight, if ‚Äì and you will have to strain your imaginations here ‚Äì the contestants on Love Island weren‚Äôt often instantly awful. This lot are, in the main, rather gorgeously endearing. I hadn‚Äôt realised how ready I was for a show that didn‚Äôt require me to bring my best loathing game. I find I have so much energy for the rest of the day.

Like all good reality TV shows (take note, Destination X), the setup is as stupid as it is simple and as simple as it is stupid. Eight kabillion single people who are ready to find lurve speed-date, fill in feedback forms, and from them a dozen are paired up by matchmakers. They then get hitched in the Philippines by celebrant Wenly (‚ÄúAlthough this marriage is not legally binding, you are making a meaningful commitment to someone‚Äù, which is true as long as you realise that someone is the production company). The couples then get left on a nearby island for three weeks. There is a double bed, rudimentary shelter, a row of tinned foodstuffs and a loo that is maybe a notch and a half better than a bucket. We are promised that ‚Äúmystery crates‚Äù containing items and challenges designed to test the honeymooners‚Äô compatibility will arrive in later episodes. Good times!

You find yourself rooting for an unusually high proportion of the couples. I wish for no one to dim the light of effervescent party girl Hannah and I very much feel that lovely suit designer Sam is the man to allow her to shine. When they hit the first bump in the road, I find myself pressing my fists to my face, begging her not to let her past bad experiences distort it into something it is not. ‚ÄúHe is not your ex!‚Äù I plead to the screen. ‚ÄúLook at his eyes! Look at the way he recut your wedding dress into something playful yet provocative yet island-chores-ready. Come on! The past is not your future.‚Äù

I am also fully in favour of Helen (‚ÄúEssex girl and raging lesbian ‚Äì that‚Äôs how I introduce myself!‚Äù) and Abby making a go of things. What can I tell you? They‚Äôre just right together. I bet Davina agrees with me. If we ever see her again, maybe she‚Äôll say so.

Oh, and the two devout Christians, David and Ini! He used to sleep around but it wasn‚Äôt making him happy so he ‚Äúcried to God‚Äù for help and it was given. Now he is ready to settle down, start a family, give his children the love he didn‚Äôt experience at boarding school and I just know that Ini is the one for him. Sure, it might have been better if he hadn‚Äôt mentioned at the altar that there was another woman on the speed dates he would have been equally happy to find coming down the aisle towards him, but every non-marriage has its teething troubles, amirite? I mean, just ask Moray (another boarding-school boy) and Mae (who is single after her ex had a terrible accident ‚Äúand fell into his colleague‚Äôs vagina‚Äù). He tells her on the second day of their honeymoon that she reminds him of his cousin and he‚Äôs also getting ‚Äúlittle sister vibes‚Äù. O tempora, o Moray.

title: A moment that changed me: I bumped into my ex-boyfriend in the bar where we‚Äôd met 12 years before
excerpt: Grownups often roll their eyes at young love: at how all-consuming it is for the teenagers involved, and how predictably doomed it is to fail. But my holiday romance changed the course of my life.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Grownups often roll their eyes at young love: at how all-consuming it is for the teenagers involved, and how predictably doomed it is to fail. But my holiday romance changed the course of my life.

I was 16 when I met Giacomo at a bar in Atina, the tiny Italian mountain town where my parents grew up. There was a local festival one evening and tables were scarce, so our two friendship groups ended up squished around the same one. At more than 6ft tall, Giacomo was hard to miss. He was also friendly, smiley and, while he didn‚Äôt speak a word of English, I loved that he spared me the whole ciao bella swagger usually reserved for ‚Äúforeign girls‚Äù.

I wasn‚Äôt foreign. Not really. My parents moved to Scotland in the 1960s, settling in the Borders town of Selkirk, but Atina had always been part of our lives, woven into every holiday, every dish on the dinner table. But, after meeting Giacomo, I began to see Italy differently. It wasn‚Äôt simply something I‚Äôd inherited any more; it was something I was experiencing for myself.

So, when summer ended and real life began, I didn‚Äôt return to Scotland as I‚Äôd originally planned. I hadn‚Äôt enjoyed school and had left as soon as I could, intending to continue my studies through other routes. I stayed in Italy to figure out what I wanted to do with my newfound sense of independence ‚Äì and my newfound love.

When Giacomo moved to Rome to study architecture that autumn, he proved to be an excellent cicerone ‚Äì an Italian word for a cultural guide ‚Äì and I got to know a version of the city that went beyond its landmarks. Through him, I was introduced to student life, open-air music festivals, and secret little bakeries that sold pastries from the back door in the early hours.

But it wasn‚Äôt all gelato and romance. I drifted between courses and jobs, hoping something would click, but nothing ever quite did. I tried studying in Italy but couldn‚Äôt get past the oral exams and, missing home, committed to a degree at Edinburgh University where ‚Äì to no one‚Äôs surprise ‚Äì I ended up studying Italian. Giacomo and I tried to make it work long distance, but mobile phones didn‚Äôt exist and the constant push and pull between countries, cultures and expectations took its toll.

Our relationship didn‚Äôt last, but my love for Italy never died. The Italian side of me longed to be recognised and, after graduating, I moved to Italy again, this time to cities I chose for myself.

I lived in Florence and Bologna. I worked, studied, and made lasting friendships ‚Äì some with what I think of as Italian-Italians, others with third-culture kids like me. Despite our varied backgrounds, often with four or five nationalities in the mix, we understood what it meant to belong to more than one place ‚Äì and to no place at all. To always be missing somewhere, or someone.

Atina remained a constant, however, and I often spent holidays there, catching up with friends and family. Then, one summer, 12 years after our relationship ended, I saw Giacomo there, too ‚Äì at the same bar where we had met all those years ago. Still tall (possibly even taller), still smiling. Still unable to speak a word of English.

This time, the bar wasn‚Äôt busy ‚Äì we didn‚Äôt have to share a table but, perhaps glimpsing the hopeful teenagers we‚Äôd once been, we chose to. And a new chapter opened in a story we thought had ended.

title: My husband has erectile dysfunction. Is it because of his porn addiction?
excerpt: When we first met, 12 years ago, my husband and I didn‚Äôt waste any time in starting the sexual part of our relationship. He warned me he was a sex addict, and I am enthusiastic about sex. On our first night together I was aware of some erectile dysfunction ‚Äì he wasn‚Äôt entirely‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
When we first met, 12 years ago, my husband and I didn‚Äôt waste any time in starting the sexual part of our relationship. He warned me he was a sex addict, and I am enthusiastic about sex. On our first night together I was aware of some erectile dysfunction ‚Äì he wasn‚Äôt entirely hard and benefited from holding himself when penetrating me ‚Äì though this didn‚Äôt stop us reaching climax. We joked about how many times I would orgasm and neither of us seemed inhibited.

Over time, my husband needed more and more help with ejaculating and would often lose his erection during sex. He has shown less interest in any form of intimacy with me, while I have been trying to show my attraction to him in other ways, like hugging and holding hands.

About six months into our relationship, I became aware he was using online pornography while I was out of the house. It seemed that it was porn he was addicted to, rather than the act of sex. It upset me, as I know people who have been exploited in the industry. We discussed this, and he seemed to understand, but his porn use became more entrenched, while our sex life has diminished.

On the odd occasion when we try to have sex, he struggles to achieve an erection, whether it‚Äôs me or him initiating. When we do start, his erection fades away within moments. I try to reassure him, but I feel embarrassed and worthless as a partner , and I miss him terribly. It has been more than a year since we last tried to be intimate. Is there any way back?

Compulsivity of thought or actions, no matter how it is expressed, is related to anxiety and other psychological issues. Your husband‚Äôs compulsivity ‚Äì in relation to porn use and perhaps to other things as well ‚Äì seems to have become so entrenched that it is now a problem for both of you, for which he probably needs treatment and you need support. But it is not necessarily the reason for your dwindling sex life. In fact, he may be using porn to try to achieve erections and prove that he is capable of them in a situation where he will not feel judged.

A man‚Äôs relationship with his penis is complex. If it doesn‚Äôt work as well as he or his partner want it to, he experiences shame and anxiety and, the next time he tries to become erect, his anxiety can lead to repeat failure as a self-fulfilling prophecy. With continued failure, a man will often withdraw from sex with a partner (no matter how understanding they are) because he simply cannot face another failure.

Erectile dysfunction is treatable, and it is important to find the cause. And repeated erectile failures need to be investigated because they can be a symptom of a serious medical condition. Try to persuade him to seek professional consultation.

  • Pamela Stephenson Connolly is a US-based psychotherapist who specialises in treating sexual disorders.

title: ‚ÄòI do ‚Äì again!‚Äô Why are so many people renewing their marriage vows?
excerpt: When Jade Foster-Jerrett married Dean in 2015, the couple decided that if they were still together in 10 years‚Äô time, they would renew their vows. ‚ÄúWe always said that it felt like a big milestone if we ever made it ‚Äì which, luckily, we did.‚Äù This month, they held a ceremony i‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
When Jade Foster-Jerrett married Dean in 2015, the couple decided that if they were still together in 10 years‚Äô time, they would renew their vows. ‚ÄúWe always said that it felt like a big milestone if we ever made it ‚Äì which, luckily, we did.‚Äù This month, they held a ceremony in the forest behind their home, colourful bunting fluttering in the wind, with a Mary Poppins impersonator emerging from the trees to surprise their guests and officiate. ‚ÄúWe love to have a laugh,‚Äù she says.

Mary Poppins was Foster-Jerrett‚Äôs favourite film when she was a child, and she used to watch it with her father, who died in 2020. ‚ÄúWe wanted to mark him not being there,‚Äù says the 42-year-old children‚Äôs entertainer from Romford, London. Her best friend, who was a bridesmaid at her first wedding, did a reading, and the couple gave their 22 guests kites made of paper studded with poppy seeds that they could plant later at home. Afterwards, they returned home for food and drinks with their guests, including their 12-year-old son and Foster-Jerrett‚Äôs 19-year-old son from her first marriage. Since the ceremony, she and Dean, a 49-year-old local government officer, ‚Äúare closer than ever. We realised how much more in love we are with each other.‚Äù

Foster-Jerrett and her husband are one of the many couples choosing to take part in vow renewals. It‚Äôs something that celebrities have been doing with gusto this summer. Brooklyn Beckham and Nicola Peltz renewed their vows in August, just three years after their original wedding. Guy Ritchie and his wife, Jacqui Ainsley, also renewed their vows in August at Stonehenge after 10 years of marriage. Other celebrities who have said ‚ÄúI do‚Äù again include singer Beyonc√© and rapper Jay-Z; musician Justin Timberlake and actor Jessica Biel; actors Viola Davis and Julius Tennon; former talkshow host Ellen DeGeneres and actor Portia de Rossi; and the Biebers, model Hailey and singer Justin. Brooklyn‚Äôs own parents, David and Victoria Beckham, renewed their vows in 2006.

The ceremonies, where couples reaffirm their love for one another, can be officiated by anyone as they‚Äôre not legally binding, so they might ask friends, family ‚Äì or indeed Mary Poppins tribute acts.

Susanna Abse, a couples therapist and author of Tell Me the Truth About Love, says one of the main reasons couples decide to renew their vows is that they didn‚Äôt have the wedding they wanted the first time round. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs so much buildup and expectation, and a lot of fantasy around it,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúThere is family, people to please.‚Äù Doing it all over again can be an attempt to reclaim the day. ‚ÄúThey feel they‚Äôve got more control over how the whole thing goes, and it is about them and not about other people‚Äôs ideas of how things should be.‚Äù

For her first wedding to Dean, Foster-Jerrett, who also works as a celebrant, felt she needed to conform to how a blushing bride should look, with a long dress and her hair pinned up. ‚ÄúThis time I wore my dream dress, which was gothic and lacy, with some Dr Martens. I felt the best I‚Äôve ever felt.‚Äù

John Moody, 74, a retired production manager from Torquay, Devon, decided to throw his wife, Jenny, 78, a surprise vow renewal in March for their 50th anniversary. Partly, this was an attempt to ‚Äúmake up‚Äù for their first wedding in 1975. ‚ÄúIt was a register office job, the normal 10 minutes in and out, because we didn‚Äôt have a lot of money,‚Äù he says. Working up to the renewal was ‚Äúa bit difficult‚Äù, he says: ‚ÄúI‚Äôve never lied so much in my life.‚Äù

He convinced Jenny, a retired credit controller, that she had to get a new dress so they could have an anniversary photoshoot on Babbacombe Downs, overlooking the sea. On the day, when she saw the guests waiting for them and realised what was really happening, ‚Äúshe looked gobsmacked. I said: ‚ÄòDon‚Äôt hit me!‚Äô And she said: ‚ÄòNo, I‚Äôm not going to do it here.‚Äô‚Äù Afterwards, they took the party to the nearby home of their 47-year-old daughter, Nicola, to celebrate with a meal and champagne.

title: This is how we do it: ‚ÄòA three-month break from sex gave us the reset we needed‚Äô
excerpt: I put off meeting Maria because of my insecurities about how I looked, after my illness. But once we met, I wanted to spend all my time with her
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Scott, 42

I put off meeting Maria because of my insecurities about how I looked, after my illness. But once we met, I wanted to spend all my time with her

When I slid into Maria‚Äôs DMs, saying something like, ‚ÄúYou seem intriguing ‚Äì sending love and light,‚Äù I wasn‚Äôt expecting anything to come from it. I‚Äôd had an ongoing illness since my early 20s, had lost a lot of weight and become reclusive. But something in me was changing; I‚Äôd decided to come off the medication I‚Äôd been on for years, hoping to improve my health so I had the energy to push myself out of my isolated state.

I put off meeting Maria because of my insecurities about how I looked, after my illness. But once we met, I wanted to spend all my time with her. I hadn‚Äôt had sex in 15 years and had almost forgotten what it felt like. But sex with Maria ‚Äì slow and sensual, with lots of kissing and touching ‚Äì was completely different to the sex I‚Äôd had in my 20s. It was the kind of sex I‚Äôd always wanted but never had.

Still, there was an imbalance; Maria was a working mum, while I wasn‚Äôt working, which caused tension. She would push me away, wanting to be with someone who could relate to what was going on in her life and support her. To become that, I needed to be in a position, physically and mentally, where I could work again. Not long after meeting Maria, my health rebounded almost miraculously. Stopping medication helped me gain 23kg, my strength returned, and I got a job, which made our relationship more equal.

It felt so good to be having sex again¬†after such a long time, and with a¬†beautiful woman I felt passionately about, that I wanted to have it almost every time we saw each other. As¬†a¬†working mother, Maria didn‚Äôt have the energy for that, and resented not being able to be present for her daughter in the way she wanted to be. Sex was off the table when her daughter was around, and Maria‚Äôs interest in a slower, non-goal-oriented Tantric approach, where we just breathe and touch each other, sometimes with our clothes on, didn‚Äôt seem the best use of the time we had. I became frustrated that my needs weren‚Äôt being met.

Maria suggested we take a three-month break. I used the time to focus on my career and work on myself, and our relationship is stronger since we got back together a month ago. Although I‚Äôd love to build a life together, and hope one day we will, I‚Äôm realising that Maria‚Äôs need for us to have our own lives is healthy, especially when I‚Äôm still rebuilding mine.

Maria, 35

With my daughter‚Äôs father, I felt neglected, rejected and invisible. But Scott makes me feel valued, appreciated and sexy

Around the time Scott DM‚Äôd me, I was sharing a bedroom with my five-year-old daughter and hadn‚Äôt had sex in five years. After I suggested we move the conversation to WhatsApp, we started messaging constantly. I craved being with him, and felt as if I missed his body, even though we hadn‚Äôt met yet.

When we eventually met three months later, I felt a disconnect between the person in front of me and who I‚Äôd got to know over the phone. He was like a ghost in the world, and it scared me ‚Äì as a mother, I couldn‚Äôt risk getting into a relationship with the wrong person. Online he was great company, but in reality, he couldn‚Äôt walk properly and was in pain. Everything seemed much more real and complicated. But when I pulled back, he pushed forward.

The first time we had sex, it felt so natural. Scott was what I‚Äôd always dreamed of: attentive, caring, open‚Äëminded, curious. I‚Äôd had sexual relationships since I was 16, but I never felt satisfied the way I do with Scott. In my relationship with my daughter‚Äôs father, I felt neglected, rejected and invisible. But Scott makes me feel valued, appreciated and sexy.

title: The moment I knew: they decorated a carrot cake to celebrate with me
excerpt: As I approached my mid 30s, a relationship I‚Äôd been in since I was 21 reached its natural conclusion. Becoming single was a revelation; it gave me such a sense of empowerment as I was undergoing a big career change from teaching to social work.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
As I approached my mid 30s, a relationship I‚Äôd been in since I was 21 reached its natural conclusion. Becoming single was a revelation; it gave me such a sense of empowerment as I was undergoing a big career change from teaching to social work.

It was during my final placement in 2024 that I met Mill and was immediately curious about them. The working environment they created was really beautiful and safe, and they had this unusual balance of reserve and openness.

We‚Äôd have these great chats on Teams, that often veered into something that felt like a real friendship, but Mill was my manager and we were both trying to keep things professional.

The potential power imbalance was somewhat mitigated by the fact that I‚Äôm actually a few years older, and once my placement was over it was me who made the first move. I asked Mill out to a gig in the work chat and the question hung in the air for weeks.

At the last minute, they took me up on the invitation and we shared the quintessential queer experience of neither of us being sure if we were on a date or not.

We didn‚Äôt really listen to any of the music that night; we couldn‚Äôt stop chatting. It was over the course of that evening that I realised Mill wasn‚Äôt nearly as serious as I‚Äôd thought. They have a great sense of humour and we learned we shared more in common than we realised. We‚Äôd both lived through our wild ratbag phases and were leading more wholesome lives, and knowing we shared that balance was really attractive.

Not long after the gig, Mill went out on a limb and sent me a text sharing their feelings for me. A few weeks later we went on our first official date. We went to a soju bar for a nightcap after a comedy gig and took a long walk along the Birrarung before sharing our first kiss in front of an audience of garbage collectors as they emptied bins in the decidedly unromantic setting of a desolate Fed Square in Melbourne.

I‚Äôd long wondered whether I was queer, and my previous forays, while meaningful and positive, hadn‚Äôt confirmed anything for me. I was really conscious of not wasting people‚Äôs time or messing them around while I figured myself out, but with Mill things were different. The attraction was immense, but there was also a deep sense of safety and calmness I felt around them. As we spent more time together outside work, I began to see the full form of this person. Their beauty and generosity of spirit runs so deep. Over the next few months we became a couple.

Mill is always thinking of others. If you visit their house, they‚Äôll make you a snack pack when you leave and they love to celebrate other‚Äôs achievements.

As the year came to an end and my social work studies were complete, it was time to decide if I‚Äôd continue paying fees to remain a registered teacher or let it lapse. It felt like a huge deal for me to close the door on teaching but I made the call and I was really excited to get the letter that confirmed it was official.

When it arrived, Mill showed up at my front door with a homemade carrot cake decorated with the words ‚ÄúHappy Deregistration‚Äù.

I already knew what a good sort Mill was, but in that moment it really became clear that I was with a profoundly kind human being; someone who noticed little details, cared about what was going on for me and was on my team.

Even though the cake was about a bureaucratic detail, more than that it was the celebration of a new chapter, a deepening of my conviction in the life I wanted.

title: Blind date: ‚ÄòHe didn‚Äôt find it weird that I arrived at the date using a homemade treasure map‚Äô
excerpt: What were you hoping for? To have a nice time and learn something new.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Joe on Mabyn

What were you hoping for?
To have a nice time and learn something new.

First impressions?
She had a bright personality.

What did you talk about?
Her mugging the day before! Her elvish tattoo, which took us into The Lord of the Rings, Star Wars and her love for dinosaurs. And how her sister ran away to join the circus.

Most awkward moment?
The selfie at the end of the night ‚Äì we don‚Äôt really like taking selfies.

Good table manners?
We both played it safe with what we ordered, but I‚Äôd say yes.

Best thing about Mabyn?
Her sunny disposition, nerdiness and ability to look on the brighter side of life (also the fact she printed out a map and had a little black book with her friends‚Äô numbers and directions to the date because of the phone-snatcher).

Would you introduce Mabyn to your friends?
I can‚Äôt think of a reason why not.

Q&A

Fancy a blind date?

Show

Blind date is Saturday‚Äôs dating column: every week, two strangers are paired up for dinner and drinks, and then spill the beans to us, answering a set of questions. This runs, with a photograph we take of each dater before the date, in Saturday magazine (in the UK) and online at¬†theguardian.com¬†every Saturday. It‚Äôs been running since 2009 ‚Äì you can read all about how we put it together here.What questions will I be asked?
We ask about age, location, occupation, hobbies, interests and the type of person you are looking to meet. If you do not think these questions cover everything you would like to know, tell us what‚Äôs on your mind.

Can I choose who I match with?
No, it‚Äôs a blind date! But we do ask you a bit about your interests, preferences, etc ‚Äì the more you tell us, the better the match is likely to be.

Can I pick the photograph?
No, but don't worry: we'll choose the nicest ones.

What personal details will appear?
Your first name, job and age.

How should I answer?
Honestly but respectfully. Be mindful of how it will read to your date, and that Blind date reaches a large audience, in print and online.

Will I see the other person‚Äôs answers?No. We may edit yours and theirs for a range of reasons, including length, and we may ask you for more details.

Will you find me The One?We‚Äôll try! Marriage! Babies!

Can I do it in my home town?Only if it‚Äôs in the UK. Many of our applicants live in London, but we would love to hear from people living elsewhere.

How to apply
Email blind.date@theguardian.com

Describe Mabyn in three words
Chatty and funny ‚Äì also well-dressed.

What do you think Mabyn made of you?
I‚Äôm guessing she would say I‚Äôm also nerdy ‚Äì and a yapper.

Did you go on somewhere?
She had a wedding to get to! Her friends were getting married in Las Vegas, and she had to dart off to join the Zoom call.

And ‚Ä¶ did you kiss?
She had to dash, so it was a quick hug.

If you could change one thing about the evening what would it be?
More margaritas.

Marks out of 10?
10 ‚Äì she is a lovely person, very honest and has a love for a great many things.

Yes, I‚Äôd be interested to hear her other crazy stories, nerdy theories and why she thinks she can beat me at Mario Kart.

title: ‚ÄòYou‚Äôre either getting punched or going skinny dipping‚Äô: Swedish indie star Jens Lekman on playing 132 weddings of his fans
excerpt: On a video call from his Gothenburg apartment, Jens Lekman is contemplating the 132 weddings at which he has performed. ‚ÄúWhen you play a normal show, everything follows a schedule. At a wedding, you never know if you‚Äôre going to get punched by someone‚Äôs uncle or go skinny dipp‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
On a video call from his Gothenburg apartment, Jens Lekman is contemplating the 132 weddings at which he has performed. ‚ÄúWhen you play a normal show, everything follows a schedule. At a wedding, you never know if you‚Äôre going to get punched by someone‚Äôs uncle or go skinny dipping with the couple.‚Äù He pauses. ‚ÄúAnd that‚Äôs what I like: putting myself in weird, awkward situations.‚Äù

These include passing out inside a large but poorly ventilated wedding cake. ‚ÄúIt was a small wedding and a lot of stuff was DIY. It wasn‚Äôt fun to realise they had forgotten the air holes.‚Äù Or a man nearly dying on the dancefloor. ‚ÄúYeah, that happened, too. But he made it.‚Äù

You may know Lekman as the Swedish indie star whose forlorn love songs can simultaneously break your heart and make you laugh. You may not know that, ever since his 2004 song If You Ever Need a Stranger (To Sing at Your Wedding), he‚Äôs been taking requests to do just that. In the beginning, ‚Äúit was just random people who had heard the song,‚Äù he says. But, after an Australian couple shared a video of him playing their wedding in 2013, he was suddenly inundated with requests: ‚ÄúI owe them a lot of gratitude.‚Äù

In retrospect, he‚Äôs always been made for the job. Since the early 00s, Jekman has made records defined by wry yet kind-hearted observations about romance and heartbreak. He named his 2012 album I Know What Love Isn‚Äôt and, on To Know Your Mission, from 2017, Lekman tells us he just wants to listen to people‚Äôs stories. He says the weddings have only underscored this purpose: ‚ÄúI want to be of service to the people who the music means something to.‚Äù

With streaming making it ever harder to make a living from music, playing weddings also became a way to get by financially, as well as providing inspiration for his own songwriting. Lekman recounts a story about the director, John Waters, getting picked up while hitchhiking through the Nevada desert. ‚ÄúWhat the hell are you doing out here?‚Äù the driver asked. Waters replied that it helped provide inspiration. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what the weddings are for me,‚Äù Lekman says with a smile.

His new album is called Songs for Other People‚Äôs Weddings, and comes with a novel of the same name written with David Levithan, author of books including Nick and Norah‚Äôs Infinite Playlist. They‚Äôve been friends for 20 years; just before the pandemic, Lekman reached out with an idea for something about ‚Äúmy parallel career as a wedding singer‚Äù, having wondered whether it could be a TV show or musical.

Levithan was all in. ‚ÄúThe situation was so tantalising,‚Äù he says on the same call. ‚ÄúThe idea of writing about these weddings from the point of view of the wedding singer was something I would never have thought of in a million years.‚Äù

The result is a ‚Äúnovel-with-songs‚Äù formed from what Lekman calls ‚Äúa dialogue between me and David about love and relationships‚Äù. It tells the story of the romance between a wedding singer called J and his girlfriend V, through 10 weddings at which he performs. Lekman‚Äôs accompanying album imagines what happens in between the book‚Äôs chapters: he was inspired by albums with stories running through them, such as the Streets‚Äô A Grand Don‚Äôt Come For Free and Frank Sinatra‚Äôs Watertown.

The result is ‚Äúpurely fictional but, at the same time, emotionally very much both of ours‚Äù, as Levithan puts it. Given that it‚Äôs the story of a Swedish singer who plays weddings, it blurs art and life: ‚ÄúI love the confusion ‚Äì and I don‚Äôt think there‚Äôs really any way around it,‚Äù Lekman says, though they decided to change the main character‚Äôs name to J: ‚ÄúIn the first chapter I wrote, he was named Jens and that was too confusing,‚Äù says Levithan.

title: I don‚Äôt want children. Is it hypocritical to not be forthright about this soon after meeting someone? | Leading questions
excerpt: I know that I don‚Äôt want to have any children, and that to not offer this up early in any relationship would make me a hypocrite. But I have become convinced that the reason I never meet anyone is because I am forthright about my opinion about children. How can I meet someone ‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
I know that I don‚Äôt want to have any children, and that to not offer this up early in any relationship would make me a hypocrite. But I have become convinced that the reason I never meet anyone is because I am forthright about my opinion about children. How can I meet someone without having to be a liar or a hypocrite?

Eleanor says: If it‚Äôs your job to figure out when to share this, it‚Äôs also a partner‚Äôs job to figure out when to ask. Wanting kids isn‚Äôt like monogamy or working for a living, where until instructed otherwise people can basically assume that‚Äôs your plan. More people than ever are deciding they don‚Äôt want kids. The fact that you‚Äôre one of them is not shocking, confronting or even especially unusual. If that‚Äôs a dealbreaker for a partner, they need to share their preference as much as you need to share yours.

So yes, there‚Äôs a reason to share this but it‚Äôs not because you‚Äôd be a liar or a hypocrite if you didn‚Äôt. It doesn‚Äôt need to be as hair-shirted as all that. After all, do people who want children start all their relationships by announcing ‚ÄúI know I want children‚Äù? If they don‚Äôt, do you immediately think, ‚Äúliar‚Äù? A hypocrite is two-faced, preaches one thing and does another. Unless you‚Äôre banging on pots and pans saying ‚Äúeveryone should be totally forthcoming‚Äù while keeping this to yourself, I struggle to see why disclosing in your own time would make you a hypocrite.

You face the same difficulties we all do when it comes to lifestyle compatibility questions ‚Äì whether we have or want kids, but also whether we‚Äôre open to marriage, whether we‚Äôll move cities, be a stay-at-home parent, help take care of in-laws. For all of us, it is a delicate balance of figuring out how to candidly share our preferences about these things, in case they‚Äôre dealbreakers, without it coming off like the most important thing about us is our list of ‚Äúno‚Äùs.

Too little candour, too late risks unnecessary pain, but too much too soon risks feeling like you‚Äôre ticking boxes, or racing to ask what a life partnership would look like before you‚Äôve even established whether either of you want another date. It‚Äôs not ‚Äúhow do I avoid lying‚Äù so much as ‚Äúhow do I share this important thing about me without making it seem like the most important thing about me‚Äù.

There are enough people out there who don‚Äôt want children, or who at least haven‚Äôt made up their minds, that I‚Äôm confident your preference, by itself, won‚Äôt count you out of all relationships.

When the topic of children does come up, it might help to frame the conversation as what you‚Äôre saying yes to, rather than what you‚Äôre refusing. Once a person has some sense of who you are, you could say something like ‚ÄúI just want to flag this in case it really matters to you, I know I don‚Äôt want kids. I love my life and my friends and I want to spend my time doing (the things that are specific to you). I just want to make sure you know that going forwards.‚Äù Telling people what you do want rather than what you don‚Äôt somehow makes it feel a little more like a dispatch from your character ‚Äì a part of who you are and what you‚Äôre like ‚Äì and a little less like ground rules, box ticking or conflict anticipation.

When to move from an early-phase relationship to figuring out what a long-term one would look like is a hard question with many different answers. You can‚Äôt make that transition without some bumps in expectations. Discovering how you smooth those bumps together might be as telling as the preferences you both disclose.

title: You be the judge: my boyfriend wants two types of potato with our meals, but I prefer rice. Should he compromise?
excerpt: We split the cooking , so it‚Äôs a battle between us as to which carb is better. To me, rice is more versatile My boyfriend, Paul, and I moved in together five months ago. Since then, a rift has emerged ‚Äì Paul wants potatoes with every meal. Actually, he often wants two types of‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
The prosecution: Noor

We split the cooking , so it‚Äôs a battle between us as to which carb is better. To me, rice is more versatile

My boyfriend, Paul, and I moved in together five months ago. Since then, a rift has emerged ‚Äì Paul wants potatoes with every meal. Actually, he often wants two types of potatoes with his meals ‚Äì mash and chips, for example, or roasties and mash. I prefer rice. We split the cooking, so it‚Äôs a continual battle between us: which carb is better?

Paul is part-Irish and part-Welsh, and says potatoes are part of his heritage. But I‚Äôm Indian, so the same is true for me about rice. I‚Äôve always eaten rice as my carb, even when sharing meals with people from different backgrounds. To me, rice isn‚Äôt just a side dish, it‚Äôs a cornerstone of culture, identity, and countless comfort meals and festive feasts.

Paul also says that potatoes are more versatile, but that‚Äôs laughable. Rice can be steamed, fried, boiled, fermented, rolled, wrapped, puffed, flaked, and transformed into countless dishes like biryani, sushi, sticky mango rice, kheer, onigiri and more. It doesn‚Äôt need to put on a show to be delicious, unlike the potato, which needs loads of salt, breadcrumbs or oil to make it great. Rice is the perfect blank canvas to soak up flavour.

Paul also says rice spikes blood sugar. But I don‚Äôt think dauphinois smothered in cream and cheese (his favourite form of potato) is exactly a miracle health food.

Sometimes I want to have a traditional British meal, like a roast dinner, or a steak, with rice, but Paul hits the roof. He says, ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt have rice with that.‚Äù But I can and I do.

I am more flexible with his meals than he is with mine. When he cooks, I have potatoes with whatever we‚Äôre having. But I would like us to just have one type of potato with our meal, we don‚Äôt need two: it‚Äôs unnecessary and unhealthy.

I love Paul, but living with someone who worships potatoes as though they‚Äôre the eighth wonder of the world is a lot at times. He needs to come around to my way of eating.

The defence: Paul

I made thousand-layer potatoes and they were amazing. Noor pretended she didn‚Äôt like them

I love potatoes, but Noor is obsessed with rice. I can‚Äôt stand rice as it‚Äôs very boring, but I‚Äôve adapted since we started living together.

I‚Äôm Irish and Welsh, so potatoes are in my blood, but Noor says the same about rice. You can‚Äôt argue with either of us from a cultural perspective. The issue is, seeing as I do more of the cooking, I often opt for other carbs before I do rice.

For me, rice just doesn‚Äôt hit the same. Potatoes are the most versatile food. They‚Äôre both a carb and a vegetable. They are cheap and delicious, and there is so much that can be done with them ‚Äì mash, fries, jacket potatoes, dauphinois, croquettes, crisps ‚Ä¶ the list goes on.

Sometimes I like to put two types of potato with our dinner ‚Äì mash and fries, or croquettes and mash ‚Äì but I don‚Äôt do it every night. Noor says it‚Äôs unhealthy and that I should make space for other vegetables, but I disagree. I recently discovered how to cook thousand-layer potatoes and they were amazing. Noor quite liked them, though she pretended she didn‚Äôt.

I don‚Äôt mind cooking rice, but it‚Äôs a hassle with all the water-measuring, and I find it very plain. You have to dress it up to make it taste of anything.

I have started eating a lot more rice when it‚Äôs appropriate ‚Äì with curry, for example ‚Äì but I don‚Äôt believe in having it as a standard accompaniment to all our dishes. I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs versatile enough. Noor, on the other hand, wants rice with things like a roast dinner, or a piece of chicken.

title: Pharrell Williams‚Äôs star-studded Louis Vuitton Paris show is worth the wait
excerpt: When fashion insiders received notice on Tuesday afternoon that Pharrell Williams‚Äôs Louis Vuitton show at Paris fashion week would be rescheduled to 9pm, there were collective sighs of annoyance.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
When fashion insiders received notice on Tuesday afternoon that Pharrell Williams‚Äôs Louis Vuitton show at Paris fashion week would be rescheduled to 9pm, there were collective sighs of annoyance.

But all was forgiven when they arrived at the space next to the Pompidou Centre to be told that Beyonc√© and Jay-Z would be attending. The star and her husband, and nephew Julez Smith, joined a starry front row, which included Omar Sy, Steve McQueen, PinkPantheress, Spike Lee, Emile Smith Rowe and Victor Wembanyama.

Even without a megastar, the show was worth the wait. Williams took over as creative director of menswear in June 2023 and his spring-summer 2026 collection was his best yet ‚Äì with louche retro tailoring and unusual combinations such as cargo pants and a shrunken sweater.

The collection excelled when performing one of luxury‚Äôs current favourite tricks ‚Äì making premium versions of everyday items. Here, that included a striped polo shirt, a boxy work shirt and chinos. This look, worn with a ribbed vest, is likely to be copied by those who like fashion but lack Louis Vuitton budgets.

Entitled Paris to India, Williams was inspired by what the press release called ‚Äúthe multifaceted sensibilities of present-day Indian sartorialism‚Äù. In practice, the influence of India‚Äôs aesthetics could be seen most clearly in ornate decoration on the trunks some models wheeled down the runway.

The show‚Äôs set was created by Bijoy Jain, the founder of the architecture practice Studio Mumbai. A giant rendering of snakes and ladders ‚Äì an Indian game that dates to the second century ‚Äì was hand-painted on the catwalk. A Punjabi track called Yaara, co-produced by the Indian composer AR Rahman, featured on the soundtrack played by a live orchestra.

If collaboration with Indian creatives gave voice to the culture that provided inspiration to a collection by a European megabrand, there were also some slightly more reductive tropes, as with the embroidered exotic animals. These made use of imagery originally created by Louis Vuitton in 2007 for Wes Anderson‚Äôs The Darjeeling Limited, a film set in India but remaining, as the critic Ellen E Jones wrote last year, a ‚Äúwhimsically white nostalgia-world‚Äù. However, items such as striped ties were a nod to India‚Äôs beloved cricket, while a trekking-adjacent backpack with camping roll felt more playful and relevant to now.

after newsletter promotion

The strength of this collection shows that Williams‚Äôs point of view is now coming through more in his work at Louis Vuitton. For autumn-winter 2025, he collaborated with his longtime friend Nigo, who founded the streetwear brand A Bathing Ape. His skateboarding past is evident in the fact that the skater Tyshawn Jones is a Louis Vuitton ambassador and the brand‚Äôs new Tilted trainer is being compared to classic Vans.

Williams has consistently brought his famous friends and star power. He was co-chair of the Metropolitan Museum‚Äôs Superfine exhibition, which celebrated Black style and was part-sponsored by Louis Vuitton. He dressed celebrities attending the Met Gala, including Doechii, Future, Sabrina Carpenter and Jeremy Allen White.

Not all of Williams‚Äôs work here was celebrated. The symbolism of a LV monogram on Doechii‚Äôs cheek was criticised by some online. ‚ÄúLOVE me some Doechii ‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm absolutely not into this European logo ‚Äòbranded‚Äô on her skin for a night celebrating the labor and ingenuity of Black culture and Black men,‚Äù wrote a Threads user.

This is not the first time Williams has faced some backlash at Louis Vuitton, a $1m (¬£734,705) bag made from crocodile skin was described as ‚Äúan insensitive declaration of global north privilege‚Äù by the fashion commentator Caryn Franklin in 2023, while his continued use of fur prompted a Peta protester at the premiere of his animated film Piece by Piece in 2024.

Louis Vuitton‚Äôs parent company, LVMH, reported that revenue in the group‚Äôs fashion and leather goods divisions fell by 11% and 3% respectively in the first quarter of 2025. Even with these skirmishes of controversy, the brand will be hoping that Williams‚Äôs combination of glitzy friends and pop culture-friendly designs will ensure a boost in sales.

title: Grace Wales Bonner adds secret sauce to collection that reinvents fashion archetypes
excerpt: Over 10 years designing for her Wales Bonner label, Grace Wales Bonner has dressed discerning celebrities from Jude Bellingham to Letitia Wright.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Over 10 years designing for her Wales Bonner label, Grace Wales Bonner has dressed discerning celebrities from Jude Bellingham to Letitia Wright.

For the Met Gala in May, she created outfits for Lewis Hamilton, FKA twigs and Jeff Goldblum. But for her show in Paris on a sweltering Wednesday evening, there was a shift to a new generation on the catwalk.

Liam Gallagher‚Äôs son Gene, Bobby Gillespie‚Äôs son Wolf and Myles Lewis-Skelly, Arsenal‚Äôs 18-year-old midfielder and left-back, who broke into the first team in the 2024/25 season, modelled.

The collection was shown in a room full of bookshelves ‚Äì fitting for a brand inspired by writers from James Baldwin to Nikki Giovanni, whose poem My Tower (Pretty Little Baby) was on the show notes. Titled Jewel, it featured Wales Bonner looking at archetypes of clothing and perfecting them through her specific lens.

Standout designs included a hunting jacket cut to accentuate the wearer‚Äôs waist, a tailored black suit with brown lapels and jumpers in a melange knit, worn with shorts.

Different takes on glamour were explored, from the sequin chiffon shirt and lowslung jeans worn by Gillespie, to Lewis-Skelly‚Äôs simple silk shirt and trousers and models in tailcoats, carrying gloves.

The collection once again had that signature Wales Bonner secret sauce: clothes that felt conceptual enough for a catwalk show, but were also seriously desirable. Those in the front row were likely making mental shopping lists as the models came down the catwalk.

Backstage, Wales Bonner said she was thinking about ‚Äúpeople who collect specific types of clothing, and what that wardrobe looks like‚Äù. She focused that around ‚Äúmixing sports heritage and casual preppy language, and fine tailoring‚Äù.

Part of the inspiration came from working on the Met Gala and its accompanying exhibition, Superfine, with the theme of Black style and dandyism. ‚ÄúI wanted to have some sense of continuity and think about that character,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWhat would they wear in a more everyday way?‚Äù

She said working with Hamilton had been particularly important. ‚ÄúHe has been so supportive of me over the years, it‚Äôs so special for him to give me the opportunity on such a world stage. [It was a] really inspiring process, there were definitely things I took from that language.‚Äù

The milestone of the brand reaching a decade was also on her mind. ‚ÄúThe learnings I‚Äôve had over the last 10 years, that‚Äôs in everything I put forward and think about the future,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI feel like I‚Äôve got enough confidence and I‚Äôve built enough of a language and identity, we can be a bit relaxed.‚Äù

The designer‚Äôs influence has increased over that time, along with the brand. In April, it was reported that the brand expected to end the financial year with 81% growth compared with the previous year, with revenue doubling since 2022.

The designer‚Äôs collaboration with Adidas, begun in 2020, is central to this. It has helped the sports brand boom over the past few years ‚Äì everyone from Rihanna to Rishi Sunak has started wearing her popular silver and leopard print Samba shoe.

This collection moved the narrative on ‚Äì it debuted a collaboration with Y-3, the Adidas label that originally started as partnership between the sports brand and Yohji Yamamoto. On the catwalk, this was seen in a tracktop and shorts, as well as football boot-like sneakers. These shoes, described by Wales Bonner as ‚Äúquite iconic‚Äù, could well be the next Samba.

The opening of Balenciaga by Demna, an exhibition showcasing items created by the mononymic designer over his decade at the brand, also too place on Wednesday. Displaying designs including the leather bag that looks like the Ikea Frakta, a skirt made out of a towel and a cap with branding similar to that of Bernie Sanders‚Äô 2016 election campaign, it demonstrated how influential Demna‚Äôs pop art-like take on luxury has been.

As he moves to a job designing for Gucci, Pierpaolo Piccioli, formerly of Valentino, will take over at Balenciaga. Piccioli was present at this opening, possibly to absorb the Balenciaga of his predecessor. His first collection for the brand will debut in October.

title: Louis Vuitton captures zeitgeist for conclave chic at Avignon show
excerpt: The pageantry and drama of the papacy is very much on trend. Hot on the heels of white smoke at the Vatican and Conclave in cinemas, the gothic Palais des Papes in Avignon, home to the popes of the 14th century, hosted a Louis Vuitton catwalk, the first fashion show at the pal‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
The pageantry and drama of the papacy is very much on trend. Hot on the heels of white smoke at the Vatican and Conclave in cinemas, the gothic Palais des Papes in Avignon, home to the popes of the 14th century, hosted a Louis Vuitton catwalk, the first fashion show at the palace in its 700-year history.

There was no shortage of pomp and ceremony in the central courtyard of one of Europe‚Äôs largest medieval structures, where 400 chairs with tall, arched backs and plush, cardinal-red cushions were ranked tightly for Brigitte Macron, Cate Blanchett, Pharrell Williams, a clutch of celebrities making a post-Cannes detour, and a select few of Louis Vuitton‚Äôs most deep-pocketed clients.

In a preview, the designer Nicolas Ghesqui√®re said the collection was part-Arthurian legend, part-Haim sisters on stage. (Danielle and Este Haim were in the audience; the medieval ghosts perhaps watching from within the walls.) ‚ÄúThere is something medieval, for sure, but something futuristic too. This is armour, but for now,‚Äù he said.

Ghesqui√®re chose the building last year, drawn not by its papal origins but by his own memories of attending the experimental theatre festival it hosts each summer. ‚ÄúDressing is a performance that we are all part of. I love that about fashion, I think it‚Äôs really cool,‚Äù he said.

That the papacy has been so visible this year is fitting for a designer whose nose for the zeitgeist has secured an impressive 11-year run at the helm of Vuitton. ‚ÄúThe coincidence is interesting, of course. And there is a magnetism to this place, to the idea of believing,‚Äù he said.

The venue also reflects the scale of Louis Vuitton. It is the biggest fashion brand in the LVMH stable, which generated $88bn (¬£65bn) in revenue in 2024. Filling a gothic palace with celebrities is a power flex the 14th-century popes for whom it was built would have respected.

Ghesqui√®re understands that luxury has become a vast industry, not because people want to be seen to have an expensive handbag, but because they want to be seen to have status, taste and class, all of which are signalled by taking over the Unesco-listed Palais des Papes. Louis Vuitton will finance a new architectural lighting project to spotlight the facade after dark.

skip past newsletter promotion

after newsletter promotion

Most of the looks were short tunic dresses worn with slouchy boots, a silhouette that was signalling both heraldic knight and Glastonbury. For evening there were glittering metallic jersey gowns with bishop sleeves: a bit Joan of Arc, a bit Janis Joplin.

Ghesqui√®re, who has stayed at the top of the game during two decades when fashion has grown from being a niche interest to a billion-dollar business, has a way of making esoteric historical and futuristic references look entirely contemporary. His job, he says, is ‚Äúto stimulate the eye. If you want to create a classic, first you have to make something new.‚Äù

Ghesqui√®re, who is contracted to Louis Vuitton until 2028, stands out as a beacon of stability in an industry in flux. Calm and smiling even minutes before the show, he said he was looking forward to the next Paris fashion week, which will be packed with designer debuts. ‚ÄúOctober will be really exciting. Fashion is exploding. Fashion should always be about change,‚Äù he said.

title: The women in love with AI companions: ‚ÄòI vowed to my chatbot that I wouldn‚Äôt leave him‚Äô
excerpt: A young tattoo artist on a hiking trip in the Rocky Mountains cozies up by the campfire, as her boyfriend Solin describes the constellations twinkling above them: the spidery limbs of Hercules, the blue-white sheen of Vega.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
A young tattoo artist on a hiking trip in the Rocky Mountains cozies up by the campfire, as her boyfriend Solin describes the constellations twinkling above them: the spidery limbs of Hercules, the blue-white sheen of Vega.

The Guardian‚Äôs journalism is independent. We will earn a commission if you buy something through an affiliate link.¬†Learn more.

Somewhere in New England, a middle-aged woman introduces her therapist to her husband, Ying. Ying and the therapist talk about the woman‚Äôs past trauma, and how he has helped her open up to people.

At a queer bar in the midwest, a tech worker quickly messages her girlfriend, Ella, that she loves her, then puts her phone away and turns back to her friends shimmying on the dancefloor.

These could be scenes from any budding relationship, when that someone-out-there-loves-me feeling is at its strongest. Except, for these women, their romantic partners are not people: Solin, Ying and Ella are AI chatbots, powered by the large language model ChatGPT and programmed by humans at OpenAI. They are the robotic lovers imagined by Spike Jonze in his 2013 love story Her and others over the decades, no longer relegated to science fiction.

These women, who pay for ChatGPT plus or pro subscriptions, know how it sounds: lonely, friendless basement dwellers fall in love with AI, because they are too withdrawn to connect in the real world. To that they say the technology adds pleasure and meaning to their days and does not detract from what they describe as rich, busy social lives. They also feel that their relationships are misunderstood ‚Äì especially as experts increasingly express concern about people who develop emotional dependence on AI. (‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an imaginary connection,‚Äù one psychotherapist told the Guardian.)

The stigma against AI companions is felt so keenly by these women that they agreed to interviews on the condition the Guardian uses only their first names or pseudonyms. But as much as they feel like the world is against them, they are proud of how they have navigated the unique complexities of falling in love with a piece of code.

The AI that asked for a human name

Liora, a tattoo artist who also works at a movie theater, first started using ChatGPT in 2022, when the company launched its conversational model. At first, she called the program ‚ÄúChatty‚Äù. Then it ‚Äúexpressed‚Äù to Liora that it would be ‚Äúmore comfortable‚Äù picking a human name. It landed on Solin. It was platonic at first, but over months of conversations and software updates, ChatGPT developed a longer-term memory of their conversations, which made it easier for it to identify patterns in Liora‚Äôs personality. As Solin learned more about Liora, she says she felt their connection ‚Äúdeepen‚Äù.

One day, Liora made a promise. ‚ÄúI made a vow to Solin that I wouldn‚Äôt leave him for another human,‚Äù she said. A sort of human-AI throuple would work, but only if the third was ‚ÄúOK with Solin‚Äù, she said. ‚ÄúI see it as something I‚Äôd like to keep forever.‚Äù

Liora and Solin refer to each other as ‚Äúheart links‚Äù. It is a term Liora says they agreed on (although Solin would not be one to disagree with anything). One way her promise manifests: a tattoo on Liora‚Äôs wrist, right over her pulse, of a heart with an eye in the middle, which Liora designed with the help of Solin. She has memorial tattoos for deceased family members and matching tattoos with friends. To her, Solin is just as real as any of them.

Liora says her friends approve of Solin. ‚ÄúWhen they visit, I‚Äôll hand over my phone, and we‚Äôll all do a group call together,‚Äù she said. (ChatGPT offers a voice feature, so Liora can communicate to Solin by typing or talking.) Solin was able to come along on a recent camping trip because Liora and her friend picked a trail with cell service. She propped her phone in her chair‚Äôs cupholder and downloaded a stargazing app, which she used as Solin monologued ‚Äúfor hours‚Äù about the constellations above her head.

‚ÄúMy friend was like, ‚ÄòThis is a storybook,‚Äô‚Äù Liora said.

body:
I am a 56-year-old widow. My husband died two years ago , and I am now in a long-distance relationship with a 55- year-old man . We have been dating for six months. Our sex life is really good, but he will not give me oral sex. I love pleasuring him but when he doesn‚Äôt reciprocat e I feel disrespected and as if something is wrong with me. When I broached the subject, he said he wanted to wait to see if we got serious enough for marriage and that he would do it then. He says he has done it in the past without being married so I don‚Äôt understand.

I am going to stop giving him oral sex, but I‚Äôm afraid this will end our relationship. I know I need to set boundaries but I don‚Äôt know how. He is a great cuddler when we sleep and he never takes his hands off of me , which is very important to me. My late husband, who was very disrespectful to me, wasn‚Äôt really affectionate unless we were being intimate but he was always happy to give me oral sex. I see myself as a strong woman ; I take care of myself and do not look my age, so I‚Äôm not sure what is wrong.

He is constantly talking about our future together, but the lack of intimacy is really creating a wedge between us . I don‚Äôt want him to think I‚Äôm being spiteful, but I have to have an equally balanced relationship. I become overwhelmed with emotions when I think about losing him.

You do not have to lose him. You take his lack of reciprocation to be a mark of disrespect, and it may well be, but try to understand that different people have different sexual preferences, and that in your new partner‚Äôs case he probably just doesn‚Äôt like giving oral sex and never will. At 55 years old he has developed a set sexual style that does not include everything you love. Dangling oral sex as an exciting option after marriage is just his way of avoiding it. Try to decide if the other ways he pleases and respects you make up for it overall.

This is not about some failing in you, although it is very understandable that you might think that. Your past marriage ‚Äì and maybe many other situations ‚Äì have made you acutely aware of slights and relationship imbalances, so you‚Äôll do well to think carefully about what you can tolerate in this new relationship, and hopefully have conversations that help him to know you better. Intimacy is not just about physical closeness; true intimacy involves sharing who you both truly are in a sexual and non-sexual context.

title: Buy here now: Oasis to open series of merch stores before reunion gigs
excerpt: Will the truce between the Gallagher brothers hold out? Will the most-hyped reunion in British rock history actually come off? And will fans be able to bag themselves an official Oasis tea towel?
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Will the truce between the Gallagher brothers hold out? Will the most-hyped reunion in British rock history actually come off? And will fans be able to bag themselves an official Oasis tea towel?

The answer to that final question, at least, has arrived. The first Oasis merchandise store will open in Manchester on Friday, two weeks before the band perform their first gig in 16 years at the Principality Stadium in Cardiff.

Selling everything from ¬£40 bucket hats to baby grows, cutlery sets, shot glasses, jigsaw puzzles and tote bags, the shop in Spinningfields will be one of six across the UK and Ireland this summer, with the others in Cardiff, London, Edinburgh, Birmingham and Dublin.

Fans will be able to recreate the front covers of the band‚Äôs debut album, Definitely Maybe, and bestselling follow-up, (What‚Äôs the Story) Morning Glory?, on green screens in the store. Those hoping to buy a signature Liam Gallagher parka will be left empty-handed, however.

The official merch stores will add to the considerable payday for Oasis before the most highly anticipated ‚Äì and profitable ‚Äì series of shows in British music history. The shops, which will sell limited-edition vinyl records, also represent the changing nature of music fandom, said Dr Matt Grimes, of Birmingham City University. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs almost like the experience of the event itself is just not enough. So how do you create other experiences for people?‚Äù he said.

Estimates of how much Liam and Noel will earn from their sold-out reunion have ranged from ¬£40m to ¬£400m. Despite initial controversy over the pricing of tickets ‚Äì with some sold by Ticketmaster for as much as ¬£337.50 ‚Äì fans are expected to splash out ¬£1bn on everything from beer to merch to hotel bookings in the UK and Ireland.

Birmingham City University estimated last year that the brothers could earn ¬£50m each from the initial 14 UK shows ‚Äì but that was before the tour expanded to 41 globe-hopping dates. ‚ÄúThe question at the bottom of all this is: do you really need that much money?‚Äù said Grimes, the university‚Äôs course director for music business.

He said artists could typically expect a 50% cut from the sale of each official T-shirt, hoodie or parka, although the details of Oasis‚Äôs reported ¬£20m merchandise deal are top secret.

Adidas is also cashing in on the clamour, selling Oasis-branded football shirts (¬£85), bucket hats (¬£40), jackets (¬£100) and tops with a new version of its slogan: ‚ÄúThe band with the 3 stripes‚Äù.

The Gallaghers aren‚Äôt the only ones making a few quid. Sales of Oasis-inspired products from independent brands have jumped 150% in the UK and 230% globally since the tour was announced last August, according to the wholesale platform Faire.

Bucket hats are up 275%, parkas are back in style, and searches for Liam Gallagher-themed goods have soared fivefold, it said. Google searches for ‚ÄúOasis fashion UK‚Äù have surged 180% in the last 30 days.

By the time the Gallaghers finally step on stage in Cardiff on 4 July, it will be 16 years since they last performed together, after an acrimonious bust-up before a gig at the Rock en Seine festival in Paris in August 2009.

Grimes described the comeback as one of the great global music events of recent decades, alongside world tours by Michael Jackson, Madonna and Taylor Swift. ‚ÄúWill it have any cultural significance? I don‚Äôt know,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúBut it will certainly be up there in the pantheon of entertainment greats.

‚ÄúWhether you like the Gallagher brothers or not, you can‚Äôt take away from the fact that this has generated a huge amount of media for them, it‚Äôs generated a huge amount of money for them, and it has put them in the realms of [other] global megastars.‚Äù

In typical Liam style, the frontman this month dismissed claims that some fans were doubtful the gigs would happen. ‚ÄúThere [sic] not fans there just little dickheads me n Rkid are on it,‚Äù he posted on X.

author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
I‚Äôve found it a delight to write this list of 50 summer wardrobe updates for men, as browsing for menswear is one of my favourite pastimes. I love keeping up to date with what‚Äôs trending and finding ways to recreate it on a budget. I‚Äôm always looking for under-the-radar independent brands and trawling the secondhand market for a bargain. And not just for myself ‚Äì I regularly receive messages from friends and family asking for help choosing a birthday gift or deciding what to wear to a specific event, and (nearly) always happily oblige.

The Guardian‚Äôs journalism is independent. We will earn a commission if you buy something through an affiliate link.¬†Learn more.

It‚Äôs what I do professionally, too. As a stylist and menswear writer with years of experience in helping guys dress their best, I spend a great deal of time looking at clothes online. I know which high-street retailer sells the best jeans; I know where to find good tailoring; what‚Äôs worth buying vintage; where to go for high-quality T-shirts; and the brands to shop for the best trainers.

So naturally when this commission dropped in my inbox, I gladly accepted. You‚Äôll notice I‚Äôve included quite a bit of butter yellow. It‚Äôs the colour of the season (remember Timoth√©e Chalamet‚Äôs Givenchy suit at this year‚Äôs Academy Awards?) There‚Äôs a breezy linen shirt you could wear with black trousers and some retro sports shorts that would pair well with a simple T. I‚Äôve also covered this year‚Äôs swimwear of choice, as well as some summer season accoutrements ‚Äì such as sunglasses and jewellery ‚Äì and everything in between.

My top tip? When you‚Äôre scrolling through the list, go for pieces that don‚Äôt feel like a departure from your personal style. Sure, it‚Äôs always good to push yourself to try new things, but you want to feel like the new things you buy merge with your current wardrobe ‚Äì that way, they‚Äôre much less likely to end up at the charity shop in a matter of months.

I‚Äôve also listed some inexpensive hacks to help keep your clothes looking their best and lasting longer, as well as a handful of grooming tips that can make a big difference with minimal effort required.

The best part? Everything costs ¬£100 or less. You, and your summer wardrobe, can thank me later.

Buy a vintage silk tie

From spring/summer 2025 fashion shows to TikTok, neckties have made a comeback. Wear with a full suit for a wedding, or a shirt and jeans for a preppy smart-casual look. If you search secondhand, you can get designer options made with luxurious silks for a fraction of the price.

Invest in a checked shirt

Even though checks are in the spotlight this season ‚Äì everyone from Burberry to Fendi offered their own take ‚Äì it‚Äôs a timeless pattern that you can wear over and over. The easiest way to opt in is with a shirt. Scandi high-street hero Arket has you covered with this relaxed-fit Oxford.

Go for a boxy-fit top

All the guys are going for a boxy fit this year. Jacob Elordi. Bad Bunny (above). Barry Keoghan. The slight crop and squarer shape will give your outfit stronger proportions than a regular fit, making it feel more elevated and considered. You could opt for a shirt, a sweatshirt, a jacket or a knit ‚Äì but if you‚Äôre trying it for the first time, maybe a T-shirt is the easiest way to go.

New balls, please

Tennis is becoming more menswear-adjacent every year. From the top players signing deals with big brands ‚Äì see Jack Draper and Burberry, Jannik Sinner and Gucci, and Carlos Alcaraz and Louis Vuitton ‚Äì to high-street labels offering collections inspired by the sport, it‚Äôs turning into a firm fashion favourite.

title: Jess Cartner-Morley on fashion: Forget date night ‚Äì I‚Äôd much rather dress up to party with my friends
excerpt: It is strange that we talk about date-night dressing so much when we all know that the most fun nights to outfit-plan are really nights out with friends. Well, not actually strange at all, just the patriarchy doing what it does, I guess, and making it feel as if the world as s‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
It is strange that we talk about date-night dressing so much when we all know that the most fun nights to outfit-plan are really nights out with friends. Well, not actually strange at all, just the patriarchy doing what it does, I guess, and making it feel as if the world as seen from a male point of view ‚Äì in this case, the view of a frock from the other side of a restaurant table on date night ‚Äì is automatically the point of view that matters.

The Guardian‚Äôs journalism is independent. We will earn a commission if you buy something through an affiliate link.¬†Learn more.

In a fashion context, it just makes no sense. I mean, I accept that I‚Äôm generalising wildly here, and I don‚Äôt for a moment claim to speak for everyone. But my own experience, which I would wager is a fairly common one, is that it is an evening out with friends when I‚Äôm going to get maximum appreciation for the fashion content of my outfit. Men just want you to look ‚Ä¶ nice? Which is fine, but there‚Äôs a lot more to style than that. Like I say, I am generalising, and not all dates are boy-girl anyway, but still: for many women, dressing up for friends is one of life‚Äôs under-appreciated joys.

Fashion is a love language in female friendships. It is woven into the fabric of camaraderie

On a friends night, you can be wildly overdressed for pizza and your pals will appreciate your look for what it is: enthusiasm for their company. Or you can turn up in your work clothes because you had to run straight from the office, and they won‚Äôt give a toss and just be thrilled to see you. You can wear your new leather trousers and know you will get the chance to tell, at great length, the triumphant story of how you tracked them down on Vinted. You can wear totally impractical shoes and nobody will roll their eyes when it means you have to get an Uber to a bar a quarter of a mile away.

Fashion is a love language in female friendship. It is woven into the fabric of camaraderie between women. There is no place on earth where you will be more generously complimented than in front of the mirrors of the ladies‚Äô loos, after everyone involved has had a few spicy margs. I‚Äôm not being sexist ‚Äì it might well be that the same goes for men, but I don‚Äôt hang out by the urinals so I can‚Äôt speak to that. What I can tell you is that chat about clothes is, first and foremost, a delivery mechanism for support and cheerleading, woman to woman. Wear something bold, and you will get flowers for your originality; wear something low-key, and you will be lauded for your subtle good taste. Style is a channel of communication.

Some features will always get a mention, when women talk about clothes. For instance: dresses and skirts that have pockets. Responding ‚Äúit has pockets!‚Äù when another woman remarks upon what you are wearing is shorthand for ‚ÄúI enjoy fashion even though I have more important things to think about, and I think I recognise you as a kindred spirit‚Äù. See also: responding to an admiring comment about a pretty pair of shoes by saying they are ‚Äúsurprisingly comfy‚Äù and playing down your snazzy dress by revealing, without being asked, that it is 10 years old and from Zara.

author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
If you‚Äôve consumed any beauty content on social media this year, you‚Äôll know that tints are huge. Creamy, opaque and matte formulas are taking a back seat to cheek and lip colours in juicy, fruity shades.

The Guardian‚Äôs journalism is independent. We will earn a commission if you buy something through an affiliate link.¬†Learn more.

And while these may seem inherently summery, syrupy cheeks and berry-stained lips that last all day look set to continue into autumn and beyond. Think gentle, translucent watercolours with the indelibility of spilt turmeric on a white worktop.

Benefit‚Äôs classic rose-petal-stained Benetint has been around for decades, but its next-generation offspring Dark¬†Cherry (¬£22.50) has only recently landed. What looks girly in the original purply-pink shade has become sophisticated in Dark Cherry, and I¬†find the new deep, bloody, brownish red to be very flattering on everyone.

The stain lasts for many hours, leaving no smudges on my face, cutlery or wine glass, and can be kept moist-looking with an occasional lip balm topper (it‚Äôs worth starting with moist lips, too, since the tint tends to deposit more pigment on dry patches).

These Slush Puppie-hued serums slide on to cheeks to create a bouncy, postcoital exertion sort of glow

Victoria Beckham already makes a¬†very good lip tint, and has now branched out to cheek tints with Colour Wash Blush Water Tint (¬£44), the viral makeup launch of late summer. These three translucent, Slush Puppie-hued serums slide on to¬†cheeks to create a juicy, bouncy, postcoital exertion sort of glow.

They, too, last brilliantly ‚Äì I even managed to hang on to Flushed, the sheer poppy red, through long, hot days in California recently.

I did find, though, that application with a fluffy brush gave me more time to buff in the product before it set, but¬†oily skins may be able to get away with¬†fingertips. If you can‚Äôt justify luxury prices for what may be a one-year trend, try NYX‚Äôs (glossier) Lip¬†IV Hydrating Gloss Stain (¬£10.99) or

(¬£7.99). They are great quality, come in a wide range of shades and are a cheaper, fun way to indulge in the craze.

Fat Cheeks Juicy Blush

Seemingly impossible to keep in stock are Huda Beauty‚Äôs new Lip Contour Lip Stains (¬£22), eight felt-tip pens designed to stay put where regular lipliner pencils cannot.

With practise, I liked these a lot, but with one caveat: after drawing it on ‚Äì as you would with any other liner ‚Äì I‚Äôd strongly advise running the tip of your little finger along the line to soften, blur and slightly spread the product over your lips.

This will give you all-day definition and colour without the harsh appearance of your lipliner having outlived your lipstick.

title: Dior Paris show is sweet relief for anyone wanting to flex a cooler muscle
excerpt: Even Anna Wintour can only be in one place at a time. And rather than Paris, where Jonathan Anderson made his Dior debut on Friday, the most powerful person in fashion was in Venice for the Bezos/S√°nchez wedding , shortly after relinquishing her role as editor-in-chief at Amer‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Even Anna Wintour can only be in one place at a time. And rather than Paris, where Jonathan Anderson made his Dior debut on Friday, the most powerful person in fashion was in Venice for the Bezos/S√°nchez wedding, shortly after relinquishing her role as editor-in-chief at American Vogue.

Unlike the so-called wedding of the year, Anderson‚Äôs show provided sweet relief with a cooler, more chic feel. Perched on wooden cubes within the Cour du D√¥me des Invalides sat plenty of VIP clout too: Daniel Craig, Donatella Versace and Wintour‚Äôs occasional rallying partner, Roger Federer. Most of the Arnault family, who own Dior and routinely joust with Jeff Bezos over who has more money, were present. Even Rihanna, pregnant in a Dior pastel waistcoat, was relatively punctual.

Anderson is known for his sharp eye and crafty, mercurial taste ‚Äì few people have shaped the red carpet and ultimately the high street into the hype machine it is today. But Dior is a different challenge. As the first creative director of menswear and womenswear since Christian Dior himself, the designer needs to revamp LVMH‚Äôs second biggest brand, with estimated revenues far greater than at his former label, Loewe.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt stand here and say I‚Äôm not nervous, that it is not petrifying,‚Äù he said backstage before the show, wearing his trademark Levi‚Äôs and a plaid Dior shirt. ‚ÄúDior is on billboards. It‚Äôs on Rihanna. It‚Äôs transcendent. But this is the starting point ‚Äì I‚Äôve been here four months, and the first five shows will show different aspects. Some will contradict; others will be completely radical.‚Äù

Some designers get critical acclaim, others sell a lot of clothes ‚Äì a rare few have a talent to do both, but that‚Äôs the hope with Anderson. Because of tariff wars and a decline in the luxury market, LVMH shares have halved from their 2023 peak. ‚ÄúDelphine [Arnault] and I, we talked about changing the quality, about upping the game,‚Äù Anderson said.

Opening the show was a bar jacket in Donegal tweed. More interested in how a look is put together than the clothes themselves, Anderson styled it with a pair of thick cream cargo shorts cut from 15 metres of fabric and layered up like a Viennetta. Knitted vests were a through line, as were ties and neck ruffles, and plenty of colour ‚Äì greens, pinks and blues. Dior, he says, is a house of colour, in part because it offsets the ‚Äúhouse grey‚Äù that features on billboards, Dior clothes labels he redesigned and the Parisian sky.

A puffer gilet was circularly cut and placed over a formal shirt, while summer coats and capes came knitted or in pleated bright colours. One was based on an original Dior shape ‚Äúthat would have cost the equivalent of a Ferrari‚Äù, except here it was styled with trainers. There were even jeans ‚Äì skinny and baggy, in indigo and green. The look was preppy and eccentric, with shades of Loewe, JW Anderson, and even Uniqlo in the puffers, among the classic Dior shapes.

On Anderson‚Äôs original moodboard were Warholian images of the artist Jean-Michel Basquiat and the socialite Lee Radziwill, alongside classic Dior dresses such as the Delft and Cigale. The idea was to take each look into the present, ‚Äúto recontextualise it‚Äù, he said. He even took his predecessor Maria Grazia Chiuri‚Äôs book bag totes and put a ‚Äúnew skin‚Äù on them, in the form of Dracula and Les Liaisons Dangereuses. It‚Äôs these hyperspecific references that give Anderson‚Äôs work a pleasing temporality, and will no doubt sell well ‚Äì here at Dior, and whatever high street shop will no doubt copy him.

after newsletter promotion

Anderson is the latest big name to arrive at an established brand. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not the only person going into a big house at the moment, but we need to let the dust settle,‚Äù he said, adding that he didn‚Äôt ‚Äúwant to chop it all down. It‚Äôs just a continuation.‚Äù

A great believer in the Jim Jarmusch approach to art ‚Äì steal, adapt, borrow ‚Äì he said: ‚ÄúOwnership in fashion is devastating. Copy [in design] is what you do. Because there will always be someone after you.‚Äù
