title: ‚ÄòYou can‚Äôt run a certification based on vibes‚Äô ‚Äì does B Corp still signal a business that cares?
excerpt: Princess Polly, available on Asos in the UK, has a lot in common with other ultra-fast fashion brands. Although a little more expensive than Boohoo and PrettyLittleThing, the Australian-American multinational offers the same kind of trend-driven, low-priced clothes, mostly mad‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Princess Polly, available on Asos in the UK, has a lot in common with other ultra-fast fashion brands. Although a little more expensive than Boohoo and PrettyLittleThing, the Australian-American multinational offers the same kind of trend-driven, low-priced clothes, mostly made from polyester. At the time of writing, shoppers can peruse more than 2,000 dresses, from a ¬£6 pink mini dress to an ¬£82 cream maxidress. There are bikini bottoms for ¬£3 and barrel-leg jeans from ¬£8. But there is one key difference between Princess Polly and its competitors. In early July, it became B Corp certified, bringing the certification‚Äôs integrity into question.

The Guardian‚Äôs journalism is independent. We will earn a commission if you buy something through an affiliate link.¬†Learn more.

B Corp is the world‚Äôs most recognisable corporate responsibility certification and, since its inception in 2006, has been awarded to businesses that meet its ‚Äúhigh standards of social and environmental performance, accountability, and transparency,‚Äù including Patagonia, the Body Shop and the Guardian. The B stands for ‚Äúbeneficial‚Äù.

The B Corp label has long symbolised a business dedicated to caring for people and planet. Through a rigorous, months- or even years-long verification process, it is intended to hold companies to high standards by measuring positive impact on workers, community, environment and customers. However, at the time of writing, Princess Polly is running a buy-one-get-one-60%-off promotion, pushing excess product in a way that doesn‚Äôt seem to align with B Corp values.

Dale McCarthy, whose carbon-neutral certified swimwear label Bondi Born was awarded B Corp status in 2020, says the news left her ‚Äúdeeply disappointed ... It makes a mockery of it.‚Äù ‚Äú[Now] it seems any company can get certified if they issue enough policies and tick enough boxes, even if the fundamentals of the business are a major contributor to environmental damage,‚Äù she says.

Another B Corp fashion brand, New Zealand designer Kowtow, takes issue with Princess Polly‚Äôs business model, which relies on producing vast volumes of clothing. ‚ÄúIt contributes to a hyperconsumerist culture,‚Äù says its managing director, Emma Wallace. ‚ÄúThe root [problem] of overproduction ‚Ä¶ needs to be addressed.‚Äù A new report from the Apparel Impact Institute (pdf) attributes the apparel industry‚Äôs 7% emissions increase to ultra-fast fashion, overproduction and a reliance on virgin polyester.

On its website, Princess Polly says: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre on a mission to make on-trend fashion sustainable‚Äù, and notes it has introduced a range of measures, including using ‚Äúlower-impact materials‚Äù such as recycled polyester and organic cotton in 30% of its ‚Äúnew arrivals‚Äù.

Sustainability campaigners and industry observers voice scepticism. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs greenwashing,‚Äù says Alden Wicker, the founder of the Substack EcoCult, which reports on sustainability issues in the industry. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt run a certification like this based on vibes. Anybody who wants a better world when it comes to how we purchase and consume fashion would have values that clash with the ethos of this brand.‚Äù

B Corp has found itself on shaky ground recently, not just because of Princess Polly. In February, after the certification of several companies not usually associated with good environmental practice, the famously ethically minded soap company Dr Bronner‚Äôs dropped the certification, stating: ‚ÄúSharing the same logo and messaging ‚Ä¶ [with] companies with a history of serious ecological and labour issues, and no comprehensive or credible eco-social certification of supply chains, is unacceptable to us‚Äù.

David Bronner, the company‚Äôs CEO, is unimpressed with the certification of Princess Polly. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just single-use plastic. You could be doing all kinds of good stuff, but if that‚Äôs your product offering, then that‚Äôs inherently not better for the world.‚Äù

Princess Polly says it‚Äôs ‚Äúproud of its environmental, social and governance progress‚Äù, and highlights that its focus is on two areas: ethical sourcing (100% of its mostly Chinese garment manufacturers have a ‚Äúvalid ethical manufacturing audit‚Äù) and environmental impact (it has pledged to reduce carbon emissions by 2030). But its circularity initiatives are scant (you can read its policy here) and it only has a vague commitment to paying living wages.

Last year, in the interest of sustainable fashion, I joined a pledge only to buy five new pieces of clothing. Despite thinking of myself as someone who doesn‚Äôt really shop, I found the restriction a real chore. Unless you‚Äôre buying vintage or spending a fortune, the dilemma of how to engage in the fun and newness of fashion without contributing to its environmental footprint is, it turns out, nearly universal: data in a new report reveals 74% of people want to dress more sustainably but most don‚Äôt know how to go about it.

The Guardian‚Äôs journalism is independent. We will earn a commission if you buy something through an affiliate link.¬†Learn more.

The report ‚Äì released by multi-brand retailer Zalando and GlobeScan ‚Äì found that 41% of consumers find sustainable garments too expensive and 27% say they are hard to identify. It‚Äôs little wonder sustainable fashion remains plagued by vague claims, convoluted supply chains and a call-out culture that‚Äôs left brands reluctant to promote initiatives to customers on the lookout for greenwashing.

‚ÄúPeople are more engaged than they‚Äôre often given credit for,‚Äù says Pascal Brun, Zalando‚Äôs vice-president of sustainability and D&I. Almost two decades after sustainable fashion entered mainstream discourse, most people have some awareness of the industry‚Äôs environmental impact ‚Äì carbon emissions, pollution of waterways, deforestation, microplastics, waste. They probably also know these ill effects are exacerbated by the sheer volume of product being made every year (somewhere between 80 and 150bn garments) and the increasing proportion derived from fossil-fuel based fabrics (polyester accounted for 57% of all fibres in 2024).

The rising popularity of ultra-cheap, ultra-fast fashion brands such as Shein and Temu (the targets of French legislation passed last week) brings the dilemma into stark focus. Yet this new data reveals, despite everyone‚Äôs best intentions, it‚Äôs not clear where and how to shop with a reduced impact. So, how does one buy reasonably priced, sustainable clothes?

The starting point is, of course, vintage ‚Äì sales of which happily, according to ThredUp‚Äôs Annual Resale Report, grew by 15% in 2024. Data from eBay suggests users search for ‚Äúvintage‚Äù items more than 1,200 times a minute. But given the constraints on sizing and the time required to sift through racks, second-hand clothing isn‚Äôt always practical.

When buying new clothes, context is important, says author and fashion educator Andrea Cheong. ‚ÄúWhat is financially accessible to people is going to vary, as is what is sustainable.‚Äù So rather than focusing on brands, she suggests buying the best quality of the item your budget can accommodate. That way, you will actually wear it. To assess quality, apply three criteria. First, buy nothing that contains a synthetic or semi-synthetic blend. Second, the garment must look as good on the inside as it does on the outside (small stitches, neat seams, non-synthetic lining). And third, it must be fit for purpose (leggings that are supportive enough for a workout, coats that keep you warm, pockets deep and sturdy enough to hold your phone).

Detail is your friend. Garments made from a single, natural fibre (100% cotton, linen or wool) are easier to recycle and generally more durable. If a brand is using sustainable materials, they will tell you about it ‚Äì and provide the nitty-gritty; specificity is the enemy of greenwashing. Look for third-party certifications that promote safe use of chemicals including Bluesign and Oeko-Tex, or regenerative or organic farming practices such as the Responsible Wool Standard and the Global Organic Textile Standard (Gots), or the inclusion of recycled content like the Global Recycled Standard.

Similarly, if a brand has engaged suppliers with closed-loop systems (to recycle water and chemicals) and renewable energy, who are paying a living wage, they will include this detail, as well ‚Äì most notably ‚Äì as the location of the factory on their website. This is a detail that reveals a level of trust, transparency and confidence. In addition, brands get bonus points for having repair, rental and resale programmes.

title: Chile targets fast fashion waste with landmark desert cleanup plan
excerpt: In a dusty corner of the Atacama Desert, the driest non-polar region on Earth, mounds of used clothes are scattered across the sand, where they sit, bleached and tattered, under the sun.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
In a dusty corner of the Atacama Desert, the driest non-polar region on Earth, mounds of used clothes are scattered across the sand, where they sit, bleached and tattered, under the sun.

As the sea mist drifts over a high coastal plateau above the city of Iquique in Chile‚Äôs far north, the breeze rustles plastic bags bursting with second-hand clothing.

Piles of garments stretch into the distance: consignments of nursing uniforms, shipments of shoes, bundles of work overalls and last season‚Äôs fast fashion discards, high street tags still attached.

But Chile‚Äôs government has taken a decisive step towards addressing the environmental crisis which has beset the Atacama Desert.

This week, the country‚Äôs environment ministry announced that it had added textiles as a ‚Äúpriority‚Äù category to its extended producer responsibility law, paving the way for importers to be made responsible for the waste produced by the thousands of tonnes of used clothing brought into Chile each year.

Importers are now obliged to report the clothing they bring into the country, and further regulations will be added to the bill shortly.

Chile‚Äôs government will also publish a public policy specifically targeting textiles and their place in the circular economy. One of its goals will be to eradicate textile dumps in the Atacama Desert.

According to government data, more than 90% of textiles sold in Chile are imported, making the South American country the world‚Äôs fourth-largest importer of second hand clothing.

The government calculates that Chile imports 123,000 tonnes of used clothing every year, with the effects felt most acutely in the north of the country ‚Äì where the situation in the Atacama Desert has won global attention.

‚ÄúThis would spur a new consumer culture, as companies would be required to offer repair, reuse, and recycling services,‚Äù said Beatriz O‚ÄôBrien, the national coordinator for NGO Fashion Revolution.

‚ÄúIt is a step toward a transition from a linear economy of production, consumption, and disposal to a circular economy for textiles and clothing in the country.‚Äù

Global textile production is projected to grow from the 109m tonnes manufactured in 2020 to 145m tonnes in 2030.

In Chile, people use an average of 32kg of textiles, contributing to 572,000 tonnes of textile waste per year in the country.

Every day, tonnes of clothing arrive duty-free at the freeport in Iquique as giant plastic-wrapped bales, where they are sliced open and sorted into categories by a migrant workforce.

The best clothes, often in near-pristine condition, are sold in outlet stores built into the narrow rows of warehouses at the freeport, or sent to Chile‚Äôs capital, Santiago, for resale. Some are even bailed up and sent back to the US to be resold.

The rest winds its way in a convoy of small trucks up to Alto Hospicio, a poor city sprawling across the plateau above Iquique, where the clothes are incorporated into a seemingly endless cycle of resale and reuse.

At La Quebradilla, one of the country‚Äôs largest open-air markets, vendors sell clothes for small amounts of cash, while the least desirable items are often slung out in the Atacama Desert.

Some are then burned, with thick plumes of black smoke spiralling skyward from a messy dump on a high plateau outside Alto Hospicio.

But after several years of research, Chile‚Äôs government has managed to add textiles to its extended responsibility law.

Many countries have similar legislation, but Chile‚Äôs, in force since 2017, had only made producers responsible for recycling goods in several categories, including, tires, batteries, oils and plastic packaging.

‚ÄúThe inclusion of textiles in the [producer responsibility law] will establish the obligations of producers, who will no longer be able to disregard the environmental impacts of unused textiles,‚Äù said Chile‚Äôs environment minister Maisa Rojas.

‚ÄúThe successful application of the law will allow us to address the lack of regulation for the industry, which has generated huge quantities of waste and affects the quality of life for people and the environment.‚Äù

According to the hemline index, skirts shift upwards during prosperous times ‚Äì the theory being that hemlines rise and fall in line with the economy. Well, it seems that for guys, it‚Äôs the opposite. With turbulent markets, our shorts are rising higher than ever ‚Äì so much so that this season has been dubbed ‚Äúthigh guy summer‚Äù.

Sure, we‚Äôve sort of been here before. Donald Glover was spotted in teeny tiny shorts back in 2022 while Paul Mescal, the king of short shorts, has been wearing them ever since Normal People was released in 2020. And lest we forget Milo Ventimiglia‚Äôs viral moment in his post-workout micro-minis in 2021.

However, this year has brought a gear change that can‚Äôt go unnoticed: Marks & Spencer, purveyor of British wholesomeness, has jumped on board. The high-street retailer has released a range of its shortest shorts ever, with an in-seam of less than 12.7cm (5in) ‚Äì clear proof that a thigh-grazing length is going mainstream.

What‚Äôs so interesting about short shorts, though, is that they always make headlines. They‚Äôve been around for decades (think John Travolta in Perfect, Tom Selleck as Magnum PI, and basically every pair of running shorts in the 70s), but a man‚Äôs bare legs still cause a stir. Whenever a celebrity wears anything above the knee ‚Äì whether on the red carpet or spotted in the wild ‚Äì it sends the internet into swooning overdrive: whether it‚Äôs Vogue and GQ reporting on Paul Mescal wearing boxers as shorts or the hoards of people thirsting over the Gladiator actor‚Äôs legs on X.

Mere mortals may not receive such high praise for baring a little leg, but only because it‚Äôs not fully normalised for a guy to show his mid-thigh area ‚Äì yet. Even as a stylist and fashion writer, I‚Äôve received a disapproving glance or two from more conservative folk, but the compliments always far outweigh the flak.

And, as a menswear expert, trust me when I say it just looks so good. It‚Äôs sexy. It‚Äôs cool. It even makes you look taller by visually elongating your legs. So, us guys have to be brave, pull our socks up, and put our short shorts on (look at Alexander Skarsg√•rd on Lorraine, below, to see how it‚Äôs done). The best part? To get it right, there are a few easy rules to follow. First of all, context is key. You may not want to wear them somewhere formal or if you‚Äôre likely to be with people who are more conservative. Second, always wear underwear to avoid any Basic Instinct-coded mishaps.

There‚Äôs one snag, though: a suit is a big-ticket item. But if you know where to look, a good-quality suit doesn‚Äôt need to cost a fortune. Choose something timeless and you‚Äôll have it for years.

I still wear a few suits I‚Äôve held on to for almost a decade. The ones that ended up at the charity shop, meanwhile, typically strayed from the timeless rule, with a skinny leg, bold colours or an ill-fitting silhouette.

Suits never really go out of style, but they‚Äôre having a moment in fashion right now. Menswear influencers (namely @chico_lachowski, @reubenlarkin and @josefmiichael) are sporting suits beyond formal events, and their accounts provide some good styling inspiration ‚Äì even if you choose to wear the trousers and blazers separately.

title: How the campus became the new catwalk
excerpt: It‚Äôs almost September, which means ‚Äúback to school‚Äù season is in full swing. But this year it‚Äôs not just British schoolgoers being bombarded with uniform reminders and lunchbox ideas. The classroom comeback now extends to university students. Welcome to a new era of the commod‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
It‚Äôs almost September, which means ‚Äúback to school‚Äù season is in full swing. But this year it‚Äôs not just British schoolgoers being bombarded with uniform reminders and lunchbox ideas. The classroom comeback now extends to university students. Welcome to a new era of the commodification of the campus.

The Guardian‚Äôs journalism is independent. We will earn a commission if you buy something through an affiliate link.¬†Learn more.

Previously, it was easy to differentiate between UK and US campus culture. US students had frat parties, drank from plastic red cups and slept in shared dorm rooms. Meanwhile, UK freshers had house parties, drank cans on the bus and congregated in communal kitchens. But thanks to social media the lines are becoming more blurred. Algorithms have influenced everyone to dress the same and now this is affecting campus culture. Social media is peppered with US and UK students doing room makeover tours and library fit checks, and the only difference between them is their accents and labels. Now, as the illusion of campus life becomes more powerful than the reality of it, brands are attempting to monetise it.

This month Kim Kardashian‚Äôs all-powerful shapewear label Skims pivoted from selling Hannibal Lecter-esque face-sculpting wraps to PJs for students to bed rot in. Its first dedicated ‚ÄúCampus Collection‚Äù features ‚Äúdorm-approved and lecture-ready‚Äù pieces such as jersey capri pants, cropped hoodies and cotton poplin micro shorts modelled by a group of real students (dubbed the ‚ÄúSkims Class of 2025‚Äù). On Asos you can browse a ‚ÄúStudent Edit‚Äù comprising over 2,000 pieces that promise to ‚Äúlook on-point in the lecture, library and beyond‚Äù ‚Äì because nothing says reading week like a sheer maxi skirt.

PrettyLittleThing‚Äôs ‚ÄúBack to Class‚Äù edit includes an advertising campaign shot in a library (a gear shift from their usual poolside settings) complete with models wearing preppy polo tops and rugby shirts. The accessories brand Charles & Keith has teamed up with students from Central Saint Martins, photographing them on the fashion school‚Äôs campus in their favourite pieces from the brand. Even Shein, the mega fast fashion company that churns out up to 10,000 new pieces a day, is hopping on the trend with a ‚ÄúCampus Babe‚Äù programme where students can apply to be ambassadors for the online retailer and earn a commission on sales. Presumably by never wearing the same piece twice.

‚ÄúStudents have become a crucial audience because they‚Äôre tastemakers,‚Äù says Nick Drabicky from January Digital, a marketing agency. According to Drabicky, this particular cohort appeals to brands as ‚Äúthey‚Äôre early adopters, hyper-connected, and influence household and peer spending.‚Äù

The campus-focused trend is a knock-on effect from RushTok (an amalgamation of rush week ‚Äì which is a bit like freshers‚Äô week ‚Äì and TikTok) , a corner of social media where applicants for elite Greek sororities in the USA document the process of getting a ‚Äúbid‚Äù (i.e. membership). The recruitment phenomenon first went viral on TikTok in August 2021 with PNMs (potential new members) sharing their experiences at the University of Alabama, including game nights and synchronised dances. However, it was outfit of the day videos posted from dorm rooms that really captivated viewers. These 60-second videos featured predominantly thin, white, 18-year-olds with bright blond hair and obvious fake tans name-checking brands such as Steve Madden shoes, Kendra Scott earrings, Golden Goose trainers and The Pants Store ‚Äì which, it turns out, didn‚Äôt just sell pants ‚Äì in a distinctive southern drawl. Viewers who prior to the videos were blissfully unaware of what a Panhellenic sorority is ‚Äì and lived in countries such as the UK where they don‚Äôt even exist ‚Äì began to mimic them, while phrases such as ‚ÄúMy jewelry is normal‚Äù were then commoditised and turned into merch.

Four years later and the yearly event has become akin to a reality TV show, with brands keen to get involved.

title: From budget sunnies to the perfect semi-short shorts: 69 summer style updates and hacks
excerpt: There is a very specific panic around summer dressing ‚Äì all that flesh on show, for starters. So it always seems strange just how little thought we give to it. Obviously you care what you look like, but think how much time and energy you put into finding the perfect winter coa‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
There is a very specific panic around summer dressing ‚Äì all that flesh on show, for starters. So it always seems strange just how little thought we give to it. Obviously you care what you look like, but think how much time and energy you put into finding the perfect winter coat, or boots to see you through the post-Christmas doldrums. Some of you probably save up, or at least try on a few different styles to see what you like. Compare that to choosing a swimsuit or shorts. How often do you buy something the day before you go on holiday, or even at the airport? You‚Äôll probably spend more time in your coat and boots but still, it‚Äôs a bit daft panic-buying some sandals before finding out, mid-hike, that the back strap rubs your heel and they slip off the moment your feet get sweaty.

The Guardian‚Äôs journalism is independent. We will earn a commission if you buy something through an affiliate link.¬†Learn more.

The truth is that aside from the fact that people equate wearing fewer clothes with being cooler ‚Äì not true! ‚Äì it‚Äôs very hard to know what to wear when the sun comes out. So we are here to help. How about a tank that needs no bra, a swimsuit that doubles as a top, and a quick-dry, no-towel towel? Or a T-shirt for the guys that‚Äôs cocktail-approved ‚Äì and a hat the kids will actually wear?

The perfect summer look is a mythical unicorn, but there are things you can invest in now that will see you through until late September and, ideally, multiple summers to come.Morwenna Ferrier

Womenswear by Jess Cartner-Morley

The full-coverage dress your summer wardrobe needs

Counterintuitive though it is, the summer dress I wear most has long sleeves and is almost ankle length. A full-coverage but super-light dress is so much more useful than any number of itsy-bitsy sundresses. It keeps the rays off if it‚Äôs hot, the air conditioning off when you‚Äôre inside, and doesn‚Äôt leave you goosebumpy in the evening. Great for holiday days, office days, travelling days. Look for one you can wear with a bra ‚Äì this one has a cut-out at the back, but above bra-strap height ‚Äì and ensure it‚Äôs a generous fit.

The cami that works as evening wear

A friend asked me the other day if she could borrow ‚Äúthat lovely Stella McCartney camisole‚Äù. Turns out she meant this, which is actually a silk camisole from M&S. So chic for a night out with jeans, blazer and kitten heels.

A clash course

Instead of striped trousers and a plain T-shirt, try clashing your prints. Think stripes and florals. Leopard and polka dots. Camo and gingham. The more unexpected, the better.

A tank top with a built-in bra

If you have huge boobs, this isn‚Äôt going to work, so apologies, but for many women, a top with a built-in bra is ideal when you want that sleek, no-bra-strap vest-top look but also a bit of support. I love these Uniqlo ones because the support layer is totally invisible, and the tank isn‚Äôt too tight.

The ¬£35 M&S swimsuit that‚Äôs a modern classic

Two years ago, I bought a black neoprene scallop-edged bikini from M&S. I love it so much that this year I added the one-piece version. I have it in emerald, which is now sold out, but the tomato red is possibly even nicer, and the white is very Talented Mr Ripley coded.

The not-too-long, not-too-short shorts

It‚Äôs not so much that I‚Äôm too old to wear baggy knee-length shorts ‚Äì no one is too old to wear anything ‚Äì it‚Äôs more that I‚Äôm old enough to know I don‚Äôt have to wear anything that makes me feel ridiculous just because it‚Äôs fashionable. Same goes for tiny Daisy Dukes. A short that hits the mid‚Äëpoint of the thigh is the answer. This length can look a bit dowdy in linen, so I‚Äôd go with denim. And possibly a belt for added smarts.

title: Women‚Äôs spring wardrobe essentials: 27 easy-to-wear pieces to see you through the season

author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Spring feels like the perfect time to blow away the cobwebs ‚Äì in life and in your wardrobe. After a winter of wool and heavy boots, the time is ripe for shaking up your look with a warm(er) weather update.

That doesn‚Äôt mean buying a whole new wardrobe: one of the things I enjoy about getting older is developing a wardrobe for each season that comes back year on year. Put clothes away between seasons: some items that make their way back out of storage were everyday favourites before then, while others may not have felt right for some time but now ‚Äì lucky for you ‚Äì they feel right once again. There‚Äôs something extra-fun about falling back in love with something from your own wardrobe.

Having said that, the odd update can be a welcome thing in a wardrobe needing to cope afresh with sun, showers and occasions such as weddings and holidays. Now‚Äôs the time to do a wardrobe audit, think carefully about what you need and what you don‚Äôt, and let this guide inspire you to fill any gaps, thoughtfully.

A jacket

Rainbow gingham jacket

¬£135 at Boden ¬£135 at John Lewis

Boden isn‚Äôt a brand I naturally recommend, but this jacket is an instant spring wardrobe shaker-upper. Fun, a versatile fit and a massive shot of sartorial caffeine. What‚Äôs not to make you smile.

A dress

Polka dot midaxi cami dress

Very much in the vein of the polka dot dress Julia Roberts famously wore in Pretty Woman, this frock from M&S stands out. Team it with your old denim jacket if the weather‚Äôs still patchy, or a blazer if you want to smarten up the look. It‚Äôs 100% cotton and available in regular, petite or tall lengths, and it will fill a hole in several wardrobes. It will also signal you know what‚Äôs currently filling column inches in Vogue: the polka dot, while also a timeless classic, is pinging back this spring. If that one doesn‚Äôt float your boat, M&S is currently a trove of other similarly affordable polka dot styles which just might (such as this one).

A bag

A different season calls for a different bag. Those heavy leather bags of winter start to feel OTT come spring, and lighter materials feel more in keeping. You may have an old wicker basket from warm seasons past to pull out. If not, this handcrafted basket bag, made out of the veta vera plant in northern Ghana, is a great option. Big enough to carry pints of milk back from the shop and available in a few different colours, it will also make a nice storage basket in the colder months. Or, basket bags are two-a-penny on Etsy, from classic, understated woven straw baskets with leather handles to sisal shoppers and wicker totes. Just search ‚Äúbasket bag‚Äù and make sure your results are filtered so you‚Äôre looking only at ones that dispatch from the UK. Dress them up or down and wear them to the office or the beach.

This time of year offers a chance to have fun playing around with colour via sock and shoe combinations. Spring shoes offer up more room for socks to speak, so pick a pair with something to say, like this bright pink cotton-blend pair from Le Bon Shoppe, pedlars of good-quality socks. title: Want to look posh on a budget? It‚Äôs all about the right colours | Jess Cartner-Morley
excerpt: This outfit looks so classy, doesn‚Äôt it? Understated, but with an indefinable air of poshness. Effortless, but elevated. But did you spot the best part? It‚Äôs in the small print. The clothes are from Uniqlo and the shoes are from Zara. The look is expensive, but the clothes are‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
This outfit looks so classy, doesn‚Äôt it? Understated, but with an indefinable air of poshness. Effortless, but elevated. But did you spot the best part? It‚Äôs in the small print. The clothes are from Uniqlo and the shoes are from Zara. The look is expensive, but the clothes aren‚Äôt.

The Guardian‚Äôs journalism is independent. We will earn a commission if you buy something through an affiliate link.¬†Learn more.

Money isn‚Äôt everything, but some pricey clothes look cheap and some inexpensive clothes look luxurious, and I think we all know which side of that divide we‚Äôd rather be on. A great way to get it right is by picking the right colours ‚Äì tonal warm neutrals are what you need for high style without high prices.

What you have to do is seek out exactly those colours you may initially overlook. Faced with a rack of clothes, a default approach is to reach for black or white, because we know those colours are useful and we know where we are with them. Or, on a different day with a different mindset, we are drawn to the prettiest, brightest, most eye-catching colours. An exciting colour makes a piece feel more special, more valuable.

But the best-value colours are not found at the end of the rainbow. Or indeed anywhere on it. They are the soft, muted pieces that have more warmth than the austere minimalism of monochrome, without the cheesiness of brights.

These colours would scream good taste, except they are much too elegant to scream anything

Olive. Terracotta. Putty. Mocha. Plaster. Sand. Butter. The names evoke the good life ‚Äì chic kitchens, sunny gardens, good food. The sartorial equivalent of Farrow & Ball paint, these are colours that come from nature, not colours that look straight out of a car paint factory. They are nuanced rather than basic. They would scream good taste, except they are much too elegant to scream anything.

Forget black, shift to charcoal. Put down the white, and reach for oatmeal. I‚Äôm making it sound really straightforward, which it is. But it can feel challenging, mainly because it is not immediately obvious what these colours go with. Many of us lack confidence in our judgment when putting colours together, so we tend to go with combinations that feel familiar ‚Äì a flag trio of red, white and blue, for example. Faced with a pair of chocolate trousers, we pick them up and worry: what shoes would I wear with these? Will they go with my coat? And put them down and reach for blue jeans.

The secret to making posh colours work in your wardrobe is to treat them as neutrals. Let them all rub along together. Don‚Äôt get hung up on what goes with what. We have wired our brains to think that colours need to stay in their lane, one or two per outfit. If one colour is popping in your outfit ‚Äì a pink jumper, say ‚Äì it feels as if everything else must match it. Following this formula can block you from trying out new colours, because it isn‚Äôt immediately obvious how they slot into your usual wardrobe formulas.

Soft, warm, earthy tones vibrate on the same colour frequency, so your eye reads them as a match. A butter-yellow shirt under a tan leather jacket. Khaki cargo pants with a deep sea green shirt. Take another look at the outfit here ‚Äì shades of cream, green and brown, as well as black. The effect is soothing, a blur of neutrals, like gazing out of a train window at an all‚Äënatural landscape.

title: ‚ÄòInhaling the microplastics‚Äô: what is in British children‚Äôs school uniforms?
excerpt: Hugo Keane‚Äôs investigation into polyester began at home. He had just started year 7 but, thanks to Covid, he was stuck knocking about at home in Camden, north London.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Hugo Keane‚Äôs investigation into polyester began at home. He had just started year 7 but, thanks to Covid, he was stuck knocking about at home in Camden, north London.

‚ÄúIt was kind of a family pandemic project,‚Äù said his mother, Alexandra Milenov. ‚ÄúHe sat down with my husband and did the calculations on the microplastic release of three items of his uniform: the blazer, the PE T-shirt and the shorts.‚Äù

What he found out was to significantly affect his school career.

Almost every child in England spends about 195 days a year in uniform. They are not a legal requirement, but the Department for Education insists they promote ‚Äúthe ethos of a school‚Äù, provide ‚Äúa sense of belonging and identity‚Äù and set ‚Äúan appropriate tone for education‚Äù.

But the widespread use of uniforms has a hidden cost: most of them are made from polyester, the synthetic, petroleum-derived fibre that is one of the world‚Äôs most significant environmental pollutants, leading some to question our reliance on it, and whether it is a suitable fabric in which to dress our children.

Polyester, the ‚Äúmiracle fabric‚Äù, was invented in Britain in the 1940s as a new synthetic fabric that followed the popularity of nylon in the 1930s. Thanks to its durability, economy and ease of production, it has come to dominate the global garment industry, and by 2023, 71.1m tonnes of polyester were produced around the world ‚Äì 57% of global textile production.

‚ÄúPolyester is, in fact, the most-used synthetic fabric globally,‚Äù said Dr Melis Duyar, an associate professor in chemical and process engineering at the University of Surrey. ‚ÄúSince there is no need to grow the fibres needed to make this fabric, it can be made cheaply and quickly in vast quantities, which is why it has become the fabric of choice for the fast fashion industry.‚Äù

But in common with other petroleum-derived plastics, polyester is not biodegradable. ‚ÄúWashing causes each item of clothing to shed tiny strands, or microfibres, which are carried down the drain and into our water systems,‚Äù Duyar said. ‚ÄúMicroplastics are particularly hard to remove from the environment and are easily ingested by organisms across the food chain.‚Äù

The infiltration of these microfibres into the biosphere is now well known ‚Äì these insidious chemical pollutants have been detected from the Mariana Trench to the peak of Mount Everest, and in almost every organ of the human body. Researchers have estimated that synthetic textiles are responsible for 35% of the microplastics in the planet‚Äôs oceans. But the long-term effects of them remain uncertain.

At home, using a Plymouth University study which estimated that between 700 and 4,000 microplastic fibres are released per gram in a single wash, Hugo calculated that just a year‚Äôs worth of washing and everyday wear of the uniforms worn by the 125 boys in his year would shed 6.4bn plastic microfibres.

When school Covid restrictions ended, Hugo presented his findings at his student council and in class. Teachers were enthusiastic about his advocacy, and helped him take it to the headteacher and the board of governors. ‚ÄúAnd you know everyone was very supportive and excited about his work,‚Äù said Milenov. Meanwhile, she had managed to source a cotton alternative to nearly every item of school uniform, but not the blazer, which in any case had been temporarily waived for fear that such an infrequently washed item would be a vector for Covid transmission.

Milenov lobbied the school, but the headteacher was not interested in changing direction, and by the time Hugo entered year 8, William Ellis reimposed all uniform requirements, including the wearing of its polyester blazer. ‚ÄúWe wrote to the head of year 8, and we attached Hugo‚Äôs presentation, and we said for environmental reasons, and because we want to support our son‚Äôs advocacy, we are unable to purchase or have him wear polyester items in the school uniform,‚Äù said Milenov.

Her persistence worked; Hugo was granted an exemption. The school agreed that his objections to the pollution caused by polyester schoolwear had the status of a protected belief. To forestall disciplinary action from over-keen teachers, he was issued with a card: ‚ÄúNotification of non-compliance with school uniform,‚Äù reason: ‚ÄúSustainability ethical issue.‚Äù

title: Elegant, determined, a little unknowable: Giorgio Armani is gone but will never be forgotten
excerpt: Giorgio Armani dressed all of us. Whether or not you ever had the money for a jacket with an Armani label, you wore a jacket that he invented. He was the mastermind of contemporary style, the architect of how we dress now. If you have worn an unstructured suit with a T-shirt t‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Giorgio Armani dressed all of us. Whether or not you ever had the money for a jacket with an Armani label, you wore a jacket that he invented. He was the mastermind of contemporary style, the architect of how we dress now. If you have worn an unstructured suit with a T-shirt to a wedding; if you have worn muted neutrals to work; if you have thought it might be chic to paint your living room grey: that was Armani.

Armani was working until his final days. Invitations had already been sent out for his next show, to be held on 28 September in the 14th-century courtyard of Milan‚Äôs Palazzo Brera. A spectacular party to accompany the show was planned as a celebration of the 50th anniversary of the brand, which he founded in the summer of 1975.

On my phone I have dozens of videos of Armani taking catwalk bows at the end of his Milan ready-to-wear and Paris haute couture shows. For the past decade, everyone in the audience at each of his shows has been aware of being in the presence of a living legend. Each brief catwalk appearance has felt like a moment to capture, because even legends don‚Äôt live for ever.

Those videos tell the story of a dignified, determined man, who even a decade ago, at 80, was taking bows in fitted navy T-shirts that showed off an impressive physique. In his last few years the walk became slower, the wave less muscular, but he was still immaculate.

At his January haute couture show in Paris, he wore a double-breasted black velvet tuxedo, smiling as he walked on the arm of a favourite model, blue eyes still piercing. In June and July this year, he was absent from his menswear and haute couture shows for the first time but oversaw fittings via video link from home, and corresponded with reporters over email.

Newspaper house style requires that we refer to him as Armani, but he was always Mr Armani, not just to the industry at large but to close colleagues. The fashion industry has long been a first-name-term world, even at the highest levels ‚Äì backstage, Donatella is Donatella, and Karl was Karl ‚Äì but the most commercially successful European fashion designer of the past century was never Giorgio, or even Armani, but always Signor or Mr Armani.

His persona was elegant, detached and a little unknowable. On the occasions when I interviewed him ‚Äì at his home in Milan, at Paris haute couture fashion week, and on his yacht, Mariu ‚Äì he was courteous and polite, an impeccably gracious host, but always with a note of reserve.

The Armani story begins with a suit. In the late 1970s, Armani took the trousersuit, filleted out all the stuffiness and tradition, and replaced it with a veneer of urbane sophistication and a spritz of louche sex appeal. In doing so, he reinvented power dressing for the late 20th century.

More than that, in fact: he redefined what it meant to look modern. Armani intuited how the once pin-sharp divisions between a starched world of work and a warm-slippered domestic bubble were already beginning to soften, in the 1970s and 1980s, even before the internet came along to annihilate them. His supple tailoring appealed to a generation who aspired to a different kind of success, who wanted to make it big but without losing their soul. They didn‚Äôt want to get stuck in the same office until they earned their carriage clock, but rather to prowl and preen around the city.

As lifestyles shifted, Armani tailored a new silhouette to fit. ‚ÄúStyle for me is a mood that can be applied to everything,‚Äù he once said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve always thought fashion is much more than just clothes: it is a way of being.‚Äù An Armani suit made a new generation feel like big beasts of the urban jungle. If you aspired to be an architect or an actor or a media hustler or an agent, this suit spoke to who you wanted to be. He took the suit, which had been stuck in the 9-to-5, and gave it both street smarts and bedroom appeal.

title: ‚ÄòPerfect match‚Äô: Charli xcx in Vivienne Westwood becomes gen Z‚Äôs bridal muse
excerpt: Charli xcx is a British pop star known for pioneering trends. Last summer she turned the word ‚ÄúBrat‚Äù into a cultural phenomenon complete with a uniform featuring ‚Äú a pack of cigs, a Bic lighter, and a strappy white top with no bra .‚Äù
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Charli xcx is a British pop star known for pioneering trends. Last summer she turned the word ‚ÄúBrat‚Äù into a cultural phenomenon complete with a uniform featuring ‚Äúa pack of cigs, a Bic lighter, and a strappy white top with no bra.‚Äù

So it came as somewhat of a surprise to fans when, last weekend, she opted for a more classic bridal look to marry George Daniel, the drummer in the band the 1975.

Arriving at Hackney town hall in east London, the bride wore a white sculpted corseted minidress from Vivienne Westwood. Even her accessories veered towards the traditional: a bouquet of locally grown white cosmos and dahlias, a short white veil, and slingback heels.

Despite the look being more conventional than defiant, Alexandra Macon, the weddings editor of Vogue.com and founder of the e-commerce site Over The Moon, describes the pop star‚Äôs choice of designer as a ‚Äúperfect match‚Äù.

‚ÄúVivienne Westwood has forged a legacy as a true ‚Äòanti-bride‚Äô icon in the world of bridal fashion,‚Äù Macon said.

In 2008, Sex and the City‚Äôs Carrie Bradshaw was jilted at the altar by Mr Big while wearing a floor-sweeping corseted gown from the British designer. Yet even without the couple‚Äôs eventual happy ending, a Westwood wedding dress has been desired by millennial brides ever since.

Seventeen years later, gen Z have welcomed their own bridal muse. This time the hemline may be shorter but the brand remains the same.

Charli xcx‚Äôs dress was inspired by the Cocotte, a style of dress Westwood first unveiled in her autumn/winter 1995 collection. Featuring a swooping neckline, a waist-cinching corset and draping detail on the hip, the original paid homage to the dresses worn by the 17th-century French author and courtesan Ninon de l‚ÄôEnclos.

Westwood was one of the first to subvert the historical flat corset. Instead of lacing there are zip fastenings, and while the corset still moulds the body there are stretch panels for comfort. Since then, the brand has launched numerous iterations of the silhouette. Off-the-peg versions start from ¬£3,200. The style is as popular among celebrities as it is with non-famous brides.

In 2005, Dita Von Teese wore a billowing purple version. Hailey Bieber wore a mini take on it for her nuptials, while Demi Lovato chose a longer length and added a cathedral-style veil. In June, the Hot Milk star Vicky Krieps wore a rose-patterned version for her Greek island wedding, while the model Daisy Lowe customised hers with a bustle and side slit.

skip past newsletter promotion

after newsletter promotion

Such is its ubiquity that last year Vogue declared it ‚Äúthe wedding dress of the decade‚Äù. Macon describes the silhouette as ‚Äúinstantly recognisable and beloved, which is why we see it again and again on brides‚Äù.

A finale bridal look has been the brand‚Äôs show signature since the 1990s when the model Sara Stockbridge was an unconventional bride, carrying her baby down the catwalk in a dress depicting Jean-Honor√© Fragonard‚Äôs 1797 painting The Swarm of Cupids.

Bridal is now a core part of the business with a dedicated atelier. In April, Vivienne Westwood staged its first standalone bridal show.

After trying on 120 dresses in her search for her perfect dress, the writer and influencer Katherine Ormerod was surprised to find herself choosing a Cocotte.

‚ÄúNo one wants to be a basic bitch and feel like what they‚Äôre wearing is ubiquitous, but also after all my years working in fashion, I‚Äôve seen the distinction between something that is trend-led and ‚Äòeverywhere‚Äô and design which is iconic, timeless and popular for a reason,‚Äù she says.

The Cocotte dress is also a hot ticket item on resale and rental platforms. Ormerod says that ‚Äúin contrast to a sea of algorithmically fine-tuned brands and designs‚Äù, it ‚Äúfeels like a bit of a FU to the lace and full train‚Äù.

Six months after her wedding, Ormerod sold hers. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt think of anything sadder than that beautiful dress hanging, Miss Havisham-like, in a dust bag for ever. It wasn‚Äôt a hard sell: within a fortnight it had found its new bride.‚Äù

title: ‚ÄòRage bait‚Äô or good design? The Row‚Äôs ¬£600 sliders are an exquisite provocation
excerpt: Rounded, cushioned and with a thick strap, foam sliders have been a familiar sight on feet this summer. While they are available for ¬£30 from Adidas or ¬£3.49 on the online marketplace Temu, a high-fashion version is now also on offer. The Ama sliders , in a choice of black, re‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Rounded, cushioned and with a thick strap, foam sliders have been a familiar sight on feet this summer. While they are available for ¬£30 from Adidas or ¬£3.49 on the online marketplace Temu, a high-fashion version is now also on offer. The Ama sliders, in a choice of black, red or white, were launched by the American fashion brand The Row this week. They cost ¬£600.

Laura Reilly, the writer of the influential fashion newsletter Magasin, called them ‚ÄúThe Row‚Äôs latest rage bait‚Äù, using the name for posts online designed to provoke anger, and go viral in the process.

Fashion‚Äôs version of rage bait seems to be luxurious versions of everyday things. It remains unclear whether the creators of these items are deliberately provoking a reaction, but the prices certainly drive some consumers into a fury.

The Ama follows The Row‚Äôs other recent item in this tradition: the Dune sandal, otherwise known as flip-flops with a red sole, which cost ¬£670 (they also come with a black sole, as worn by the actor Jonathan Bailey at an event to promote Jurassic World). But the brand is not alone. Items that have prompted similar outrage include a Loewe white vest for ¬£325 and the Italian brand Golden Goose‚Äôs ‚Äúdirty trainers‚Äù, which cost ¬£435. Balenciaga, during the decade that Demna has been the creative director, has provided copious items here, from ¬£720 Crocs, to a towel ‚Äúskirt‚Äù that cost ¬£695 and a take on the Ikea Frakta bag for ¬£1,365.

Dal Chodha, the pathway leader of Central Saint Martins‚Äô fashion communication course, is familiar with the genre. ‚ÄúThis one in particular is brilliant because it‚Äôs so well positioned for us to take offence, in the most exquisite way,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs an awful lot of [questions] that come out of looking at that shoe. The first is the one that most people ask themselves when they look at [a] work of art or any piece of luxury fashion: ‚ÄòWhy does that cost that much?‚Äô‚Äù

Taking something ordinary and putting it into a different context has a tradition in the visual arts, one that Balenciaga‚Äôs Demna is definitely influenced by. See Marcel Duchamp‚Äôs urinal in 1917, Jeff Koons‚Äôs 1980 vacuum cleaner and Martin Creed‚Äôs light switch from 2000, all items that have prompted public rage.

But if art remains elitist due to the fact that most people can‚Äôt buy it, everyone wears clothes, so consumers feel more invested when everyday items are sold for higher prices. This has long created a tension; Daniel Rodgers, the fashion news editor at Vogue, describes it as ‚Äúan inverse form of snobbery from people who have always been cynical of luxury fashion anyway‚Äù ‚Äì but it is exacerbated by online discourse. ‚ÄúEveryone‚Äôs voice is amplified so now we‚Äôre hearing more from the people that don‚Äôt get [items such as the Ama],‚Äù says Chodha.

The wider news cycle is also a factor. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm interested in who‚Äôs defending that shoe, and is it defendable,‚Äù says Chodha. ‚ÄúI would‚Äôve been that person a while ago but now with all of the wars happening around the world and all of the economic struggles that we‚Äôre all going through, I just think this is a bit insane.‚Äù

skip past newsletter promotion

after newsletter promotion

Rodgers says the flatness of online exacerbates the reaction. ‚ÄúFashion is mediated mostly now through onscreen images,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúIn the case of the Balenciaga Ikea shopping bag, you look at a picture of it on the screen and you think ‚ÄòWhat? I can pick that up from Ikea for 75p!‚Äô, but what you don‚Äôt see on screen is actually leather and it is actually made like a luxury item.‚Äù

title: ‚ÄòMade in Italy‚Äô: is the label just another luxury fashion illusion?
excerpt: For years shoppers have been aware of scandals about the origins of cheap clothing sold in high street stores. Garment industry workers who make clothes for leading brands have been beaten for asking for living wages and notes pleading for help have been found hidden in clothi‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
For years shoppers have been aware of scandals about the origins of cheap clothing sold in high street stores. Garment industry workers who make clothes for leading brands have been beaten for asking for living wages and notes pleading for help have been found hidden in clothing. There have also been stories about hidden child labour and some workers in UK factories are feared to be trapped in modern slavery.

Now after a series of labour investigations by Milanese prosecutors, the luxury fashion industry is fast coming under similar scrutiny.

Last week, Loro Piana, the 100-year-old Italian brand that sells four-figure cashmere jumpers and whose ‚Äúquiet luxury‚Äù aesthetic had been championed by celebrities including Gwyneth Paltrow and worn by the super-rich characters in the TV show Succession, was placed under a 12-month court administration over alleged worker exploitation.

The ruling arises from an investigation into Italy‚Äôs luxury goods supply chain that began in 2023. According to the court, Loro Piana ‚Äì owned by the luxury conglomerate LVMH ‚Äì outsourced production of some clothing including cashmere jackets to an external Chinese-operated fashion company, which in turn subcontracted the work to two other companies. These were illegal workshops that operated on the outskirts of Milan. In May, the labour crime unit of the Carabinieri military police found that 10 Chinese people, five of whom were undocumented migrants, were forced to work up to 90 hours a week for as little as ‚Ç¨4 per hour, as reported by Reuters.

It is worth noting that the brand is not under criminal investigation and if the company complies with a set of legal requirements before the deadline issued by the court, the order will be lifted.

In a statement to the Guardian, Loro Piana said the supplier had not informed the company of the existence of subcontractors. It also said: ‚ÄúLoro Piana was made aware of this situation on 20 May, and, as a result, the Maison terminated all relations with the concerned supplier in less than 24 hours.‚Äù

However, news of the order has further tainted the idea of the ‚ÄúMade in Italy‚Äù label, a term that typically denotes high-quality manufacturing.

Loro Piana is now the fifth fashion house to be placed under court monitoring in Italy since 2023. Armani and LVMH‚Äôs Dior have both faced similar action over the last year. In February the monitoring orders placed on them were lifted early as the court said both brands had taken all the necessary corrective action before the 12-month deadline assigned to them had passed. In May a subdivision of Valentino, Valentino Bags Lab Srl, was also placed under judicial administration.

Last year, an investigation by Italian police found that Armani bags that retail for ‚Ç¨1,800 were being made by a Chinese subcontractor for ‚Ç¨93 and then sold on to the group by an intermediary for ‚Ç¨250. A Dior subsidiary was sanctioned for paying as little as ‚Ç¨53 for bags that retail for more than ‚Ç¨2,000, the FT reported.

Loro Piana released a statement about the difference between the price tag on its clothing and the supposed cost to produce it. According to the recent Italian investigation into Loro Piana, some jackets from the brand that can retail for more than ‚Ç¨3,000 were being produced for as little as ‚Ç¨118. The statement said: ‚ÄúThe reported cost figures are not representative of the amounts paid by Loro Piana to its supplier, nor do they consider the full value of all the elements, including, among others, raw materials and fabrics.‚Äù

For many consumers, there is a perception that luxury and ethics go hand in hand. But Deborah Lucchetti, who works as a national coordinator at the Italian segment of Clean Clothes Campaign, a network dedicated to improving working conditions and empowering workers in the global garment industry, says that this is an illusion. ‚ÄúLuxury is based on a production system founded on cost reduction, profit maximisation and opaque supply chains based on subcontracting, which often employ immigrant workers who have no protection and contracts,‚Äù she says.

title: ‚ÄòYou sold it ‚Äì now recycle it‚Äô: the protesters mailing worn-out clothes to the shops they bought them from
excerpt: In February, a threadbare polycotton bedsheet landed on the desk of Simon Roberts, CEO of Sainsbury‚Äôs. A ‚Äúprotest by post‚Äù, it had been sent by the Sheffield-based designer, maker and eco activist Wendy Ward. ‚ÄúI purchased this from Sainsbury‚Äôs at least 10 years ago,‚Äù she wrote‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
In February, a threadbare polycotton bedsheet landed on the desk of Simon Roberts, CEO of Sainsbury‚Äôs. A ‚Äúprotest by post‚Äù, it had been sent by the Sheffield-based designer, maker and eco activist Wendy Ward. ‚ÄúI purchased this from Sainsbury‚Äôs at least 10 years ago,‚Äù she wrote in the accompanying letter. ‚ÄúIt has served me well. However, I have no sustainable options available for what I should do with it.‚Äù Beyond repair, it was too damaged to donate to a charity shop, she explained. She couldn‚Äôt compost it as it had been blended with polyester, and she couldn‚Äôt repurpose it as cleaning cloths, as, being polycotton, it wasn‚Äôt absorbent. And, she added, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to put it into a textile recycling collection as the likelihood is that it will be shipped overseas or incinerated and not recycled.‚Äù Ward qualified her assertions with links to respected sources ‚Äì as a sustainable fashion PhD student, she is well informed on such matters.

‚ÄúThe only action I can personally take,‚Äù she continued, ‚Äúis to put it into my general waste bin. I don‚Äôt want to do this, as in Sheffield all general waste is incinerated as ‚Äòenergy recovery‚Äô. This isn‚Äôt a sustainable option as such processes have been shown to be as damaging to local air pollution as burning coal.‚Äù So, she concluded, ‚Äúas Sainsbury‚Äôs is responsible for designing and manufacturing this product, making decisions to use polycotton with no consideration for what could be done once it reaches the end of its life, I have decided to return it to you. I would really love to hear what you decide to do with it.‚Äù

Sainsbury‚Äôs response, sent from its executive office, was ‚Äúa lame fob-off‚Äù, Ward says, and read as if it had been ‚Äúcut and pasted from a complaints template‚Äù. (Sample platitude: ‚ÄúSainsbury‚Äôs always welcome feedback from customers.‚Äù) But when she shared her protest with her 20,000 Instagram followers, the resounding approval ‚Äì ‚ÄúBrilliant!‚Äù ‚ÄúPlease upload your template‚Äù ‚Äì motivated her to launch a campaign: #TakeItBack. She created an adaptable, deliberately non-combative letter (‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre confrontational, it won‚Äôt go anywhere,‚Äù she tells me), and encouraged her followers to return their dead clothes to brands. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an empowering action,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúI was wresting back a bit of control as a consumer.‚Äù

I joined Ward‚Äôs #TakeItBack campaign, sending my daughter‚Äôs ravaged school tights to Marks & Spencer‚Äôs CEO, Stuart Machin. To the UK heads of Uniqlo and H&M, I sent my kids‚Äô damaged polyester-blend T-shirts, and to French Connection‚Äôs CEO, a greyed, misshapen T-shirt of mine that‚Äôs so timeworn, it‚Äôs transparent, all accompanied by a version of Ward‚Äôs letter. I know they‚Äôve all been received, because I tracked them, on Ward‚Äôs advice; similarly, I washed everything first. M&S was the first to respond, reminding me about its ‚Äúindustry-leading sustainability programme‚Äù, Plan A, and its take-back scheme. Uniqlo sent a letter acknowledging mine, and ‚Äúwill respond as soon as possible‚Äù. I haven‚Äôt heard back from H&M or French Connection yet.

Ward recommends following up if they don‚Äôt answer the key questions: ‚ÄúWhat would you suggest I do with this item?‚Äù and ‚ÄúWhat are you actually doing about this problem?‚Äù She‚Äôs unsure how many people have joined her campaign, though she doesn‚Äôt expect vast numbers yet: ‚ÄúI know I‚Äôm preaching to the converted.‚Äù

You may be thinking: why not donate your unwanted clothes and other textiles to a charity shop? End-of-life textiles have for many years been a valuable revenue stream for charities. Rag merchants would buy them by weight and sell them on to be down-cycled into stuffing, blankets, wipes etc. But many UK charity shops are now ‚Äúhaving to spend money getting rid of waste textiles‚Äù, says Dawn Dungate, an independent consultant who advises charities on textile recycling. Indeed, Ward‚Äôs protest was inspired by a sign in her local charity shop asking customers to dispose of ‚Äúdamaged, torn or worn-out items‚Äù in the bin, ‚Äúas the cost of disposal is very high‚Äù.

title: Bond Bosstick: The Birth Story
excerpt: Baby Bond is about 12 weeks old now and recently I was ripped out of my maternity leave to record his birth story. Be sure to listen to the full episode here , but I wanted to share it on the blog as well.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Baby Bond is about 12 weeks old now and recently I was ripped out of my maternity leave to record his birth story. Be sure to listen to the full episode here, but I wanted to share it on the blog as well.

I‚Äôve mentioned before that this blog is like a diary of my life. Almost like a scrapbook of the last 15 years that I hope my kids look at one day to see the evolution of myself, our businesses, our life as a family and all the stuff in between.

So let‚Äôs get right to the day before Bond was born. BOND! He‚Äôs so cute. Such a dreamboat. And a big boy.

Anyway, on June 11 I went into the office, did 6000 conference calls, got my hair and makeup done and did all the things I needed to do to feel ready and prepared for the next day. I had it scheduled to be induced, because like I said, he was measuring big.

I went to bed early, read my Kindle (check out all my book reccommendations here), my bags were packed and things were calm. Until the next morning. We woke up and Michael was his usual panicky Susan. This is our 3rd child and every single time, the morning of, he is a nut. He gets so high strung and if you don‚Äôt believe me, watch this Reel.

He get nervous and I get it. But I‚Äôm not, so his nervousness projects onto me. So I really had to ZIP up. I literally woke up and did a Joe Dispenza meditation, I think, at 5:30 in the morning because I knew that he was going to be nervous and projecting onto me.

So I just imagined I was surroundied by a big ball of good energy and I wasn‚Äôt going to let him penetrate it. Again, I knew he‚Äôd be like this. When he acted like this when I had Zaza I was shocked, and he did it with Townes too, so this time I was more prepared for his vibe. He was a bit more calm, but still panicked. He was moving around the house, making noise at 6am while the other kdis were asleep and crashing around to push me to leave the house.

Finally, we get in the car. Keep in mind, there‚Äôs like no real, real urgency, we can be chill. We can be calm. We got to the hospital. He had packed about 60 bags. He brought his sleeping bag, a bag for hte sleeping bag, his hair gel, Old Blue (his hair brush), a silk pillowcase, chargers, video games, iPad. It was extravagant. As if he was going off to sea.

Meanwhile, I went minimal. Now I know you only use a handful of things. And one of the best things I brought were the Frida Mom ice packs. Your crack them, then they turn freezing cold. It‚Äôs heaven.

I‚Äôm pretty particular with the hospital, meaning I don‚Äôt want my stuff touching anything in the hospital. I just get nervous about the germs being brought into my home. I‚Äôm not trying to be offensive to anyone who works in a hospital, it‚Äôs just something I think about. So I just brought a bunch of little things.

Along with my Kindle, iPad and ice pads I brought an ice roller, some changes of clothes, Djerf Avenue pajamas (so comfortable ‚Äì I got baby blue) and a Barefoot Dreams blanket. My hot tip for every mom in the hopsital is to get one and put it underneath you in the hospital bed. I brought another one to replace it after I gave birth and it was so nice to feel like I had a piece of my home.

title: Tennis is serving! How the US Open went high fashion
excerpt: It has been one of the breakout stories of the US Open: not the surprising second-round exits, nor the at-the-net spats , but the freshly shorn head and Barbie-pink tank top of the winner, Carlos Alcaraz. The outsize reaction to the Spanish phenomenon‚Äôs new look is the latest ‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
It has been one of the breakout stories of the US Open: not the surprising second-round exits, nor the at-the-net spats, but the freshly shorn head and Barbie-pink tank top of the winner, Carlos Alcaraz. The outsize reaction to the Spanish phenomenon‚Äôs new look is the latest example of the final grand slam of the year attracting attention not just for sporting prowess, but for the style moments it serves.

The Guardian‚Äôs journalism is independent. We will earn a commission if you buy something through an affiliate link.¬†Learn more.

Take, for instance, former champion Naomi Osaka, who crashed out to Amanda Animisova in Thursday‚Äôs semi-final, but not before sparkling under the night lights in a custom Nike indigo zip-up jacket embellished with Swarovski crystals, worn over a bubble-hem minidress. For her opening match, she wore a rose headpiece. (Also present throughout Osaka‚Äôs tournament: a series of bejewelled Labubu dolls, created by accessories line A-Morir, with monikers including ‚ÄúBillie Jean Bling‚Äù and ‚ÄúAndre Swagassi‚Äù.) The getup was ‚Äúreally elaborate‚Äù, Osaka admitted in a press conference, but it‚Äôs the kind of statement outfit her fans have come to expect and appreciate.

Lacoste, the longtime kit supplier of Novak Djokovic, who was beaten by Alcaraz last week, has created a five-piece ‚ÄúGOAT‚Äù (greatest of all time) capsule, with the famous crocodile logo replaced by ‚Ä¶ well, you can guess which animal. But it was the 24-time slam winner‚Äôs first-round walk-on jacket that caused the most noise: a white windbreaker with laser-cut pieces of leather layered to form a low relief of a world map, and dotted with coloured tennis balls to match different court surfaces..

While tennis has always had a close relationship with fashion, or at least, style ‚Äì from Fred Perry‚Äôs sharp slacks and Suzanne Lenglen‚Äôs pleated skirt and headscarf to Andre Agassi‚Äôs denim shorts (originally made for John McEnroe, who turned them down) and Serena Williams‚Äô catsuit ‚Äì the walk from locker room to baseline has become its own catwalk.

Add to that last year‚Äôs hit tennis film, Challengers, and a fresh crop of personable stars with exciting play styles, and there is now a greater appetite for a sport that had rather lost its cultural way. US Open ticket sales are up 70% in the past five years.

‚ÄúFashion brands of all price ranges are heavily interested in tennis right now because the sport is hot, and they follow the eyeballs and money,‚Äù says Jessica Schiffer, a fashion business journalist who writes the Hard Court newsletter. Behemoths like Gucci, Louis Vuitton and Bottega Veneta have all brought high-profile players on board (Jannik Sinner, Alcaraz and Lorenzo Musetti respectively) and smaller, boutique non-athleisure brands are creating lines that reference the tenniscore aesthetic. Meanwhile, Depop, the second-hand clothing app, has reported a 53% increase in searches for tennis skirts.

The wealthy, upper-class roots of the sport have long seen heritage brands associated with it, but now the likes of Rolex and Ralph Lauren are no longer dominating play.

Venus Williams has a prominent relationship with Lacoste ‚Äì she even wore a Pelagia Kolotouros-created dress to the Met Gala ‚Äì but this year she worked with her stylist, Ronald Burton III, to further wow the Flushing Meadows front row. Among her looks were a Merino wool kit designed by US brand Luar ; a fun, butter-yellow shearling racket bag, custom made by ERL‚Äôs Eli Russell Linnetz; and a Pucci dress .

Daniel-Yaw Miller, who covers fashion for the Sportsverse newsletter, predicts the influx of brand interest means traditional kit makers will have to up their game. While Nike might be ensuring Osaka dazzles and Alcaraz catches the eye in a lush plum twinset, its ready-to-wear tennis apparel has trended towards drab. Miller points to the number of stars, including the popular Americans Taylor Fritz and Frances Tiafoe, who have left the iconic Nike swoosh behind ‚Äì following in the footsteps of Roger Federer, who moved from Nike to Uniqlo in a $300m deal back in 2018.

title: Are US fashion brands at risk of growing anti-American backlash over Trump policies?
excerpt: An effortlessly cool Nick Kamen strolls into a launderette, strips to his boxer shorts and washes his jeans in front of a stunned clientele, soundtracked by Marvin Gaye‚Äôs I Heard It Through the Grapevine. The 1985 Levi‚Äôs 501 advert made a star of its model, and presented an im‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
An effortlessly cool Nick Kamen strolls into a launderette, strips to his boxer shorts and washes his jeans in front of a stunned clientele, soundtracked by Marvin Gaye‚Äôs I Heard It Through the Grapevine. The 1985 Levi‚Äôs 501 advert made a star of its model, and presented an image in keeping with the clothing brand‚Äôs all-American style.

But could that deep-seated association with the US prove an achilles heel? Last week, in its UK accounts, Levi‚Äôs issued a warning that ‚Äúrising anti-Americanism as a consequence of the Trump tariffs and governmental policies‚Äù could affect its sales in Britain. The idea is not unique ‚Äì attitudes towards Tesla in the UK and Europe deteriorated when Elon Musk was closely associated with Trump. However, the Levi‚Äôs warning raises the question ‚Äì could fashion become the latest sector affected by anti-American sentiment outside the US?

Retail and brand experts are divided. Achim Berg, the founder of the Germany-based fashion and luxury thinktank FashionSights, was surprised by the Levi‚Äôs warning ‚Äì he sees the company as a different case from something such as Tesla or Amazon, which are ‚Äúdirectly associated with the US [government]‚Äù. This is in contrast to other companies. ‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt seen any reports about people holding back on Apple, holding back on Netflix. If you think about it, we are all using plenty of US products and services every day.‚Äù

However, Catherine Shuttleworth, a retail consultant and the chief executive of Savvy Marketing, does think there is a risk. ‚ÄúPeople are thinking twice about going on holiday to America and about buying some of those products,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúIf I was [a retailer of an] all-American product, I would be thinking about how I presented myself differently in terms of my advertising and marketing.‚Äù

Any sign of an anti-Americanism trend would cause a headache for an industry benefiting from the popularity of Americana and preppy looks.

Labels such as Hollister, Ralph Lauren and Brandy Melville are popular ‚Äì the last opened a new store in London in June.

Hollister‚Äôs parent company, Abercrombie & Fitch, posted a 12% rise in profit in its Europe, the Middle East and Africa division in 2024 and searches for Polo Ralph Lauren increased 27% on the resale app Depop between July and August.

Alex Goat, the chief executive of the youth-focused creative agency Livity, says this look plugs into an idealised version of the US that is served in popular TV shows such as The Summer I Turned Pretty and My Life with the Walter Boys. ‚ÄúThey are not reflecting the political issues that are going on in the States at the moment. They‚Äôre the same halcyon American days that we all probably thought about when we were growing up,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúIf that‚Äôs what you think America is, then where‚Äôs the challenge to buy from brands like that?‚Äù

Emma Davidson, the fashion features director of Dazed Digital, agrees this look is not a direct correlation with an all-American patriotism. ‚ÄúWe call it preppy and varsity style but it feels one step removed from what it once stood for,‚Äù she says.

Experts do, however, agree that overt patriotism is unlikely to export well. ‚ÄúIf you were Levi‚Äôs you wouldn‚Äôt be what you‚Äôve been leaning into [stars and stripes],‚Äù Shuttleworth says. ‚ÄúYou might use influencers that are not as American perhaps.‚Äù

Davidson points to a cultural example. ‚ÄúIt surprised me that Beyonc√© was plastered in stars and stripes throughout the Cowboy Carter tour,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúIt felt really out of step with what‚Äôs going on in the world.‚Äù

While these are global brands, appealing to US customers is an integral part of their business. ‚ÄúThe domestic markets for some of these brands absolutely blow their international sales out of the water,‚Äù Shuttleworth says. ‚ÄúThey will have to think strategically about who they appeal to in the short term.‚Äù With tariffs in place on imports, there is also an opportunity here ‚Äì with consumers potentially shifting, as Trump hopes, to ‚Äúbuying American‚Äù.

title: Move over fashion week: Chanel and Dior soft launch creations at Venice film festival
excerpt: After a year of musical chairs in the fashion industry, September is poised to be one of its biggest show months ever, with debut collections from 15 creative directors.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
After a year of musical chairs in the fashion industry, September is poised to be one of its biggest show months ever, with debut collections from 15 creative directors.

The Guardian‚Äôs journalism is independent. We will earn a commission if you buy something through an affiliate link.¬†Learn more.

Rather than waiting for the catwalk, over the past 10 days brands including Chanel and Dior have given themselves a head start at the Venice film festival, using its starry red carpets and even gondolas to soft launch looks from their newly installed designers.

Unlike the Oscars, which is one night of intense red-carpet scrutiny, or the Cannes film festival, which comes with strict rules, the focus at Venice is very much on notable art house films.

With the pressure off, it allows designers, stylists and their Hollywood clients the opportunity to have a bit more fun. Amanda Seyfried even borrowed the same Versace look from Julia Roberts. A triumph for sustainability or a marketing stunt? Either way, it was front-page news.

Jonathan Anderson, who took over at Dior in June, teased more than a dozen looks on actors including Greta Lee and Alba Rohrwacher before his womenswear debut in Paris next month. Lee wore a deconstructed minidress that riffed on the brand‚Äôs signature bar jacket, while Rohrwacher wore a navy gown with a padded bustle.

Meanwhile, Tilda Swinton hinted at what we can expect from Matthieu Blazy, the French-Belgian designer who recently landed the top job at Chanel, when she stepped off a water taxi wearing loosely cut white trousers and a short-sleeved blouse featuring tiny shimmering interlocking CC buttons.

Henrik Lischke, the senior fashion features editor at Grazia, likens this new preview strategy to the press tour of the Barbie film in 2023. ‚ÄúThat proved that the more hype you create, the more attention you get. These fashion brands are giving us a glimpse of what to expect,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt gets people excited long before a look even hits the catwalk.‚Äù

It can also catapult relatively unknown names into the spotlight. In April, when it was announced Dario Vitale would be taking over from Donatella Versace, he was a designer only industry insiders were familiar with. But this week he was the talk of the lido, thanks to that sneak peek via Roberts and Seyfried.

Pop stars such as Taylor Swift are known for planting Easter eggs, hidden clues about future projects for fans to decipher. Paparazzi shots of actors on set are used as unofficial teasers. And now it appears fashion designers are embracing the art of the promotional sneak peek too.

Fashion‚Äôs new soft launch was first embraced by the actor Timoth√©e Chalamet, who wore Haider Ackermann‚Äôs first outfit for Tom Ford to the Golden Globes, two months before the designer‚Äôs debut show. He also wore Sarah Burton‚Äôs first menswear look for Givenchy, a butter-yellow suit, to the Oscars days before her inaugural Paris show. Vicky Krieps and Julianne Moore have also worn previews of Louise Trotter‚Äôs Bottega Veneta.

But similar to how on-set images have been blamed for ruining movie magic, could these early teasers backfire? Some online users have accused Versace of becoming boring, while others say Anderson‚Äôs purposefully chaotic pieces for Dior do not exactly scream Hollywood glamour.

Amy Odell, a fashion commentator and author of Gwyneth: The Biography, says while designers will be aware of early criticism, it is important to remember ‚Äúnot every look is for everybody‚Äù. As for disclosing too much, Odell is not worried. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think a whole lot is given away by one or two looks at a film festival ‚Äì I view it as a nice teaser of what‚Äôs to come, an amuse bouche versus a big spoiler.‚Äù
